RHA2IZMH0ZXMX;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A1WPFIZ8P3O86V;;Printer;;B005IVL0SC;;Epson WorkForce 645 Wireless All-in-One Color Inkjet Printer, Copier, Scanner, Fax, iOS/Tablet/Smartphone/AirPrint Compatible (C11CB86201);;Installed immediately with my home network, excellent quality;;I purchased this Epson printer because I needed a fax machine, and after some shopping around I ended up with this all-in-one unit (print, scan, copy, fax) that significantly upgrades my existing home network (why spend almost the same money for a stand-alone fax when you can get a fully capable printer with all of the latest features?). I selected this particular model because it was on sale at for half price at Staples but I also checked reviews carefully before purchasing and was satisfied that it has been rated very positively by other users.<br /><br />Prior to this purchase I have been using an HP b&w laserjet printer P1006 that is now four or five years old but continues to perform excellently, and a Canon injet printer (MP610) which has also worked fine and is under two years old. This Epson printer will eventually probably replace both as I use up the toner and ink supplies that I have on hand for those older printers, because the ink cost and efficiency of this printer are claimed to be much better than what I've been using.<br /><br />My usage is not heavy, I am using this for home needs and it is probably very light compared to some users.<br /><br />My home network consists of an iMac with Apple AirPort wi-fi. My existing printers were networked by plugging them directly into the AirPort device since they do not have wi-fi built in. Those printers have always given me intermittant problems in that they did not always respond immediately to print jobs sent to them. Whether that is due to printer software issues or something else, I don't really know. I've always kept the software drivers up-to-date.<br /><br />Setting up this new Epson printer was straightforward and easy. In fact it could not have been easier. Once the printer was powered up and ink installed, and the software installed on my computer, I used the setup screen on the printer for it to find the home network and log in. Once linked to my network, the computer recognized it and I added it to my list of printers. Just a very short time after unpacking it from the box, it is a part of my home network and printing seamlessly from all applications. I also ran Apple's software update program right after completing the installation and verifying operation of the printer, and it updated the printer driver so that it is completely up-to-date since I knew that the driver included with the CD may not have been the latest version (but it did not result in any problems with installation).<br /><br />I would therefore rate the wi-fi compatibility of this printer to be outstanding based upon the ease of connecting to my home network and the immediate availability for printing from the computer.<br /><br />Print quality is excellent for everything I have tried so far. I like the fact that this printer has a paper tray to hold the paper supply, rather than setting the paper vertically in a feeder (like my Canon printer uses), and the printer tray capacity is large at 250 sheets. The paper tray is also adjustable for various sizes including envelopes (for those who still send things through the US mail). The tray is somewhat flimsy as other reviewers have noted. It also has the capability for two-sided printing (as well as scanning and faxing), another feature I did not have previously. This printer uses separate cartridges for each ink color (I expect this is pretty standard these days for color inkjet printers).<br /><br />This printer has also given me two important features I did not previously have - scanning and faxing.<br /><br />For my first test of the scanning capability I scanned a CD booklet cover that I needed for my iTunes library (some older CD's, when loaded into the iTunes, do not find CD artwork in the database used. I've put most of my CD collection onto iTunes and have been frustrated in the past when I was not able to get the right artwork to go with the music in my iTunes library. Now I can scan in the artwork for those CD's which are not in the general database - finally!).<br /><br />The iMac comes with Image Capture software. All I had to do was open the Image Capture program, and it recognized the Epson scanner immediately. I put the CD booklet on the flatbed scanner and initiated the scan from the computer. It works perfectly. Lots of settings to play with; to vary resolution, rotate the image and so forth, which I think are probably more a function of the scanner software than they are of the scanner itself. I've also tried scanning objects that require the lid to be left open, with very good results. I am completely satisfied with the scanning capability, lots of things I can now do that I was unable to do before having this printer. (I should mention that the Canon MP610 also has scanning capability but I was never able to get it to work for me. Probably my fault for not putting enough effort into it, but again it illustrates for me at least how easy the setup was for this Epson unit).<br /><br />I've since used the scanning frequently, and it works very well. I am very satisfied with this feature<br /><br />Faxing is likewise troublefree. The initial setup is done at the computer where you program in the heading that you want printed to each sheet faxed, set the number of rings before picking up, and so forth. Also can program quick dial numbers so that they are available from the keypad on the fax machine itself. Very nice to be able to do these setup tasks on the computer rather than having to do it on the printer itself. My first fax transmission consisted of a 16 page document, and it fed through and faxed without trouble. Fax receipts have likewise been fully satisfactory.<br /><br />Finally, this Epson printer also includes "print-to-fax" software, so that I can now send a fax directly from the computer without needing to print the document first and then run it through the fax machine. The way this is implemented is that the available printer listing on the computer now includes this printer twice - the first time for printing normally, and the second listing for fax use (both are clearly labeled and differentiated). Select which one you want depending on what you want to do, and use the drop-down menus to either provide the fax number to send to, or use one of the quick dial numbers. Superb!<br /><br />I have not yet tried the AirPrint capability but that is one more thing this printer offers that may be of interest to others.<br /><br />For me, most of these features were a welcome upgrade from my previous setup, and I'm delighted with having this on my network at home. This is my first Epson product, and I'm looking forward to receiving good service from it. I will update this review over time as I gain experience with it and have more basis for reporting on reliability and any other issues or features I have not yet come across.;;5.0;;March 2, 2012;;11;;11;;1.0

R2DHNM2QJ2U6E5;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/ARFKWA4ZCF0AI;;Printer;;B005D5M12M;;Canon PIXMA MG5320 Wireless Inkjet Photo All-in-One Printer (5291B019);;Prints orange instead of red;;Canon's MG5320, like lower-end, recent generation Canon inkjets, can't seem to print red on plain paper. It's a shame as the 5320 otherwise seems pretty well designed. The paper drawer/tray is the actual bottom of the printer, making it more difficult to open, & they went to their older style, extending rear paper feed/support, but those are minor negatives I could live with if it didn't print red as orange. Also darker prints tended to have a blue or purplish tint [that can be compensated for in software], while all images/graphics printed to non-photo paper showed an awful lot of grain. We're more than happy to live with that level of print quality with our 1/2 dozen other Canon printers, but those are bottom dollar remans [~$25] used for everyday tasks where that sort of thing doesn't matter, & in fact on plain paper the output from 1 of our MX320s actually looked better than what we got from the MG 5320!<br /><br />One thing I immediately disliked was Canon put LEDs on their print cartridges to tell you the cartridge installed properly [they also can tell you when the ink is low or out, but I can't imagine opening the printer to check ink levels when with a mouse click you can see the same thing]. We pay enough for ink cartridges already without upping the costs by adding LEDs you don't need [perhaps an attempt to distinguish Canon ink from 3rd party replacements?].<br /><br />The included software is for the most part useless & unchanged from 3-4 year old versions. Their photo print app can't use ICC profiles or Windows color management in win7, makes it a lot of extra work to import an image to print on a CD/DVD, and makes you set the diameter of the CD/DVD printable area in inches rather than mm [& only goes to 2 decimal points, making it impossible to avoid non-printed, outer white rings]. There's very little in the way of printer ICC profiles &/or driver-based color adjustments.<br /><br />All in all I really wanted to like the MG5320, but in the end I simply couldn't justify keeping it -- I couldn't find any Positives to offset the Negatives. Cranking the driver's color adjustment over towards red helped a little, but not enough. The lack of red also meant some faces were completely washed out, looking like ghosts with no other features besides the eyes & mouth. Software was only a minor, negative issue, though the drivers left a lot of leftovers when uninstalled -- I've got other software I could have probably used to print CDs/DVDs/BDs, though the driver settings to use weren't immediately clear, & I have no idea how many discs I'd have to go through adjusting the print position. Time to print [before printing really started], especially with DVDs was very long. Ink usage seemed poor, & replacement cartridges aren't cheap compared to other brands. Using the same ink cartridges, & apparently the same software & driver controls, I'm not optimistic the higher end Canon models do better -- I'm skipping the brand for now.;;1.0;;January 3, 2012;;29;;36;;0.805556

R3HUE7X0N5RLT2;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/ATKS9BK52JYQG;;Printer;;B004IZN3RK;;Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Wireless Wide-Format Color Inkjet Printer (C11CA86201);;fantastic prints, great price, handles many professional papers;;I am an advanced amateur photographer, been shooting most of my life. [...] Due to budgetary constrictions, translation my sweet wife, I have been making a gradual move towards perfect color for the past 3-4 years. Perfection being unattainable of course, things you MUST have to get close to perfection include:<br /><br />1) A good camera, tons of good stuff on the market from Nikon and Canon. I use a Nikon D300. Shoot RAW files btw, take my word for it, Google it, end of the day its like having a time machine for things like white balance, exposure compensation, saturation levels, black levels, fill light, recovery, vibrance and on and on and on. With lossy jpg files...good luck. You can always export jpgs from your RAW files, so shoot RAW.<br /><br />2) A good monitor (doesn't have to be a $2,500 - $5,000 Eizo save your money for things that will get you closer to perfection with more bang for your buck). I'm using a 27" HD Viewsonic VX2739wm that is calibrated which leads me to #3.<br /><br />3) A way to calibrate your monitor and printer (with Epson pro papers, the ICC profiles they provide via download work exceptionally well, but you still MUST calibrate your monitor) take my word for it; get the Color Munki Photo (under $500 now) and it works amazingly well. Better than devices costing 5 - 7 times more just a few short years ago.<br /><br />4) Good photo editing software; I use Lightroom 3.3 and Photoshop CS5 but I have to tell you I spend 95% of my time in Lightroom so most bang for your buck is there. I use PS for retouching or being creative primarily, I never print from Photoshop. I always print from Lightroom, it has the best printing interface of anything on the market. If you are thinking yeah but I can't softproof in lightroom, that leads me to #5.<br /><br />5) Softproofing plugin for Lightroom: [...] This is a very important piece of the puzzle, if you don't learn how to softproof, you will never get close to perfect color and contrast in your prints. Visit the Luminous Landscape web site and download ($44) their "From Camera to Print" video series. They are updating it from the version I have that was shot in 2007, worth every penny. I learned more about color calibration and getting great prints watching this series than everything else I have seen and read combined.<br /><br />6) Professional paper, sorry you're not getting close with that off-the-shelf coated crap from Staples or Walmart and you need a good printer to handle professional papers which leads to #7.<br /><br />7) A good printer. The Epson R3000 fills the bill at a great price point. It uses the same print head, firmware and inks of printers costing thousands of dollars. If your print volume is low and 13" wide (panorama's up to 13 x 44) suits your need don't even think about the 3880. It doesn't handle roll paper (think canvas on hardboard or gallery wraps up to 11 x how long you want) or thicker fine art papers at all. The R3000 handles many more professional papers than the 3880 from Epson and from other manufacturers including Hahnem&uuml;hle with ICC profiles for the R3000. Forget the Epson 4900 with 200 ml ink cartridges if your volume is low. Those cartridges will run you a thousand bucks or more to replace and if you don't use them in a timely manner because you are terrified of the cost they could expire and do a wonderful job of clogging the print head. With a low volume you simply don't need it.<br /><br />I have nothing but praise for this printer. It is phenomenal. The roll feeder and WiFi are two great features. Check out RC Concepcion's (Photoshop User Magazine) review of this printer on YouTube.<br /><br />I have finally attained the contrast, color and black and white print quality I have been waiting for. Epson has bridged the gap for amateurs who want pro results with their prints with this printer.;;5.0;;December 16, 2011;;23;;24;;0.958333
R1H4XTG8FFAK2H;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A1I311QTGOYUV8;;Printer;;B003YT6RMY;;HP Photosmart eStation All-in-One (CQ140AB1H);;A Great Combo Device!!!;;I would highly recommend the eStation for the current price that is available (do some research as this can be had for about $250). Don't listen to the comments of people that just don't know how to use an Android Tablet. Some reviews I've read suggest that this tablet can only be used indoors on the same network as the printer...NOT TRUE, this is a tablet that has all of the same functionality as any Android 2.1 Tablet (plus all of the ePrint functions that you won't find on any other device) with the exception of the official Google Marketplace. To me, this is not a big deal as there are so many other ways to install Android Apps (alternate Markets, side-loading or direct downloads from the web). Some people have also complained about the Tablet being slow or laggy. This is not uncommon for any Android Tablet (with the possible exception of the Tegra2 processor Tablets) as there are many things that can be running in the background. The simple fix is to install a Task-Killer app that will shut down unused programs that are still running in the background. I would also recommend the purchase of the external power adapter/charger so that you can travel with the Zeen Tablet and not have to worry about losing power. I have over 100 working apps on the Zeen and counting. It plays all my music, videos, downloads YouTube videos, opens and edits Office documents, email, multiple web-browsers, etc. Unless you need a device that has 3G, you won't need anything else in a tablet. The way I look at it, I paid less than $250 for a great Tablet and got a great FREE wifi-enabled printer. Oh, and one more thing, for those that have complained that they don't like the HP User-Interface as opposed to the standard Android UI, why not just install a Home-Screen replacement app like LauncherPro that way you can make your Zeen tablet look like every other Android device?<br /><br />UPDADE: 3/18/11:<br />HP just released their Beta Program for Android Froyo 2.2. The instructions are in some ways almost too simple. If you can follow pictures you are probably okay. But if you ever ask 'why' questions or want to know what you're doing and why, you won't get anything like that and installation may be harder for you.<br /><br />The printer is 'smart', and not always in a good way. It takes a very long time - orders of minutes - to initialize. Many times I have had to turn the printer on because I forgot to do so in advance. And then had to wait several MINUTES while it initialized. This is not a one-time process. This is an everytime I turn the power on process. The printer is fond of cleaning its print heads often too, which may be unexpected if this is  your first 'smart' printer.  The HP  Deskjet 6122 I had previously (another double-sided and image printer) was quieter, smaller and much faster responding to print commands. The 6122 dual-sided paper handling was done entirely internally. The new OfficeJet Pro 8500A Plus uses a separate mechanical dual-sided paper handler that frankly is very kludgy. And it often bends paper. The paper eject is quite forceful; it often lands on the table in front of the printer and not atop the document tray which I think is the intended design.<br /><br />Installing the scanner software seems to be a bit problematic. It does not work directly out of the box; at least it did not for me. This might be a setup error, although I tried to follow the limited instructions correctly. There seems to be a missing software component which I finally located and installed manually. Honestly, if I weren't a software professional I don't think I would have ever figured this part out.<br /><br />I cannot comment on the fax capabilities. Again there is a bit to the setup and I am not currently configured for it. I would be suspicious however given the other minor surprises that have popped up.<br /><br />I have to admit that overall I am NOT IMPRESSED with the HP OfficeJet 8500A Plus. It looked like a good idea. I wanted an 'all-in-one' printer, scanner, copier with fax capabilities. This particular printer DOES NOT DELIVER is my opinion.  I would strongly suggest that anyone contemplating buying this printer (or any HP printer in the OfficeJet product line) demand to see every aspect of the printer demonstrated on a live system. Lacking that, I must RECOMMEND AGAINST BUYING THIS PRODUCT! Do so online with no prior evaluation AT YOUR OWN RISK!;;3.0;;March 3, 2011;;6;;7;;0.857143

R3KTP8U16EWTLE;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A2D2LHBRSV4ZUV;;Printer;;B001PO6IL0;;HP Officejet Pro 8000 Wireless Printer;;Warning: HP's hand will be in your pocket.;;I really have no complaints about the print quality or the setup of the wireless function, which is a great convenience in a home network. The reason this printer is going to the recycler is the cost of operation due to HP's decision to gouge consumers on replacement ink cartidges.<br /><br />If you look up the unit price on replacement cartridges, it does not sound unreasonable: roughly thirty USD for the black cartridge and twenty USD each for the three color cartridges. However, what you need to be aware of is that the printer decides when the cartridges need to be replaced and WILL NOT FUNCTION until you comply.<br /><br />This is a change from a few years ago, when you would receive a low ink warning but could still print until the cartridge actually emptied. This disabling of all print functions may be becoming a standard industry practice but, in my experience, is particularly egregious with this HP printer.<br /><br />It is no coincidence that all four cartridges are flagged as needing replacement at roughly the same time.  Even if you have been printing only black and white draft copies in the interval since replacement, the color cartridges will be flagged as empty after a few months.<br /><br />As this happens, at the least, twice a year, you will be spending close to two hundred dollars a year to maintain even minimum function.<br /><br />After literally a mere few months, using the "high-capacity" XL cartridges and extremely rare use (I rarely print more than a dozen pages per month), this printer is once again disabled due to an entirely fictitious low-ink warning.  This function is clearly not triggered by actual use, the number of pages printed or the volume of ink remaining.  It is based entirely on an algortithm combining some arbitrary time since cartridge installation and HP's greed.<br /><br />Again: The resident software decides when you will replace the ink cartridges (of which there are four) and it will not print so much as a single page until you do.<br /><br />If you print enough pages in both black and white and color, and exhaust the cartridges in a short period of time, you may consider this printer a good value.<br /><br />Read many of the four and five star reviews carefully: "I've had this printer one month and I love it", "I've had it for one day...", etc.  I'm happy for them, but I have owned this printer for fifteen months and am replacing it.<br /><br />This will be my last HP printer.<br /><br />UPDATE: I have received (11/18/2010) notice of a settlement offer in response to three lawsuits filed against HP alleging fraudulent practices related to the issues noted above.  Quote: "HP denies all these claims" but will offer coupons redeemable at the HP online store (only) as compensation.  One can therefore assume they intend to continue these practices. HP is offering an insulting maximum six dollar credit for qualifying printers. For more information: hpinkjetprintersettlement dot com;;1.0;;October 22, 2010;;246;;250;;0.984

Automatic setup did not work as advertised, so I inserted the driver CD and installed from there.  I requested a wireless setup and did the steps manually just to be safe.  It confirmed my SSID, and it asked for my network password.  It then installed the driver and the blue light on the printer turned solid blue.  I unplugged USB and printed a test page.  It worked.<br /><br />Back to the Mac, I replaced its USB cable then went into Print & Scan preferences under Settings.  The USB printer was defined there.  But I wanted wireless.  So I followed R. Ruiz's instructions again, and got past step 9.  It turns out that wireless was already setup.  This was confirmed by going to<br /><br />1) Click Open Print Queue<br />2) Click on Open Printer Utility (this displayed the printer's web page)<br />3) Click on the Networking tab<br />4) Click on Wireless link on left<br /><br />At that point, I was able to confirm settings that had been established during the Windows 7 install.<br /><br />I then<br /><br />5) Clicked OK on the print queue window<br />6) Closed the print queue<br />7) Deleted the printer from the Print & Scan list by highlighting it and clicking the '-' button<br />8) Clicked the '+' button and selected "Add other printer or scanner"<br />9) Selected "HP LaserJet Professional P1102w" with Kind Bonjour and clicked Add<br /><br />The printer was set up.  I printed a test page from the Mac and it worked.  I revisited the iPad and tried AirPrint, and the printer was displayed.  I printed from the iPad and it worked, too.  (AirPrint probably would have worked once wireless was set up on the Windows 7 machine.)<br /><br />So in summary...wireless setup did not really work on the Mac under Mac OS 10.7, it was only because I had a Windows machine that I could get it to work.<br /><br />Edit...later...I found a procedure that looks like it will allow you to set up wireless on a Mac running Mac OS 10.7.  I will summarize it here:<br /><br />1) Power the printer on,<br />2) Go to the Airport icon on the Mac's menu bar and click on it.  Select the network associated with the HP printer.<br />3) Go into Safari.  Ignore the warning that you are not connected to the Internet.  You aren't, instead you are connected to the web server on the printer<br />4) From the Bookmarks menu, select Show All Bookmarks<br />5) Under Collections, s&eacute;lect Bonjour<br />6) Double click the HP LaserJet Professional P1102w bookmark<br />7) Click on the Networking tab<br />8) Click on the Wireless link on the left hand side<br />9) Select Infrastructure<br />10) Under Network Name (SSID) click Refresh.<br />11) Select your Network Name by highlighting it and clicking the &lt;&lt; button<br />12) Select your Security Mode.  Enter your passphrase if you have one.<br />13) Click on Apply<br /><br />The web  page will disappear.  At this point, go to the Airport icon in the menu bar and connect back to your wireless network.<br /><br />Proceed with Software Update (which, in theory, will install the latest printer driver).  If that does not work, download and install the latest driver from the HP site.<br /><br />If the printer does not show up under Print & Scan preferences, add it as a Bonjour printer, as detailed above.<br /><br />This should take the Windows laptop out of the mix when installing wireless!;;4.0;;June 9, 2012;;5;;5;;1.0
R3JG2AKDBZ41NX;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/AR6QTTIQ7P4DV;;Printer;;B005O55U2Y;;HP Officejet Pro 8600 Plus  e-All-in-One Wireless Color Printer with Scanner, Copier & Fax;;Excellent economical multi-function machine;;I'll start by saying that I think this is an excellent machine.<br /><br />My journey of buying a multi-function printer started with purchasing an HP Officejet Pro 8500 all-in-one.  This was a top-rated machine, and I was excited when it arrived.  Unfortunately, the particular 8500 that we received, although easy to setup, jammed constantly.  After a week of jamming headaches, I headed online to Amazon to arrange for a return.  When considering a replacement, I saw that the 8600 series OfficeJet printers had arrived, so I needed to consider them as well.  At only about $25 more than I had paid for the 8500, I took the plunge.<br /><br />The first decision with the 8600 was which of the three models to order.  The basic model was quite attractively priced, and has features similar to the Plus and Pro models.  The Plus model's big advantage (in our case) was the larger display.  Other features separating it from the basic model are the larger automatic document feeder (50 vs 35 sheets) and a slightly faster print speed (20 vs 18 ppm black and 16 vs 13 ppm color, according to the HP website.)  Had we upgraded to the "Premium" model, we could have added an additional 250-sheet paper tray.  The Premium model might be appropriate for a small workgroup which does does lots of printing, but in our case, would be extreme overkill based on our printing volumes -- one ream of paper can last us many months!<br /><br />Display: This printer went to my mother-in-law's house - and she's not the most tech-savvy consumer.  We chose the "Plus" model because of the larger display - and it was a great choice!  The display is great - large, bright, and intuitive.  My mother-in-law has no problem completing most tasks and following the very good on-screen video instructions.<br /><br />Configuration: The printer was easy to configure without even connecting to a computer using the on-screen display to connect to the wi-fi network.  In all, it probably took about 10-15 minutes, most of which was allowing the printer to complete its self-configuration checks and print head alignment.  The software was easy to install on the computer, and the computer was able to discover the printer on the network almost instantly using the drivers on the included CD-ROM.<br /><br />Printing: Print quality is quite good and very fast -- the last time I purchased an inkjet printer was about 7 years ago, and the one this one replaced was 8 years old.  Speed has come a long way in that time!<br /><br />Copying: Again, this was quite simple.  I especially like the easy on-screen options for dealing with two-sided originals and copies, allowing for all duplexing options without any additional fuss or difficulty.<br /><br />Faxing: Also a straightforward operation, there were a few points worthy of comment.  First, the fax self-configuration was great, and I appreciated the self-check during the setup process so that sending a "test fax" to someone was not necessary.  Also, it worked fine with the AT&T U-Verse digital phone service -- not all fax devices play well with digital phone services, so this was very nice.  My mother-in-law also commented about how she appreciated that you can enter the destination fax number before inserting the document to be faxed into the feeder - a nice feature as the destination fax number is usually at the top of the front page, which is often hidden by the document feeder once inserted.<br /><br />Scanning: The network scanning was quite easy, and worked seamlessly - something not true of all network scan devices.  My previous experience had been that devices scanning over the network have some usability problems, and that they work best when connected directly to the computer.  No issues here, however - it worked great right out of the box with no physical connection to the computer.<br /><br />Driver: The included drivers on the CD-ROM worked just fine, as well as those downloaded from the HP website.  My one small complaint is that when auto-discovering the printer using Windows 7, Windows fails to install a usable driver.  The user must first go to the HP website, download an appropriate driver, then install the driver directly.  These extra steps were time-consuming and annoying - but not enough for me to deduct a star.<br /><br />Ink: The ink cartridges were very easy to insert and replace.  I particularly appreciate that they are simple units and don't have the tape-covered electrical contacts common on the older generation of cartridges which could sometimes come off during installation.<br /><br />Overall: I give this printer a strong recommendation, and 5 stars.  You may need to decide which model is best for you -- depending on pricing, the larger display of the "Plus" model might not be worthwhile, and the price of the basic model is quite attractive.  For us and our given user, the larger display was key and worth the extra cost.  I'd buy one again!;;5.0;;January 25, 2012;;57;;57;;1.0

R3BG2A8KFGG98R;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/AMZHT6EKLICB5;;Printer;;B002PLQ7LI;;Epson Stylus Pro 3880 Color Inkjet Printer (CA61201-VM);;They've almost got perfect;;I almost felt bad not rating this printer at 5 stars, but it does have a couple small problems that make it less than perfect.  First off, it is a remarkable machine that produces superb prints of artwork.  All final digital product is, of course, dependent on the filtering and scanning that the intake and digital manipulation software provide, but the quality of printing for line drawings, ink washes, and similar works really impressed me.  I have not done a lot with photograph reproduction, but what I have done was also impressive.<br /><br />It is not, however, a perfect machine.  The settings process which has to be done per print, or saved as a custom batch setting is cumbersome.  The layout is a bit awkward and makes it difficult to remember to go through every setting and tweak it for your particular batch printing job.  You can establish your own profiles, but not every setting is included in the profile which means you might still have to tweak the settings for even the  minute differences in a batch.  As per tech support, the layout options per print are dependent on the software you are using to order the print job.  The manual paper feed at the rear of the machine is EXTREMELY sensitive to paper being cocked a little to one side or the other (so sensitive that I truly believe it is imagining things).  I am actually completely unable to determine what the problem is in each instance, and simply wiggle the paper a tad in its position, and try again.  The output print is pushed hard against the right side of the machine, which is ridiculous considering the amount of space there is to work with.  It tends to catch on the sundry little irregularities and joints in the plastic located there when using thin/flimsy paper.  Thicker paper seems to glide over it without issue.<br /><br />All in all, I can highly recommend it for quality of output and economy of use (relative use of "economy" here - these are very high quality prints and not dirt cheap), but it is not a 'set it and forget it' producer of batch prints. You do need to stay on it from start to finish.  The last and final aggravation is that if you miss setting a paper-type change that requires matte black ink when you've been using photo black ink or vice versa, it undergoes a purge of the system, spilling all the 'other' type of ink into a waste tray.  This is better than having to change out ink cartridges, but once it begins there is no way to stop it without shutting down the machine mid process which I'm sure is not recommended.  However, if you don't, it will finish purging the one type of ink and then reloading with the other, and will do the whole thing in reverse when you correct your settings.  A phenomenal waste of ink.  There desperately needs to be an "abort" button to halt all processes in mid stride considering how easily you can miss a setting.;;4.0;;July 27, 2010;;33;;33;;1.0

R2J99PWPS8OVMM;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/AQZSBIJZQ9DOR;;Printer;;B00450DVDY;;Brother HL-2270DW Compact Laser Printer with Wireless Networking and Duplex;;Excellent little printer;;This is an excellent little printer; clear, fast, and hassle free.<br /><br />The installation went smoothly for attaching it to wired ethernet network, I haven't tried wireless or USB so I can't comment there.  Although two things were a bit ambiguous about the instructions.  First, the matter of how it's connected to the network refers to how the printer is connected to the network.  Never mind that your computers may be connected wirelessly to the router.  The printer's connection is all that matters here.  Secondly, even though you may have an infrastructure (central router) based network, choose peer-to-peer as your network type.<br /><br />The software installation was a bit surprising.  While most manufacturers embed a pile of useless software and some rather annoying add-ons like browser toolbars, the Brother allowed a clean and minimalist install.  It was quick and efficient, and it worked.  Just a solitary icon on the desktop that directs you to support if you need it.<br /><br />One aspect of the printer driver that is rarely touched upon in the reviews, is the "booklet" mode.  I've often wanted to print items in a reduced size format that could be carried about easily.  I tested the function and chose a 15 page PDF document to print.  I merely set the printer driver for "booklet - automatic" and it printed perfectly; all of the pages in order, ready to fold and staple.  This is normally something you have to fiddle around with in a word processor to achieve.  For better or worse, the driver reverts to single page printing upon completion.  I like that, I don't want to send a stack of invoices to the printer and have them inadvertently printed as a booklet.<br /><br />Another nice feature that's been overlooked is that the printed pages are delivered to the tray face down.  In other words, in order.  No more sorting them or having to print in reverse order, as is the case with ink jet printers.<br /><br />The thing is blazingly fast; typically done with a job before I reach for it.  Print quality is very good.  Ninety percent of my work is in monochrome (or could be) so by having a dedicated black and white printer will save me a great deal of supplies.  Most color printer drivers don't give you an option of using the black only.  I'm sure everyone has experienced printing a flashy web page with a color ink jet printer and have the pages come out laden with ink and noticeably damp from printing all of the useless advertising and background colors.  Even more maddening, it now refuses to print a black and white document claiming the yellow has run out.  With this monochrome printer you don't have to worry about it.<br /><br />A number of reviews have commented on it's power consumption.  First there's the allegation that it's draws so much power that the lights dim in the house.  The problem here is that your building needs to have it's wiring upgraded.  In any case, the printer shouldn't be plugged into a circuit that also supplies room lighting.<br /><br />Next, there have been comments that it's not really energy saver, seemingly because the power LED remains on in dimmed mode when it's sleeping.  In fact, in only uses 0.9 watt when it sleeping (2.8 watts with WAN on); that's a lot less most modern appliances, such as TV's or microwaves.  Far less than a high speed modem or router.  It needs to consume some power in order to keep it's connection to the network on standby.  You can change the status of the power indicator to "off when sleeping" in the software if it makes you feel better, but why bother?  You can save a lot more energy by vacuum cleaning the coils beneath and behind your refrigerator.  (I know you haven't done that lately.)<br /><br />Finally, it's been stated that it draws 1,000 watts while printing.  Well, inrush perhaps.  But let's do the math based on the 1,000 watts.  In most cases 1,000 watts for an hour's time would cost you about ten cents.  Ignoring the time you'd spend reloading it with paper, and at 25 pages a minute, your cost in energy would be 0.00666 cents per page ($0.0000666).  Pretty cheap, all things considered.<br /><br />It does exhibit a slight "curling" of the paper, particularly when using the duplex mode.  I switched to 24 lb. laser paper to combat this and noticed an improvement in print quality as well.  There is an option in the printer's software that supposedly will reduce paper curl.  I haven't tried it because I feel that the manufacturer would not have the default set to off unless there are performance issues associated with it's being on.<br /><br />Overall, I'm very pleased with this printer.  For what it's designed for, a SOHO environment, it can't be beat.;;5.0;;January 24, 2011;;28;;28;;1.0
R3LPEWMVB6H8IK;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A18AP5X25R9MGR;;Printer;;B001R4BTIK;;Canon Pixma PRO9500MkII Inkjet Photo Printer (3298B002);;Very mixed results (Update now in the dumpster);;To begin with I will say that I have sometimes been able to produce very nice prints with this printer but for the most part it has been a very expensive and frustrating experience. Starting with ink tank issues, at 15 bucks a pop couldn't they have made the tanks a little larger ? With 10 tanks, each being used at a different rate, it feels like at every print attempt one of the tanks will run out. At these prices and with this number of tanks I can't afford to have a bunch of spares lying around and these inks are hard to find in local stores meaning they have to be bought online, which can mean a delay of several days to produce a print.<br /><br />I have also found the startup time for the printer to start printing to be a little annoying and wondering if I have just got a 'bad' one in this case. I did some timings from pressing the print button on my computer to the thing actually starting to print and it averages around 4 minutes. Can hear the print head moving back and forth multiple times accompanied by various other 'whirring' and 'chugging' noises. No idea what exactly it is doing or whether this is typical.<br /><br />Last, and biggest, issue is the color reproduction which I have found to be completely hit-and-miss. I have my computer monitor calibrated and use only genuine Canon inks and paper but have found the print results to be very unreliable particulary in the red-pink-orange range. Seems to have major problems with color reproduction for photographs with dusk/dawn alpenglow type light. My results in these type of situations haave been of very washed out colors and a major loss of detail. In these cases I have ended up sending the pics to a pro print shop where they have printed fine without any color correction. Up-shot of this is this printer has become nothing much more than a very expensive test printer for me and I end up sending most of my prints to the pro shop.<br /><br />Oh and Canon customer service sucks : unknowledgeable, arrogant and completely un-helpfull.<br /><br />Update - as of today I have given up on this thing completely and put it in the dumpster. I followed the quick start guide and their recommended method of setting up the wireless connection.....ethernet connection (yes, you need your own ethernet cord as the unit does not come with one) from the Brother to your router and install through wireless computer (old G5 in my case).  Directions were clear and was able to get up and running in very little time and the "first" time.  I believe that other reviewers have said that this was not clear and/or a bit difficult.  I had no problems you just have to know what kind of security you have on your router, and basically the password.  If your router supports "AOSS", "Wi-Fi Protected Setup", or "Secure Easy Setup", things are probably even easier.  Installed the drivers on both my G5 and wife's iBook and everything worked!  This doesn't happen to me very often so I was overjoyed.  My wife is loving this printer.  She's out in the living room and hit's "print" and the Brother wakes up and starts printing.  Print speed is quite sufficient for our needs.  Quality seems very good.  We've only printed out documents with color printing and everything is very crisp.  When you first install it you can print out a demo page that is just awesome!  One thing you might want to remember is paper.  Brother recommends laser paper that is 20-24lbs.  Think I'm using some copy paper that is 20lbs and think my next purchase will be 24lbs paper.  The unit holds 250 sheets in a paper tray below and has the ability to print envelopes and other stuff using a straight through path.<br />  Lastly, everything I've read indicates that the cost of ownership of a laser is better than an ink jet so that's a plus. RRK852F1W4CGT;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A28CMS6L3T0NQ8;;Printer;;B005K95UI8;;Brother Printer MFCJ825DW Wireless Color Photo Printer with Scanner, Copier and Fax;;Mac OSX 10.7 & 10.8 Compatible with a little work;;I've only had this printer for a week but so far so good.  We have a Windows 7 laptop, OSX 10.8 laptop, and a OSX 10.7 workstation.  The Windows setup was fairly easy - but I didn't use the included CD because it was OLD.  You can download the latest software from Brother - you have to download the main driver package (about 130MB) and then the ControlCenter update package (about 45MB).  Upon install it finds the printer (which had already been setup on our wireless network), and installs the drivers.  The included CDROM does NOT contain software for OSX > 10.7, so you'll have to download it anyway.  Brother's download website isn't very clear about which files you NEED versus the other 6 files that you don't really need.  Grab the first two at the top of the page - the "CUPS" driver and the TWAIN driver - the first is for printing the second is for scanning.  DO NOT CONNECT THE PRINTER TO YOUR COMPUTER YET - heck, don't even turn it on.  Install the software packages and just for fun reboot so you force the CUPS daemon to restart.  Once you are all booted connect the printer USB cable to your computer, then power on the printer.  Your Mac should automatically setup the printer and you're ready to go.  Configuration on the Mac Laptop was a little more detailed - we had to configure a static IP on the printer and setup an IPP config for the printer in the Mac settings - but it DOES work.  I would hope that Brother is developing a new version of the automatic installer that will work on 10.7 and 10.8.  Also, if you want to print on CD/DVD/BR you'll have to download a newer version of the NewSoft software, a link is available on the Brother website.;;4.0;;August 29, 2012;;5;;6;;0.833333

Now, I'm using a 30" Apple Cinema Display and printing on 13 x 19 paper and experiencing printing nirvana.<br /><br />I'm using 24 lb bright white bond that I got from an internet source; just search for "13 x 19" paper and you'll find a wide range of paper at good prices.<br /><br />I do like that the printer completely closes (good for dust control) but nonetheless I made a custom cover for it, partly to camouflage its bulk. As others have noted, the printer is BIG, so allow for a wide stand and plenty of room for the front and back paper trays.<br /><br />Three tips:<br />First, I did have some trouble learning how to use the front sheet loader. Silly me, I thought the paper would feed from the front and exit the back, but instead, you manually feed the paper from the front toward the back and the printed sheet then exits the front. Once I understood the paper path, I did appreciate that the printer drivers prompt you to insert the paper, press the front feed button, etc.<br /><br />Second, if you want to use the auto feed for 13 x 19 paper (for proofing, or if, like me, you're printing chart-type output on bond paper) note that the auto feed only supports paper up to 12.95 x 23 inches (even though the paper feed is wide enough to handle 13" media.) To print on  13 x 19 paper, just set up a custom paper size of 12.95 x 19 and print away.<br /><br />Three, although the specs say the printer will print on lighter weight paper (17 lb, if I recall correctly) I wouldn't use anything less than 24 lb if you're going to use the auto feeder. I just feel that there is a good chance of paper jams with lighter weight paper.;;5.0;;January 7, 2009;;15;;16;;0.9375

R3CRTMDSB0OTBA;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A3M10VCTPICIYW;;Printer;;B004HO58UW;;Canon Pixma MX882 Wireless Office All-in-One Inkjet Printer (4894B002);;Like it so far... with addendum about lower cost;;I purchased this printer to replace a 12-year-old HP DeskJet 930 (I'm pretty easy on my stuff, so it tends to last a long time).  I did quite a bit of research before buying, and am very happy so far with the printer.  It prints well, scanning is a snap, and it's very handy now having a fax at home, since I have a number of document recipients who prefer fax to email.<br /><br />I really like being able to fax without actually printing a document out -- the fax function shows up as an available printer, so to send a document, whether pdf or Word or Excel or PowerPoint, all you have to do is click the print button and select the Canon fax as the destination printer.  A window pops up asking for the phone number.  Enter the phone number from the computer keyboard, hit "enter" and ZIP -- the printer dials and faxes the document directly from the computer file with no intervening paper copy.  Paperless faxing is VERY handy!<br /><br />The automatic duplex is also handy but very slow -- it prints one side, then sucks the page back in to print the other side.<br /><br />It appears to be a bit more frugal with ink than the old DeskJet it replaced; I've not yet put in new cartridges but the ink indicator says I've used about a quarter of the pigment black and negligible amounts of the dye tanks.  With the older printer, I'd have used about half the black and a quarter of the color tank after the same amount of time -- and with this printer, I can change out individual color tanks instead of the entire cartridge when I run out of one color.  Ink cartridge costs, both for the black and for the color set, are comparable to OEM for the HP and a little lower for non-OEM.  As a rough estimate, it looks like my per-page costs will be about 75% or so of what they were with the DesdJet.<br /><br />I'd read several comments about the footprint, but although the printer is much more massive and bulkier than the DeskJet, the two-dimensional footprint on the desk is virtually the same.  The DeskJet had a large base with a fairly small upper body, while the Canon is much more cubic.  It therefore seems much bigger and more in the way.  Though it doesn't take many more square inches of the desk surface, it consumes many more cubic inches of volume and is easier to bump into.<br /><br />All in all, I'm very happy with the print quality, ease of use, and functionality.  I can't address photo printing since I've not done any yet.  I don't know if it will last 12 years or even 12 months, but no regrets on the purchase as yet.<br /><br />-----------------------------------<br /><br />ADDENDUM after five months of use:  I've now run about 400-500 pages through the printer of Office Depot recycled paper.  I've seen some complaints about jamming with inexpensive paper, but the only feed problem I've had is the ONE time the printer took two sheets of paper at once.  I had let the supply tray get down to near-empty, and the printer grabbed the last two sheets at the same time.  I also now have a handle on ink costs, and I'm VERY happy.  My HP InkJet used HP 45 black and 78 cartridges; a set of both ran about $70 OEM and about $50 for off-brands and refills -- and the off-brands and refills had about an 20% failure rate, so they weren't any cheaper than HP name brand cartridges.<br /><br />I just now changed out the black pigment tank and two of the color dye tanks -- using off-brand cartridges I ordered from an online discounter for just over $7 each (about $36 for a full set vs $50 for the HP).  They work perfectly with no streaking, spotting, or missed spots.  After three weeks of use, I'm using the off-brand no more quickly than I used the Canon brand -- and I got about 50% more pages using the Canon "fast" setting than I did with the HP "draft" setting.<br /><br />Cheaper ink cartridges that print more pages -- I LOVE saving money on ink.  It looks so far like my ink costs could be about half what they used to be for the same print volume.  It will be nice not to spend as much on ink every year as I did for the printer.<br /><br />My only annoyance is caused by my fairly low print volume.  I print 20-30 page jobs about 5 or 6 times per month, with one or two page jobs about twice a week.  That means the printer may be in use daily for a few days, but it also means it might sit idle for four or five days at a time.  After an extended idle time, the first print job may not start until the machine takes about 3 or 4 minutes to clean the cartridges and do other "internal maintenance."  I guess the cure would be to print more often, but it's a very minor and occasional annoyance.<br /><br />So, after six months of use, I'm still very happy with the printer and would definitely purchase again.;;5.0;;May 15, 2011;;51;;52;;0.980769

RNIMYOAABL3S4;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/AURO3K8VHLIVX;;Printer;;B004HO58UW;;Canon Pixma MX882 Wireless Office All-in-One Inkjet Printer (4894B002);;Love my Canon Printers!;;I purchased the Canon MX882 printer from Amazon to replace a 3-year old Canon MX7600.  Yes, this switch was a "bit of a step-down",  but it has all the bells and whistles I need in a home office printer.<br /><br />My MX7600 had developed a problem where it started printing a black stripe down the back of each printed sheet.  I performed every cleaning I could and tossed the ball to Canon Tech Support (who have always performed admirably for me).  They told me that sometimes the felt pads that sit down somewhere deep in the innards of the printer get loose and start depositing ink on the transport rollers.  Since my MX7600 was out of warranty, Canon Tech Support referred me to our local authorized repair center.  A call to the repair center confirmed what I already suspected.  It would probably cost more to repair the printer than it would to purchase a new one.<br /><br />The MX7600 had some "annoyances" I never really liked, so rather than buy the very most expensive injet multifunction all-in-one Canon printer I could find, I opted for the Canon model that had all the features I wanted; multi-sheet scanning via an auto-document feeder, duplex scanning and duplex printing.  I no longer print my digital photos at home, so the photo print quality of the printer was not important to me.  Nor was the ability to fax - although I do, from time to time, fax a document or two.<br /><br />At any rate, the printer was extremely easy for me to setup.  Perhaps that is due to my previous experiences with Canon printers.  I chose to use the hard wired network method since my home wireless network is already somewhat conjested.  Canon gives you three methods to connect your MX882; wireless, wired and USB.  You can even purchase an optional Bluetooth dongle that will allow you to connect your BT-enabled phone or tablet for printing to your MX882.  I should note that the total time to install and configure the printer is about 20 minutes.  Longer than most, but worth the wait.<br /><br />Canon supplies an adequate suite of applications to use with your MX882.  However, the web printing application does not yet support IE9.  So you might want to bypass the installation of that application if you are already using IE9.<br /><br />On running some preliminary tests, I was surprised to find that the MX882 is actually faster than my old MX7600, both in scanning and printing.  And even better, Canon designers seem to have improved the duplex scanning.  On older models, I experienced a 50/50 success rate in duplex scanning.  The MX882 scanned all my duplex jobs without a single jam!<br /><br />They have also improved the MP Navigator application.  The older version I was using with my MX7600 also had some annoyances that were never fixed with updates.  The version that shipped with my MX882 does everything I need it too without constant reconfiguring.  They "smarted" it up!<br /><br />One of the biggest annoyances I had with the MX7600 was the manner in which it handled envelopes.  After many discussions with tech support, they admitted that the MX7600 was meant to be more of a workgroup printer rather than a home office printer.  The MX882 sees when I am printing an envelope and automatically switches to the rear feed tray - just like a well-behaved printer should!<br /><br />I'm very pleased with this purchase and would give it a high recommendation for anyone looking for a first-class home office printer.;;5.0;;August 28, 2011;;11;;11;;1.0

R288DBN9Z8SEGC;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/AMVIYH2EEDNTD;;Printer;;B002M78HX6;;Canon PIXMA MP990 Wireless Inkjet Photo All-In-One Printer (3749B002);;Ink Guzzler;;(See update below 8/21/10)<br />Buyer be aware of ink consumption! The cartridges are tiny and the printer guzzles ink. It makes noise when you start it up and the tech support person says it is cleaning using a "negligible" quantity of ink to do so... I don't know if that is true or not but it does make quite a bit of noise setting up before the first print.<br /><br />I purchased this printer after extensive research on several sites and reading reviewers. I like the multifunction capability but am overall disappointed with my purchase because of my usage habits. I am a low volume print user. After 1 month of only low usage (probably only around 30-50 pages max with only a few color pages and no photo prints 3 of my ink cartridges are 1/2 full and 2 are 3/4 full. Only the small black shows full.<br /><br />I have the settings on Fast to save ink. I called tech support today and they did inform me that using Duplex printing uses the color cartridges because the color ink dries faster. I wish I had known that. However I am not sure I will meet the following yields the tech support person gave me for mixed text/ graphic prints.<br /><br />He stated the continuous printing page yields are 322pg on the Lg Black, 1250 pg on the small black, 448pg on Cyan, 445 on Magenta, 477 on Yellow, 1370 on Gray. I was told that real life printing will have lower yields (possibly even 1/2 stated quantities) because the tiny nozzles need to be cleaned to ensure they do not get clogged when the printer sits idle between printing times. I know many reviewers have complained about ink usage and I agree wholeheartedly. This is a very expensive printer to run.<br /><br />However, all that said if you are a high volume color user and are looking for very high quality photos or color prints and do not mind paying for the ink usage this may be a printer for you. My mom had a much larger older Canon photo all in one printer (obsolete model) that does not consume as much ink. It has probably 1/5 the print density heads but she is extremely happy with her printer and the quality of the photos, ink usage, etc. The increase in number, decrease in size of the print heads comes with an increase in operating cost.  As long as you are willing to pay for the ink, the printer performs well.<br /><br />A note about the copy machine function. It works well on master copies with white paper but when you copy from a master printed on colored paper it does print a light grayscale background... acceptable but not as nice as taking it to a real copy machine at a Fed Ex office location which only copies the text.<br /><br />If I had to do it over again I would look for a printer less expensive to run. I will probably buy a cheap laser printer and do 90% of my printing there and only use the Canon for special color projects. I don't think I'll ever bother trying photo printing, the cost for the ink alone makes it cost prohibitive for us.<br /><br />Perhaps all the multifunction printers consume ink at a high rate. I just think that a user needs to consider their usage habits carefully before committing to a printer that has such high operating costs. I knew ink consumption would be somewhat expensive but I don't really want to pay $25 a month in ink for mostly black and white prints. It is possible I will get higher yields toward the end of the cartridges or with the next set not using Duplex printing. I will post an update.<br /><br />UPDATE 8/21/2010<br />Switching off duplex printing slowed down the consumption of my color inks; however, after nearly 3 months of low usage (mostly black & white) all my cartridges are at 1/2 with the exception of the page black which is at 3/4. Most of my ink is being used to keep the heads clear which is a waste. If I were a higher print user at least the ink would be on paper.<br /><br />I have changed my opinion on the purchase however. I like having color available and a photocopier at home so I am willing to pay for the ink for the personal convenience. I figure I will need to buy 2-3 sets of cartridges a year. I may be able to cut down my usage by purchasing a laser printer.;;3.0;;July 6, 2010;;7;;8;;0.875

R582M9XNUW8KJ;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A3QMJMTLJC34QC;;Printer;;B0043D2O7C;;HP Envy 100 e-All-in-One D410a Printer (CN517A#B1H);;Printing From My iPad with Air Print, Well Almost;;Bottom-Line: Great printer, scanner, and copier, but printing with Air Print needs to be rethought.<br /><br />One of the major complaints about the iPad when it was first introduced was that one could not print from it.  Apple heard us and with the release of IOS (iPhone Operating System) 4.2 the company included Apple Air Print a technology that allows, or is supposed to allow the iPad, iPhone, or iPod Touch to print wirelessly from the device to an ever-increasing number of Hewlett Packard printers like the HP Envy 100 e-All-in-One D410a Inkjet Printer.<br /><br />Hewlett Packard upped the ante with this All-n-One (AIO) unit by including wireless and giving the "HP Envy 100 e-All-in-One D410a Inkjet Printer" an e-mail address from one can print from your iPad via a technology called "e-Print."  One is also supposed to be able to print wirelessly via Apple Air Print.<br /><br />The Product<br /><br />The "HP Envy 100 e-All-in-One D410a Inkjet Printer" is a small footprint multifunction printing device (compatible with PC as well as Macintosh) that allows you to print, scan, copy all from one unit.  The HP Envy 100 has the added capability of printing photos directly from the unit and will accept input from all manner of removable and or portable memory devices including SD Media, or USB port for connecting directly to a digital camera.  All of these connections are situated on the front of the unit.<br /><br />Wired networking is built into the HP Envy 100 e-AIO; the machine has built-in 10/100 Ethernet port.  Once set up, computers speak directly to the printer abrogating the need for a dedicated print server, or sharing via Windows.  Note: the HP Envy 100 e-AIO can also be connected directly to a PC via a USB cable (not included), in which case its printer functionality can be shared via Windows.<br /><br />Unlike other AIO printers the HP Envy 100 e-AIO is a smaller than usual unit without an automatic document feeder.  Gone as well are (4) cartridges, replaced by (2).  The HP Envy 100 e-AIO also features a flatbed scanner, copy collating, two-sided printing, print up to legal size; and a slide-in 25-sheet input paper capacity.  The HP Envy 100 e-AIO offers print and copy speeds up to 27 pages per minute (ppm) black, and up to 22 ppm color, with up to 4,800-optimized dpi color and laser-quality text.<br /><br />Un-Packing<br /><br />As I stated above, the HP Envy 100 e-AIO is a small unit, and as such it ships in many different parts and had to be put together before use.  It took me a little less than 15 minutes to completely assemble the printer.  Since the printer is so compact there are few moving parts, even the duplexer is built-in.<br /><br />Network Setup<br /><br />Before connecting the HP Envy 100 e-AIO to a computer (USB), or network (Ethernet), the decision must be made to utilize one or the other communications medium, but not both.  But, of course there is one other option: wireless, so I installed the HP Envy 100 e-AIO utilizing wireless and USB and I can print either way. Wireless set-up was effortless using DHCP.<br /><br />Wireless Printing & e-Print<br /><br />One of the selling points of the HP Envy 100 e-AIO is of course the ability of the iPad to print to the device either wirelessly (Air Print) or via e-Print.  For me the first doesn't work, while the second mostly works; let me explain.<br /><br />IOS version 4.2 shipped with Air Print, which allow the iPad to wirelessly "talk" to Air Print enabled printers like the HP Envy 100 e-AIO.  While I could see the printer on the iPad from Air Print enabled applications like Safari, select the printer and the app stated that it was rendering a print job, yet nothing came out of the printer, ever!<br /><br />I Google'd the issue and it turns out I am not the only one with the issue; it appears to be a wide-spread and caused by a combination of wireless access point (WAP)/ Router, printer, and iPad compatibility.  I tried all of the steps outlined in numerous BLOG's on the issue and I have yet to resolve it; (heavy sigh!).<br /><br />On the other hand, e-Print works like a charm, most of the time.  With e-Print the HP Envy 100 e-AIO is assigned an e-mail address to which one can forward e-mail's to be printed from iPad, iMac, iPod, or PC as long as the printer is connected to the Internet.  This feature works reasonably well; it is supposed to be able to print attachments, but this is a hit or miss proposition; i.e. sometimes it works, sometime not, sometimes it print half a page.  Overall, I am pleased with e-print, and of course since I cannot print to the HP Envy 100 e-AIO via Air Print, it is the only way I can print from the iPad.<br /><br />Software Installation<br /><br />To get the most of the HP Envy 100 e-AIO you will have to install the software suite on a PC or iMac, and for this you will need to connect the AIO via a USB cable.  The software will allow one to control features on the printer, as well as download HP Apps, yes I said Apps from the Internet in order to use directly on the printer.  Via HP Apps like Disney you can print out ready to color pictures from the movie Tron; just bring them up from the color screen on the HP Envy 100 e-AIO and hit print. Seriously cool!<br /><br />With the software is installed the workstation will be able to print, scan, and copy from the HP Envy 100 e-AIO.<br /><br />Printing<br /><br />Pretty straight forward; the software installation process installed a full set of print drivers on each workstation, which in turn give you complete control over the printing process, including two-sided printing.  The HP Envy 100 e-AIO can also print from inserted USB flash drives and or SD Media cards.<br /><br />Scanning<br /><br />The HP Envy 100 e-AIO offers up only a flatbed scanner for use, gone is the ADF.  Initialing the scanning process can be accomplished from the included software or the HP Envy 100 e-AIO control panel.  Once an item is placed on the flatbed scanner on the scanner glass surface, you can push the Scan button on the front panel, at which time you choose where to scan to: Computer, USB Flash Drive, or Memory Card. Once a destination is chosen, you can then chose to scan to file, e-mail, or photo.<br /><br />Copy Process<br /><br />This process, like printing is pretty straight forward; both color and black & white copies can be made, up to 99 at a time.  Because there is a duplexer installed two-sided copies can be made in a number of different configurations, including 1-side original/ 1-side copy; 1-side original/ 2-side copy; 2-side original/ 1-side copy; 2-side original/ 2-side copy.  Copies can also be enlarged up to 144%, or reduced down to 25% of original.<br /><br />Working with Photos<br /><br />As stated above, the HP Envy 100 e-AIO will accept input from a number of commercially available portable memory storage devices, slots for which are located on the right hand side of the printer underneath a sliding panel.  Simply insert the memory card and the photos it contains are displayed on the small 2.4" 256 color display in the middle of the OJ L7680 AIO's control panel.<br /><br />Using the square control button that sits to the right of the display, pictures can be scrolled through and then printed on borderless or regular paper.  Pictures can also be shared between users as long as the HP Instant Sharing utility is set up.<br /><br />Conclusion<br /><br />Overall I like the HP Envy 100 e-AIO, it is compact, easy to use, and has an aura of coolness that is hard to resist.  Of course its inability to utilize Air Print and print wirelessly from the iPad is a big impediment considering it is what I bought the AIO for.  However, since the e-print is working relatively well, I can excuse the minor, well okay, major bump in the road to iPad nirvana!<br /><br />The built-in wired Ethernet capability, coupled with USB and wireless make the HP Envy 100 e-AIO a versatile, flexible unit that is ideal for a small home office setting and well as workgroup setting; however, with its multitude of family-centric HP Apps, the AIO seems to be geared towards the home user.  If you or your small workgroup need a scanner/ copier/ printer, and need to print from your iPad is some form or fashion the HP Envy 100 e-AIO should be given serious consideration, just be aware of the wireless constraints!;;4.0;;May 20, 2011;;6;;8;;0.75

R3MZW5W1T06YLY;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A2W4PP0KMHLAA1;;Printer;;B004G5ZZQY;;Brother MFCJ6710DW Business Inkjet All-in-One Printer with 11-Inch x 17-Inch Duplex Printing, 11-Inch x 17-Inch Scan Glass & Dual Paper Trays;;Great scans, great convenience, good printing, OK color;;I've had this unit for about a month, and except for the low intensity of its printed colors, I REALLY like it. I'm getting used to the low intensity color, too.<br /><br />I've owned at least three low-cost scanners with 11x17 capability, and I've returned them all because their 11x17 scans looked terrible. The scans from this one are superb. Once you figure it out, the scanning software is very good, too. (In my experience, Brother products come with very good software, but limited information about it.) You can control the scanning from the panel of the scanner or from the included Control Center software.<br /><br />I found the controls on the hardware to be intuitive and easy to use for scanning and printing. (I haven't used it as a FAX machine yet, but the FAX controls appear to be of a similar nature.) Those in the software are somewhat less so, but once you figure them out, they give you a lot of flexibility.<br /><br />I love the fact that I can keep 11x17 and letter sized paper in separate trays that are easy to print from. I love that the unit connects wirelessly to all the stuff in my office.<br /><br />I haven't experienced the serious paper feed problems that others have talked about, but I HAVE had a misfeed or two, and there HAVE been times when the unit seems not to know what I'm asking it to do. When that happens, I just abort and start over.<br /><br />The color printing is definitely unusual, in that the intensity of the colors is very much less than that of other printers I've had. The printer has two color modes: Natural and Intense. Both of them do pretty well at delivering readable color, but it's pretty washed out when compared to what I am accustomed to (mostly H-P). Once I got used to the Brother's lower color intensity, I began to appreciate the fact that it makes a lot of things easier to see and differentiate. I have several small logos with a lot of detail that normally can't be seen when printed in color. It shows up nicely on the Brother, though.<br /><br />The duplexing works well and is easy to use, but it only seems to work on plain paper. I couldn't get it to duplex anything on bright white inkjet.<br /><br />All in all, I'm very happy with this unit. I have two H-P laser printers and three H-P color inkjets in my home office, and the Brother is a useful addition to my capability.<br /><br />UPDATE (2/19/12) I'm getting to appreciate the benefits of the 11x17 scanning bed. One of my occasional projects is to scan some booklets that are printed on 11x17 paper, then folded and saddle stitched. In the past, I only had a letter-sized scanner, so I had to work hard to get the booklets straight on the scan glass. I either folded them back on the saddle-stitched edge and hoped to get them straight, or else flipped the booklet on every other scan then unflipped the alternate scans electronically. Either way was inconvenient, and somehow neither ever worked out very well. I'm doing one of these projects today, and I just open the booklet, lay it on the scan glass, and scan it in 11x17 mode, always with the top edge of the booklet facing into the scanner. There are no alignment problems, since the 17" side fits perfectly flush with the edge of the scanner bed, and more or less "locks in" on its raised edge. This is a tremendous improvement in convenience from what I had before. And as I said up above, the 11x17 scans are VERY clean and nice, MUCH better than anything I've had before.;;4.0;;February 10, 2012;;9;;9;;1.0
R3E7KJ8TG7MA5C;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A2QOX5BUE6A3HM;;Printer;;B002GP7Z6Y;;Canon PIXMA MP560 Wireless Inkjet All-In-One Photo Printer (3747B002);;Blown away.;;I'm a picky consumer.  I think we live in an age where products tend to not just fall short of expectations in terms of how they satisfy us, but all too often simply fail to operate as they advertise in basic functional ways.  I buy things fully expecting them to have some sort of problem that inevitably disappoints me, typically just basic operational failure that should not happen.  This is all to say I am glad to report this Cannon printer, once again proves Cannon still makes good products.<br /><br />I set this printer up on our Wi-fi network as if it were made for it.  I couldn't believe simply using the printers own menu options and its little 2 inch screen (never touching my computer) would be all I'd have to do to get it up and running and printing/scanning.  Naturally, the printer takes a driver you have to install on any computer using it, but as far as getting it up and running, you don't have to touch your PC.  And the menu options are not obscure DVD player firmware style options.  They are simple, short and well thought out and illustrated steps to help people of varying experience levels set the printer up with absolutely no headache.  There was not a single moment during the printer setup that I did not know what I was doing or where I felt lost or confused.  It was, and it's so rare with computer products, a very pleasant process.  Altogether it took about 30 minutes to set it up, including a somewhat lengthy print head alignment, which is optional but recommended if you plan to print photos.  But, even there the printer did all the work and I just had to facilitate transferring the printed test sheet to the scanner.  Job done.<br /><br />The printer comes with a set of free glossy 4x10" photo sheets.  For the first time in my life, I printed a photo on a home printer.  I was expecting it to look nice, but this was of a quality I would have gotten printing at Walgreens or Target.  It's just that clear and rich in how it prints.  I don't plan to do much photo printing, but I may change my mind considering how well this printer does that.  Document printing is also very nice, but I'd think that should be a given on just about any printer these days.  Something to think about, and this may be common with photo printers, is that you have the 3 standard color ink cartridges, a photo (I believe) black cartridge, and a fifth larger black cartridge for everyday printing.  So, ongoing expense includes 5 ink cartridges.  If you do a lot of printing, I can see where that might get pricey.<br /><br />The scanner works well.  This is the only function of this printer that I think falls short of the rest of the printer, and that's really only because the rest of the printers functions blew me away whereas I find the scanner solidly adequate.  My complaint is that it seems to scan bright, and by that I mean it tends to wash out the document you are scanning.  It's not awful, but a bit too much brightness.  A quick run through Photoshop would be more than enough to compensate, but I know not everyone has that sort of software.  Otherwise, if you just want usable scans of good quality, this printer will make you happy.  If you want perfect scans of the quality of a dedicated "fancy" scanner, I don't believe this one will satisfy you.<br /><br />All in all, this printer is feature-packed and more than lives up to its promises.  I'm pretty cheap, so even getting this on Black Friday for 79 bucks made me squirm, but I can say having it here and setup now, I couldn't be happier.<br /><br />Thank you Cannon for being one of the few companies that still makes quality products.;;5.0;;December 1, 2009;;21;;22;;0.954545

R3NXCYMSX7EP0O;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A7MCGSWU5D67Q;;Printer;;B004QM99JG;;Brother Printer MFC7860DW Wireless Monochrome Printer with Scanner, Copier & Fax;;Outstanding for the price;;So I've had this installed as a wireless printer for ~4 weeks now. It set up to a Win7 machine in about 20 minutes. Subsequent install onto 2 other XP machines and three OS X Macs took around 5 minutes each. It is important to read the manuals and follow the instructions because it does get a little tricky in places if you're not paying attention. Print quality is excellent. Copy function is good. Once you've got it set up properly it's good. The duplexing works well, although it sometimes sounds like it's shredding the paper instead of duplexing it. The 'bonus' software is all geared towards colour printers, but might prove useful sometime. Maybe.<br /><br />Now, the negatives: it's noisy when operating. Not obtrusively so, but it's not exactly quiet either. It settles back to sleep mode quickly. The scan function does not generate (as far as I can tell!) pdf files, which is annoying. It will scan in several formats and directly to wireless networked machines, but won't generate PDF's automatically.<br /><br />ETA:  Thanks for the comment below! Yup, I figured it was just me not setting it up correctly for PDFs. It does indeed, as you would expect, generate PDF's automatically. Very small amount of messing about to set up, once you know where to look. Yay!<br /><br /> It is also a pain in a arse to set up to run wirelessly on a Win& network. Once the win box goes to sleep, is shut down, or re-starts for any reason then the Win machine can't see the printer for sending print jobs. Several calls to Brother when this first happened had them get me to uninstall the priter from the Win box and then re-install it. That worked, but only until the next time the Win7 box was shut down...  This didn't happen on the XP or OS X machines, just Win7. Updating the drivers didn't help. Eventually, after three calls to Brother's help desk (which was very nice to deal with but totally didn't suggest the right solution), and spending three hours wading through online forums for a solution did I find out what needs to be done: the default install has one print standard on the Win7 box and another on the machine. You need to go into the Win7 settings and change the printer to RAW so that it matches the printer's internal default setting. Once you do that then everything works perfectly over a wireless network connection for Win7.<br /><br />Anyway, yes: aside from those things, it's all good and hard to beat at the Amazon price of ~1/2 MSRP.;;5.0;;June 27, 2011;;15;;15;;1.0

When I go to print and it is in energy saver mode, the Mac says it can't find the printer.
