R3PN2OFWX61671;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A9J4UURM4OSDW;;Printer;;B0020CL9VK;;Brother MFC-8890DW High-Performance All-in-One Laser Printer;;Fulfills its promise;;The 8890DW fulfills its promise.  It prints, scans, copies and faxes quickly and flawlessly, including duplex (2-sided) printing and scanning.  The "DW" designation means it duplexes and works as both a wired and wirelss device on your network.  The wireless feature and duplex scanning capability account for the price being higher than a similar but less expensive Brother 8840DN, which doesn't have the wireless feature and doesn't scan duplex.<br /><br />The setup software works without a hitch, which was not the case with some of the earlier Brother MFC products I've owned.  It can scan into a PDF file and it has a USB port on the front so you can load files directly from a memory stick or a camera.  You can use a USB connection to your computer, a wired LAN (Ethernet) cable, or a wireless link to a Wi-Fi network. (If you have more than one computer, you'll find it easier to set them up if you use either a wired or wirless network connection.  Setting up multiple computers when the printer is connected to one computer with a USB cable can be a pain and sometimes just doesn't work at all.)<br /><br />I set it up using the wireless feature on a mixed network (two Windows 7, one Windows XP and a Mac laptop with OSX.  The printer found the Wi-Fi network and the setup software then asked for the security code (assuming you have set up a secure network).  Once that was done, all of the computers could be set up with the driver for their particular operating system. It's easiest setting multiple computers if you remember to write down the printer's IP address -- it will look something like 192.168.1.04 (or .05 or .06 etc.) and the software displays it after it's linked to the network in the first setup step.  But if you don't know an IP address from a pitchfork, just follow the instructions in the setup software.<br /><br />You will need to install a driver onto each computer.  That's the software that tells the computer how to talk to the printer.  Brother supplies CDs one CD for Windows 7, one for various recent Mac OS's and one for Windows Vista, XP and perhaps earlier versions. You have to do that because there are no built-in drivers for this relatively new model in older Windows versions, and even Windows 7 does not have a built-in driver for this particular model yet.  The setup instructions lead you through all of this clearly.  You don't need to install the whole package of scanning and optical character recognition software because there's an option to just choose the driver, but the MFC 8890DW does come with additional reasonably useful software.<br /><br />The printed instruction manual has a very detailed explanation of how to use the fax capability, but the instructions for scanning are not as complete and there's not much information about the various printing options.  The details are in a PDF file on the CDs that come with th printer, which seems strange given that Brother makes the effort to supply a printed manual in the first place.  Programming in the phone number and ID for your fax requires that you carefully follow the instructions in the printed manual, but they're clear enough.<br /><br />The instructions for printing envelopes tell you to open the rear exit tray you print on anything other than regaulr paper, but if you use a regular weight #10 envelope you don't need to open the rear exit tray.  The envelope will follow the normal paper path without jamming or getting messed up.  One small cloud is that the left rear hinge appears to be the same design as on an earlier model Brother MFC I have, and that hinge broke despite careful use.  Be extra gentle whenever you lift the scanner cover.<br /><br />Printer manufacturers make their profits on toner and ink, and Brother is no exception.  But they give you an option.  You can buy a replacement toner cartridge good for 3,000 "average" copies at a cost of about two and a half cents each, and that's what comes with the printer.  Or you can buy one for the 8890DW and some other recent models that gives you 8,000 copies for about 80% more, which gives you a cost of about a cent and a half.;;5.0;;October 23, 2010;;14;;14;;1.0

R2N4M2B3RP8QGH;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A1DVDQSB9R9JVY;;Printer;;B000SDU7ZW;;Epson Stylus Photo R280 Ultra Hi-Definition Photo Printer (C11C691201);;Poor paper handling--but see addendum;;I bought this printer specifically to do holiday cards (I use a Hi-Touch dye sublimation printer for my photos). I checked the specifications, and it claimed it could do cardstock. However, it kept jamming on the cardstock. I went through the Epson website trouble shooting screens, and I discovered that the maximum paper weight it can handle is 24 pounds (that's the weight of fine office stationery). Cardstock is usually 50 or 60 pound weight.<br /><br />If I had discovered this earlier, I would have purchased a different printer. As it was, I think Epson made the specifications too vague, by specifying cardstock rather than the weight of usable paper.<br /><br />Addendum: In the troubleshooting section of the Epson website, it suggested that paper jam could be reduced by feeding sheets one at a time. I tried it, and the printer worked like a charm--smooth paper feeding and fast printing. The only drawback is that I must stand by the printer and feed each sheet of cardstock one at a time.<br /><br />I should mention that Epson, unlike many vendors, includes high-capacity ink cartridges in the box.<br /><br />Please consider this a four-star, not a three-star, review.;;3.0;;December 10, 2007;;84;;93;;0.903226

RGWFRI56WFQE2;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A18EVOOF2F7SZ4;;Printer;;B002OT8C8C;;Brother MFC-9320CW High Quality Digital Color All-in-One Printer with Wireless Networking;;Toner Frustration!!!!;;At first I was very happy with the purchase of this MFC. My frustration started when I ran into the low toner, then replace toner messages. Once you get replace toner message, the machine will stop printing. After several calls to Brother support and long hours on wait, (and $400 spent on new toners) I was not given ANY satisfying answers. They explained thats the yield of the toners, yield my @ss, I only printed 200 color copies. I got frustrated to the point of wanting to return the MFC. Before I did I decided to google and see if I was the only crazy one, and sure of enough there are many people out there with the same frustrations. So I found a way to trick the machine and bypass (money hungry Brother) messages. Do this:<br /><br />1. With power on, open the toner access main door (You will get a "door open" message in the LCD.)<br />2. Hit the "Clear/Back" button and... ta-dah!!! you go right to the "Toner Reset Menu" (cue Vienna Boy's choir sounds here).<br />3. Using the up ^ Down > "Search" arrow buttons, you can then scroll through reset options for each of the printer's [4] toner cartridges!<br />Code: B. = black; C. = cyan; M. = magenta and Y. = yellow<br />4. For each for these cartridges is the option to reset for low yield = S (small?) or High Yield = H<br />5. Using the number keypad, select option #1 (to reset each to the size you have installed.<br />6. Hit the "Clear/Back" button to get out of the menu, close door ad the problem is FINALLY solved.<br /><br />you can also google "toner override" to find other solutions.;;3.0;;September 14, 2010;;38;;38;;1.0

This really is a small foible; just become familiar with the printer. If your back tray does not print, try turning the printer "off" and the paper will eject; then try again as mentioned supra.<br /><br />It seems if you press slightly on the papers edge to load, when the "load paper" LED is prompted, it will load every time. R2S550A54SZQXC;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/ACW0YSGQF92A3;;Printer;;B003ZUXXP6;;HP Officejet 6500A Plus e-All-in-One (CN557A#B1H);;Prints fine, drops off the wireless network;;This was a Christmas gift from me to my wife, who needed the copy/scanner features. I was more interested in getting a wireless printer that supported AirPrint for iPhones/iPads (had to install a firmware upgrade to get that, but that was very easy and it worked.)<br /><br />SO far everything about this printer works as advertised. It fits our needs as far as print quality is concerned, color and otherwise, and prints quickly and quietly. Being able to print wirelessly from iPhones and iPads with iOS 2 is very nice and i use that capability more often than I thought I would.<br /><br />UNFORTUNATELY, this bad boy tends to drop off the network after awhile, probably after it goes into sleep mode. It apparently doesn't awaken gracefully. I went looking for a fix and was sort of amazed to find this one recommended by HP: "Go over to the printer, turn it off then back on." Yes, it works, but it's sort of like telling me that if my faucet leaks, just go outside and pull a bucket up from the well. We've used it since Christmas but if this isn't fixed by a firmware update from HP before end of January, I'll be taking it back.<br /><br />SO if you bought this one for its wireless printing capability, watch out and test it aggressively for the first couple of weeks. And maybe keep the packing material if you bought it online.;;3.0;;January 7, 2011;;16;;16;;1.0

The printer doesn't do color, but the quality is what you'd expect from a Laserjet.  The network setup was quick and easy and there is both an ethernet connection and WiFi.  The printer is also AirPrint enabled, which is nice if you want to print from your iPhone, iPad or iPod Touch.<br /><br />This printer replaced my Photosmart printer because I never print photos and I print so infrequently that my ink dries up. Halfway through the installation, you get a text box that says you must have admin rights to install the printer (I'm logged in as an admin on my Macbook).  I called HP and they said that it's a known issue with Lion.  I used another computer (running Snow Leopard) to set up the fax settings and do the initial install with no issues.  I was still able to set up the printer to both print and fax (but not scan) from the Macbook running Lion (just go to your Print & Scan menu in System Prefs).<br /><br />Pros - Networked all-in-one with Fax, Scan, Copy and Print capabilities.  It's a Laser, so the quality is great and the toner doesn't "dry out."  AirPrint is awesome!  The printer also goes to "sleep" after 15 min for energy savings, but this is transparent to the user as it wakes up once you try to print to it.  It also supports ePrint which is HPs networked solution to log in and print to your printer from anywhere in the world.  Document feeder holds plenty of paper and will collate copies.<br /><br />Cons - It's a laser, so the toner is expensive (almost $50/cartridge).  No color. R8J9TU2W1PYZ7;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A3DJWBL2E67QY9;;Printer;;B005K8AV2Y;;Kodak HERO 6.1 Wireless Color Printer with Scanner, Copier & Fax;;Good LOCAL printer, worthless on a network;;The print quality and features are good for a local printer, but it is useless over a network unless you constantly send it new print jobs to keep it awake.<br /><br />After it sits idle for a while this printer puts itself to sleep to save power (although tests suggest that it doesn't save very much power).  The problem is that this printer CANNOT wake up from sleep mode.  If you try to send it a print job after it goes into sleep mode, the print job will just time out because it cannot find the printer while it is asleep and it can't wake the printer.  As shown in Kodak's own troubleshooting guide, the only way to wake up the printer is to walk to the printer location to manually turn the power off then turn it back on again.  Once the printer restarts itself it will work fine -- until the next time it does to sleep.<br /><br />The latest firmware update finally gives you a way to choose how long the printer can be idle before it puts itself to sleep -- but the choices only range from 1 hour to a maximum of 4 hours -- there is no way to turn this "feature" off.<br /><br />I've got the Kodak Office Hero 6.1 but Kodak tech support assures me that ALL Kodak all-in-one printers share one major firmware flaw -- none of their printers can wake up from "sleep" mode without being manually reset from the printer control panel.<br /><br />This is fine for a local printer where the power button is within arm's reach of the computer but it makes the printer nearly useless as a network printer and totally useless for cloud printing unless you keep sending new print jobs to the printer to keep it from going to sleep.<br /><br />Instead of calling it sleep mode, a better name would be "coma" mode or perhaps "brain dead" mode.;;2.0;;March 15, 2012;;20;;21;;0.952381

This hasn't been an issue on any other inkjet printer I've had.  Manual duplexing doesn't work - page 2 doesn't wind up on the back of page 1 if more than two sheets are needed. I did get momentarily confused during setup as the process directed you to update the firmware to get the latest/greatest functionality and to enable ePrint.  But the printer wasn't listed in the printers supporting ePrint, which led me to a brief online chat session with HP's support.  Essentially they directed me to ignore that step, and I was able to confirm that ePrinting was functional, (the ePrint logo on the control panel clearly indicates the printer supports ePrint - so the website is simply behind).  There was a step in the setup process where I had to connect the printer via the USB cable, but that was removed in a later step, and the printer's functioning flawlessly on my wireless network now.  I've updated a couple of laptops to add the printer, (via the control panel process, and pulling the driver off the internet using the Windows Update option during printer setup).<br /><br />The ePrint setup was extremely easy as well - the printer generates a unique printer code, which it prints for you. You type in the code on the ePrint website and select a unique email address for your printer and you're done. I informally timed it, using the second hand of the Windows clock, and within 45 seconds of sending a 7 page newsletter-type document, (light graphics & text on every page), it was printing the first page, and the entire document was done about a minute later.<br /><br />Copying is extremely easy, via the two front-panel buttons, (one for color, one for black & white). R3QN8ANKG7H4EX;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A38RETOUFO29D9;;Printer;;B003VQR1RA;;Canon PIXMA MG5220 Wireless Inkjet Photo All-in-One (4502B017);;Previous reviews - paper feed;;Review for Canon MG 5220 all-in-one printer.<br />I don't normally submit reviews for products that have been reviewed over 200 times already but I feel it necessary to add a few comments to the reviews I read about this printer.  As a retired computer professional, one of my pet peeves is people who don't read the manual and then complain about something not working correctly.  After installing my new MG5220 it is obvious that some of the criticisms in the 1 and 2 star reviews were clearly cases of someone not reading the manual rather than anything wrong with the printer.  One example is the reviewer who complained that the printer required a USB cable with the flat connectors on both ends.  That's not true - it uses the standard USB cable with the flat connector on one end and the six-sided "square" connector on the other.  If he was trying to use the cable he described then he was trying to connect the printer to his computer using the USB input for connection to digital cameras and thumb drives.<br />But, there is one feature of this printer that I wish I had known about ahead of time.  The printer this is replacing had two paper feeds - the standard rear opening and a cassette.  I always kept 4x6 photo paper in the cassette and used the rear feed for whatever kind of paper I needed at the time.  The MG 5520 also has rear and cassette feed but the cassette will not hold 4x6 photo paper.  The slides that adjust for the paper will not close down to 4x6.  The manual recommends using the cassette for plain paper and the rear feed for photo paper.  This means pulling out and reloading the cassette every time you want to use a different kind of paper instead of just slipping a sheet in the rear slot.  For the way I use my printer, this is very inconvenient.;;4.0;;May 9, 2011;;13;;13;;1.0
R3GX2FYM0DNB02;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A2RTSFRRU7NZL6;;Printer;;B0002UM0PQ;;HP LaserJet 1320 Laser Printer;;Fast, duplex printer but manual feed is weak;;The print quality is excellent, and time to first page print from cold-start is very short. I love the duplexing on this unit and the ability to print 2 & 4 up. My main complaint about this printers is the manual feed function. Basically, I think the 1320 has some fundamental design flaws with regard to manual feeds. I can now do envelopes reliably with the method described below, but feeding standard letter-size paper is still an iffy proposition.<br /><br />The manual envelope feed work-around that I've kludged together is the following:<br /><br />1) take the regular paper tray out slightly (2-3 inches) so it does not feed from there<br /><br />2) have the paper path go straight-thru<br /><br />3) adjust the manual feed guide to fit the envelope<br /><br />4) send the print job to the printer, and wait for the yellow indicator light to blink before putting in the envelope (feeding the envelope earlier seems to not work);;3.0;;December 10, 2004;;95;;100;;0.95
R12B4J34388Z7Z;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A1SENCN3QG7KTE;;Printer;;B0020CL9VK;;Brother MFC-8890DW High-Performance All-in-One Laser Printer;;A truly exceptional device;;I was shopping around for all-in-one printer, to replace an old HP DeskJet 6127 Color Printer inkjet printer and an even older HP LaserJet 6p. I wanted an all-in-one with fax, print, copy, scan and built-in duplex with networking support for scan to PC and fax from PC. For some reason, the HP inkjet AIO printers do not support faxing from the PC (their laser printers do, but not the inkjet printers). They also are pretty horribly reviewed. So, even though I generally love HP printers, they were ruled out.<br /><br />After a lot of research, I selected the Epson Artisan 810 All-In-One Printer. Set it up, connected it, and started doing some test prints. The quality was pretty awful compared to my ancient HP Deskjet, using the same paper. We decided to send it back, because we just couldn't put up with that bad text and dim image quality.<br /><br />After some more thinking, I decided to keep the old inkjet for my color printing needs, and get a black & white laser multifunction printer. The Brother MFC-8890DW fit the bill, at a not unreasonable price. I was able to read all of the manuals at the Brother website and be certain that it could do everything I wanted. We especially liked the ability to copy, scan and fax from double-sided originals via the automatic document feeder - a lot of duplex devices only support duplex for output, not input. Additionally, the ability to work with legal-sized media was a bonus, as I'm going to law school next fall.<br /><br />When the device arrive, I noticed a very nice, thoughtful thing Brother had done. When you open the boxes of most components, there are little diagrams telling you how to unpack the device. Brother, on the other hand, included instructions on how to re-pack the device. Since we tend to keep packing materials and reuse them when we move, this was a very nice touch.<br /><br />The setup instructions were very clear, with step-by-step instructions for USB, parallel, wired and wireless networking setup split out, as well as Windows and MacOS software installations split out. There are also detailed instructions on setting up your fax line, depending on what other devices you have on that phone line and other things like distinctive-ring. Setting up the device was absolutely trivial - everything worked exactly as shown in the manual. The most complicated part of the setup was keying in my WPA-PSK code, which uses a mix of upper- and lower-case letters and symbols. Input is via a form of multi-tap input, which is probably trivial for texting young folk, but I prefer alphanumeric keypads. But it worked right the first time.<br /><br />Software installation on Windows XP SP3 was also straightforward. The CD that comes with the device has support up to Vista, but there are Windows 7 drivers and a complete software package on the Brother website. The Brother Status Monitor application started up and asked if I wanted to monitor for firmware updates, which I did. It immediately found an update and took me to the Brother support site to download it. Installing the update went completely smoothly. The device beeps a lot while the update is in progress, but that's the only annoyance.<br /><br />Another nice thing Brother does is to support testing your fax configuration by faxing back your registration form. After you fax it to them, you will receive a fax confirmation back from them. No need to go bother a friend to test your fax. Nice touch.<br /><br />The printer is blazingly fast, even with duplex printing. The quality is quite good, but not the very best I've ever seen. There's a HQ 1200dpi mode available, which shows marked improvement on printed images. I've use dedicated HP laser printers for the last couple of decades, and they have better print quality. But the Brother's output is excellent.<br /><br />Every feature I've tested works perfectly - print, copy, fax, scan, fax from PC, scan to PC, etc. We're using this at home, but it has a lot of features that are useful for a small office, including various network, security and remote management features.<br /><br />This is an all-around excellent device, an absolute bargain. I give it my unqualified recommendation.;;5.0;;December 20, 2009;;50;;51;;0.980392

R1GEHZSD1M579Y;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A1552EGFZY255G;;Printer;;B00450DVDY;;Brother HL-2270DW Compact Laser Printer with Wireless Networking and Duplex;;insane value & easy setup;;This is a nice, compact laser printer with good build quality.<br /><br />Wireless was essential for me - I've been waiting quite a while for a wireless laser that had reliably great reviews.  I unpacked the box, removed the plastic strips, scanned the quick start guide, plugged the printer in, and everything was great so far.  I then downloaded the newest drivers from the Brother website (drivers on included CD's are usually 3-12 month old) for my Windows 7 x64 and Windows 7 x32 laptops; executing the driver programs walks you through setup.  In the past for wireless products, I've found you usually have to first set them up on a wired (Ethernet or USB) connection, then change things over to wireless.  I decided to test the technological development level and go straight to wireless setup, starting with the 64-bit machine.  This consisted of inserting the tip of a pen [you could also use a paperclip, etc] into the wireless setup button hole, telling the printer to start looking for a router; then I ran downstairs, pushed/held the WPS button on my wireless router, telling it to start looking for another device - in one minute they met, and fell in love.  That was it.  The driver installation software (on the wireless 64-bit laptop) detected they had a successful partnership and moved on to the final screens.  Windows 7 had installed the printer with all of the advanced menus and controls.  I then installed the driver on the 32-bit laptop and it auto-detected the successful partnership without touching any hardware - very simple install and wireless printing was ready to go.<br /><br />I never bit with the wireless inkjet offerings, as the long term operating costs of inkjets are crazy.  I've been refilling the toner cartridges on laser printers for years, running them for so cheap it's amazing.  If this unit just had laser printing and reliable wireless it would be a fantastic deal.  However, it has many features which are totally surprising. This review is already too long so I'll just say that the auto duplexing is great.  What is even cooler is the Booklet feature.  I'm holding in my hand a 20-page PDF that I selected "Booklet" in the options while printing.  It printed on both sides of the paper, reduced the pages to half-sheets, arranged the pages in the precise/complicated order, and output tiny stack of FIVE sheets (from 20).  I folded the stack in half and viola - a perfect booklet that is more convenient to travel with and uses one-quarter of the paper!  I'm not sure you can know how cool this is until you actually have a booklet in your hand - so buy this machine now and see for yourself.<br /><br />One final caution, the supplier I normally order bulk toner from does not yet have the formulation for this printer.  I'm sure they will in time, but for now you might actually have to buy the TN450 replacement cartridge which runs at roughly 2.2 cents per page, once the 700-page starter cartridge is exhausted.<br /><br />I've only had this printer for a few days, so hopefully it lives up to my current expectations and retains its 5-star rating.  To be honest, these things are going for less than a hundred (on sale + coupon, at office supply stores) and at that price point just straight laser printing with wireless is a great deal.;;5.0;;November 15, 2010;;154;;159;;0.968553

R3V92JFBCQ8AIQ;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A2XT4MFGTMLXLR;;Printer;;B004IZN3RK;;Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Wireless Wide-Format Color Inkjet Printer (C11CA86201);;A Great Printer For The MoneyThe Epson R3000 is a really great deal;;I've been using Epson printers since 1995. I've also owned other inkjet printers as well as a few of the old dye-sub printers. The Epson products have a reputation for offering a great deal of bang for the buck so I was excited to get my hands on an R3000 to see how things have progressed for Epson.<br /><br />The R3000 is an A3+ printer that has been available since March, 2011. It's a pro-sumer model that many serious enthusiasts as well as professionals might find appealing. It uses Epson's UltraChrome K3 ink set which costs approximately $229 to replace. The new 25.9 ml ink tanks were easy to install.<br /><br />Unboxing the printer I was VERY glad that my assistant was here to help. This thing is a beast. You will need a substantial amount of space and a very sturdy desk or table to use it. It's well made and solid.<br /><br />You can feed paper through a front-loading paper path or a rear tray. The front paper path is for fine art papers. You can also use roll paper although I did not test installing the rollers. Likewise, you can print to CD but again, since that's not something I need to do I didn't test that function either.<br /><br />Setup is a bit daunting if you are like me, and got tricked into installing Lion on your Mac. You should NOT insert the disk that comes with the printer if you are running Lion. Go to Epson's site and download the drivers, utilities and ICC profiles from there. Install them and THEN turn on the printer's power. After about a 10-minute wait the inks are installed and primed. Then you can decide how you want to communicate with the printer. You can use a USB cable, network cable or wireless. Since I placed the printer outside my office in the studio, I used WIFI. You can connect to the router directly through the printer's own interface or connect a computer to the printer one time to speed that process up. I just used the printer's front control panel interface to type in the password to my router and all was well on the first try.<br /><br />While I do consider myself a master printer when it comes to a wet darkroom, I don't do enough of it on the digital side to know as much as some of the real artists and experts. Believe me when I tell you printing is as much an art as shooting. But I do know what I like and my initial test prints were quite nice.<br /><br />I tested a variety of papers from Ilford, Red River and Epson. There were ICC profiles for all the paper so it was easy to match the images I saw on my Apple LED Cinema Display, calibrated by an X-Rite iOne system.<br /><br />Depending on the paper, you can get very sharp prints - if that is what you are after. There are many art papers, even metal papers available so I will experiment with all and get a detailed review of the papers up later.<br /><br />The paper handling and loading was a breeze - once you read the manual. Print times were reasonably fast, ink coverage - again depending on the paper selected - was great and color gamut was very wide. The blacks were very black but occasionally a bit blocky.<br /><br />There was no banding or metamerism on the black and white prints I made. Most prints were very consistent from print to print but there were occasionally very small variances that most people would not notice.<br /><br />CONCLUSION<br /><br />The Epson R3000 is a really great deal. Considering the cost to replace all nine ink carts is rather high, that really great deal becomes just a great deal but a great deal nonetheless. I don't do a ton of my own printing but I am satisfied that anything under 13?19" can be easily handled by the R3000 and that the print quality will be first-rate.<br /><br />Highly recommended. I'd give it five stars if the ink weren't so expensive.;;4.0;;January 18, 2012;;12;;12;;1.0

R12Z8GL828TMCY;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A2BSYDI6DC3EZM;;Printer;;B0010Z1W06;;Brother HL-2140 Laser Printer;;Instructions for duplex, envelopes and booklet printing;;Great printer at a great price (around $50 on sale).  Using Times Roman font was weak so I mostly use Arial that prints better on this printer.  Covered window on the right side of the cartridge with opaque tape and the starter cartridge printed hundreds of pages after indicating empty.<br /><br />Here are my notes for printing duplex, envelopes and booklets using Word 2003:<br /><br />DUPLEX<br />From Bottom Tray (printing on face down side)<br />Print odd pages.<br />Put back with printed page up and top of page in front of tray.<br />Print even pages<br /><br />Single Page Feed (printing on face up side)<br />Open back output tray to get straight feed (for heavy stock)<br />Page side to be printed top<br />Insert page underneath rollers - make sure page is grabbed by rollers<br />Print<br />Return with top of page fed into slot<br />Print back side<br />Watch for skewed pages!<br /><br />ENVELOPES<br />Open back output tray to get straight feed for envelopes.<br />Bring up Printer in Control Panel<br />Printing Preferences/Paper Size: Choose COM 10<br />Move guides to envelope size (use both hands)<br />Put envelope in Front Feeder with side to be printed up (visible)<br /> and flap (bottom side) towards left side of printer<br />In Word 2003 choose Tools/Letters & Mailings/Envelopes & Labels<br />Print Envelope<br /><br />Note:  It wrinkled some.  Brother advises to turn envelope 180 deg<br />& change direction in software or printer driver.<br /><br />BOOKLETS (2 per page, 4 per sheet on both sides - Landscape)<br /><br />Word 2003<br /> Page Setup:<br />  Orientation: Landscape<br />  Multiple Pages: Book Fold<br /> Paper:<br />  Paper Size: Letter<br />  Width: 11"<br />  Height: 8.5"<br />  Default Tray<br /> Print<br /><br /> Properties/Advanced<br />  Click on A:B<br />  Manual Duplex<br />  Flip on Top Edge<br /><br />Click to print Even Pages<br />Wait till all even pages are printed<br />Return printed pages to tray<br /> Printed face up<br /> Top of page towards blue light<br />Click to print Odd Pages;;5.0;;October 22, 2009;;17;;17;;1.0

R1DLKPPCNMD0MQ;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A24124FPB4DNCJ;;Printer;;B004ULP9QA;;Brother Printer DCP7065DN Monochrome Laser Multi-Function Copier;;Awesome printer, cheap, great quality;;I've had this printer for a whole 10 hours, and only printed about 5-6 pages so far, but it's awesome!  Setup on my Mac was a breeze.  Hooked the printer up to the network and immediately got an IP with DHCP.  I then attempted to use the standard PCL driver with a standard JetDirect port on my Mac running OSx 10.6.. but don't do this.. it seems that printing a single page will cause the printer to just print a blank page... and then another one.. and then..won't stop :P.  Ohwell.. After loading the proper drivers, Mac nicely finds the printer over bonjour and automagically sets it up as a printer and scanner (whoo hoo).<br /><br />The Ups:<br />- Fast printing -- From deep sleep to wake up it takes about 20 seconds to get the first page out (pretty darn decent for a printer under 200 bucks)<br />- Energy saving -- in deep sleep it consumes less than a watt<br />- Solid drivers/software that doesn't get in the way.. for mac at least (not sure about windows)<br />- Painless duplex printing<br />- Copying without the need of a computer<br />- Super light (25 lbs?) and small footprint<br />- Toner cartridges that don't cost an arm and a leg<br />- A button on the printer that stops the current print job (AND actually works.. unlike some lexmark and hp printers I've encountered which cancel jobs that HAVEN'T been started yet.. ugh.)<br /><br />The Downs:<br />- Automatic document feeding can't scan double sided... but kind of expected, although.. you can tell it to scan a stack of (one-sided) documents and print double-sided documents<br />- The scanner lid seems to be spring-loaded, so be gentle when closing the flatbed scanner<br />- The scanner lid only opens 45 degrees  not 90 degrees... maybe this is normal.. but my xerox copier goes all the way up.. ohwell)<br />-Getting this printer to work in Linux (ubuntu 11.04) was a little painful-- had to install the cups and lpr driver from the website.. but it's decently document on Brother's website, so check it out (hint: even though ubuntu "recommends" using the 7045 driver, dont.. use 7065dn.. using the 7045 will just send the printer data, and then the printer will just go back to sleep without printing anything).<br /><br />So even with all the things that I don't like about the printer, I still highly recommend the printer, given the price and how many features brother packed into this model.  I would totally recommend this printer to anyone in the need of b/w network printer.<br /><br />EDIT: 7/31/2011--<br />The printer doesn't seem to have airprint support (yet), so those of you who want to print directly from you iphone/ipad/iwhatever.. sorry -- it won't work out of the box.. you'll probably need to setup a print server. I'll probably try doing this on a dd-wrt instance.  Also, I tried using the Brother iPrint&Scan app on my iPhone, but it didn't work with this printer.. ohwell.<br /><br />EDIT: 9/30/2011 @ 5:05pm--<br />According to the handy-dandy printer statistics webpage built into the printer, I've printed 442 pages so far, and the printer is telling me that I'm running low on toner.  I'm using the toner that came with the printer, (TN420) which is advertised to last about 1200 pages.  I don't believe that I've printed any images or anything that requires a ton of toner, so I'm a bit confused on why I'm low on toner.  Still-- Printer/scanner is great.. maybe just a defective toner unit that got shipped with the printer?<br /><br />EDIT: 9/30/2011 @ 5:13pm --<br />I found this "toner save" option in the web interface, so I enabled it. (Oops-- forgot about that.  Printed out a page and in my opinion, it looks the same as when the "toner save" option was disabled.  Hopefully I'll get better performance out of toner cartridges now.<br /><br />EDIT: 10/19/2012:<br />Yep, printer is still running strong.. by the way, numerous people have commented that the toner included with the printer is a 'starter toner'.  So if you buy this printer, you'll probably want to purchase a Brother TN420 along with this printer (or upgrade to the Brother TN450, if you're looking for the high yield model).;;5.0;;June 24, 2011;;233;;239;;0.974895

R1RKF2CMVUFRRP;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A18FNPT5UNWWE0;;Printer;;B003N3GUT6;;Epson Stylus NX420 Color Ink Jet All-in-One (C11CA80201);;Tremendous Disappointment;;Received this printer free with new hardware purchase. I priced these cartridges carefully over 12mo before writing this review and have found the Epson ink cartridges *much* more expensive than other printer brands including HP.  Also, mac owners beware that although this printer states it has an "economy" or "draft" print-mode, this is absolutely false - googling this matter will reveal what I have found in that any mode other than normal will result in ink barely dusting the page and absolutely unreadable due to it being so "light" (any color other than black does not even print it is so light on the page).  If these issues were not enough to sway you to look for an alternative brand printer, when one ink cartridge is reported "low," the Epson NX420 printer will be completely locked and inaccessible, including the inability to scan something to your computer (an option requiring no ink). R3KJ5XOCDMUDET;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/AL2E5SAFBLYS0;;Printer;;B000MLDPM2;;Epson Stylus Photo 1400 Wide-Format Color Inkjet Printer (C11C655001);;Good printer if calibrated with a custom icc profile;;I've had this printer for almost two years and have wasted a ton of ink and paper producing substandard prints. I bought a monitor calibration device, thinking perhaps that was the problem. The prints still were too dark and the colors were off. I downloaded icc profiles for the printer. Things only improved slightly. I was about to give up on it, but then decided to buy a Datacolor Spyder3Print to calibrate the printer. I mucked up about five sheets of photo paper because I'm too stubborn to read the instructions. Then I watched the how-to video at the datacolor site. Two more sheets of paper and my Epson 1400 was producing beautiful prints, just like I had expected it to out of the box.<br /><br />So at this point, I would give the printer five stars, and I would give the printer profiles one star. R1AVG0GTYK2VKW;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/ACBA1LZA9NXMH;;Printer;;B00450DVDY;;Brother HL-2270DW Compact Laser Printer with Wireless Networking and Duplex;;Good printer with some annoying quirks;;I just bought this printer for my dorm, because I've realized that this semester, I'll need to do a lot of printing... and walking to the library for $.10/side printouts was getting old. If the marketing material is to be believed, the printer itself, which comes with enough toner for 700 pages, is worth about 13 cents per page at the $90 I bought it for! Subsequently, with the $45 (currently), 2600-page toner cartridge, printouts will be under 2 cents a page.<br /><br />Things I like:<br />- It's small. Granted, it does take up a lot of room on my desk, but with their trays extended, most inkjet printers probably have around the same footprint. I'll soon have another place to put it, where hopefully it'll get in the way a little less.<br />- It has a nice, minimalist look.<br />- It's fast. In duplex mode, at 10 sides per minute, it'll beat most inkjet printers, even when they're set to single-sided printing. In single-sided mode, at 27 ppm, it's no contest.<br />- Being able to print double-sided automatically is fantastic. Even though paper is cheap (a fraction of the cost of toner), it still seems like a waste to print single-sided, and having less paper to carry around is nice.<br />- Though this is an advantage to laser printers in general, text comes out sharp, never runs or bleeds even if the page gets wet, and when printing double-sided, even on thin paper, toner will never bleed through to the other side of the paper.<br />- I can't use the device's networking capability on campus, but the ability to share the printer on a network without using a computer as a print server is very valuable functionality where one can use it. Even if it's only going to be used with one computer, and that computer is always right next to the printer, it's always nice to have one fewer cable cluttering things.<br /><br />Things that bother me:<br />- At its default resolution of 600DPI, some thin horizontal lines on certain fonts don't come through. I'm not sure if this is a problem with my unit, but it can be annoying.<br />- The user interface is terrible. I understand it's a low-cost printer... but I'm sure they could afford to throw in a few more buttons. It has only one button, which is used for all functionality, through things like holding it for some period of time, repeatedly pressing it some number of times, or turning the printer on while holding it.<br />- Related to the above: Canceling a print job requires holding down the button for four seconds. By this time, two pages will have already printed! Seriously, even if the device only has one button, could they not have it cancel the job immediately? I can't imagine any other functionality the button might be needed for during a print job. More egregiously, I've never actually had it successfully cancel a print job... the lights indicate it's canceling, but the remaining pages of the job still come out. The only way to stop it is cutting the power, which results in a messy jam that has to be manually cleared, not to mention most likely being pretty bad for the printer.<br />- The manual feed is near useless. About half the time, no matter how carefully I've tried, it'll pull the paper in one corner first. It's never resulted in a jam, but the printout comes out massively skewed.<br />- Others have complained about the noise from the fan. It definitely seems like there's no reason for it to run, even at low speed, for so long after it's finished printing. But I'd like to note an additional complaint: After the fan has stopped, there is a slight high-pitched electronic whine. It's hardly noticeable if there's any background noise, but when it's right there on the desk, I can hear it. Perhaps in a few years when I lose some of my hearing range, it won't bother me, but as it is, I generally turn it off.<br />- The power usage is rated at 65W when "ready" and 500W or so when printing. What they really mean by this is that, when "ready," it may in fact draw 65W on average, but what it is actually doing is, every so often, momentarily drawing something between 500W and 900W. This is something I feel they should specify. Especially in a dorm room, where a microwave, fridge, and printer might all be on the same circuit, blowing a fuse or tripping a breaker is a real possibility. When printing, the power draw varies, but often exceeds the average value of 500W. By the way -- the only advantage to having it stay awake for longer is that you'll save 10 or so seconds waiting for it to warm up before the first page comes out. Definitely not worth the 65W power consumption -- that's like leaving an incandescent light on. I have mine set to go to sleep after a minute of activity. This is probably appropriate for most users.;;4.0;;February 6, 2012;;11;;11;;1.0

I gets 3 stars because it is a reliable and easy-to-use little printer, but there are some irritating things about it.  First let me say that this is the only laser printer I have ever owned, so I won't be comparing it with any other models.<br /><br />PROS:<br />1)It is reliable and gets the job done. It hardly ever jams or acts up.<br /><br />2) The toner is reasonable if you shop around for the best price (Amazon is always competitive, but not necessarily the cheapest if someone else is running a sale).  Keep in mind there are two toner cartridge types the tn330 and tn360 - I've only used the extended one (tn360).<br /><br />3)The starter toner you get actually goes pretty far - I printed close to 1000 copies, maybe more.  It is very easy to get set up and operate.<br /><br />CONS:<br />1)I have not done a good job at keeping track of how many copies I get out of one of the tn360's, but it often seems to not quite last as long as it should.  More importantly, the toner cartridges stop working BEFORE they actually run out of toner.  There are sensors on the cartridges that tell the printer the toner is low.  You get the warning messages, but the pages you are printing still look fine.  Then one day, it says the toner is out.  But the last page you printed was perfect.  Why?  There are sensors on the cartridges that the printer reads.  However, there is a work-around of this.  Go to You Tube and do a search.<br /><br />2)  Drum replacement.  After a few extended TN360 cartridges, I started getting the drum warning light.  A new drum costs about what the printer costs.<br /><br />Bottom line:  This printer has a huge hidden cost in the drum replacement, and the toner sensor is a little evil, but it starts off so cheap that it can be worth it.  I have not tried any 3rd party toner cartridges or drum replacements, but they are significantly cheaper than Brother stuff.  I am thinking of trying one of the drum replacements from a 3rd party *they go for under $60).  If I do and it works, it will make the printer a pretty affordable little workhorse.  If not, the best option seems to be to just buy a new one, because you get a new drum and starter printer cartridge.;;3.0;;August 22, 2009;;9;;12;;0.75

R2ZJQC2NYFUNM7;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A1XEDLG5WQVYJ0;;Printer;;B001XM9BV8;;Brother HL-5370DW Laser Printer;;Great speed, resolution, and price.  Perfect "back-to-school" computer for the modern networked household;;Ordered the printer with Amazon's free "Super Saver" shipping and it arrived at the house (in Texas) 2 days later (which made me glad that I didn't pay extra for expedited shipping).  Excellent printing speed, excellent print quality, and an amazingly reasonable price for this very capable unit.  Initial wired set-up was a snap, and the kids were printing study guides and assignments like crazy.  For wireless networking you're generally going to need a spare ethernet cable to connect the printer to your wireless router (so you can configure the printer to communicate with your wireless network).  A potential problem here is that the instructions that come with the printer might not use precisely the same language/words as your router/networking software so it might take you a bit of trial-and-error to discover if your "Authentication method" really runs as an "open system" (as opposed to a "shared key", etc.), or whether or not you're really running data encryption (both "authentication" and "encryption" can be distinct from running a standard "secure" network using, for example, a WEP code).  If you're not sure and incorrectly enter your "Authentication method" as a "shared key" (because you use a network key to access your wireless network), you'll discover that the wireless link status "Failed to associate."  No problemo, but while re-running the wireless networking program you might find that your network stops recognizing your printer as a potential "wireless device".  If this happens, the recently entered (incorrect) printer settings might be the culprit so you will have to reset your printer to its "factory default" settings as described in the manual (page 43 on my version).  After the printer is reset, you can then rerun the wireless networking protocol and give it another go (while changing the wireless settings).  For my standard home network, the proper settings turned out to be "Authentication method" = "Open System" and "Encryption mode" = "none" (even though the later print-out showed the "Encryption Mode" as "WEP").  After entering the standard WEP code (as the "Network Key") the wireless link fired right up and the various wired and wireless computers in the house had no problem printing (after loading the drivers).  The above process took about 45 minutes to trouble shoot with the longest period spent reading through the manual so I could learn how to reset the factory defaults on the printer.  All-in-all, about average for a "Windows" install where you're stuck with somewhat ambiguous semantic compatibility issues muddled by imprecise directions.  As always, it's all good after the problem is solved.  Hopefully, these remarks might help you get to the good part a little sooner.  Good luck!;;5.0;;September 6, 2009;;18;;19;;0.947368

Brother's best value cartridge (for all-in-ones) is the LC-65 or LC-79.  HP's best value cartridge is the HP940XL.  Epson's is the 127 ,  Lexmark's is the 105XL/ 100XL, Canon's is the PGI-7/ PGI-9.<br /><br />I chose this Brother MFCJ6510DW  because the cost per page for the Brother LC79 cartridge was one of the very best ($.0333 per page avg.) and the LC79 cartridges are very large so don't need to be replaced as often. You can even scan and wirelessly send the scans to you computer.  (worked the first time). The paper tray is a bit inconvenient cause you have to remove the whole thing to add paper (like old full-size copy machines).<br /><br />I've had it for about a month and have printed a 2" thick stack of 8.5x11 color prints (with about 30% page coverage) on the highest setting and still haven't run out of ink from the original (non-high-yield) cartridges. If you're looking for a color laser for photographs or high-volume printing, this printer is not for you. I have a Canon inkjet all-in-one, but I wanted a laser printer for my small office that could add color to graphic elements like graphs and icons.<br /><br />Pros:<br /><br />Fast to start (for a laser.)<br />25 PPM for single-sided color and B&W.<br />Prints color.<br />Cheap (compared to other color lasers.)<br />It has auto duplexing, so it can print on both sides of a page without having to feed the paper back into the tray.<br />It has an Ethernet port.<br />Very quiet on standby with low power consumption.<br />Text is very crisp.<br />LCD screen.<br /><br />Cons:<br /><br />Not good for photos.<br />Colors tend towards oversaturated at the stock levels.<br />Minor page curl (depends on the paper.)<br />Likes to lie to you about the toner levels (but there's a fix for that.)<br />Toner cartridges are spendy (but you can refill them.)<br />It's noisy while printing.<br />No built-in wireless.<br /><br />The only real differences between the HL-4150CDN and the more expensive HL-4570CDW was a slightly lower PPM and the lack of built-in wireless. Since I had a good experiencing with my previous Brother printer (a HL-2150W,) already owned a wireless to Ethernet receiver, and felt an extra 5 PPM was not going to kill me, I went with the HL-4150CDN.<br /><br />The LCD screen is small, but it does give you the toner levels and tell you error/status messages. You still get more information through the Brother software, but it is more informative than a blinking LED. No more wondering if all the noise is going to result in a printed copy or the printer has hit a snag when you send a print job. I like the fact you can change the angle of the screen. My printer sits on a table with the top at eye level, but I can still read the screen at a glance without having to get up.<br /><br />For a color laser with automatic duplexing, you're not going to find a better deal in this price range.<br /><br />Someone asked me about this, soooo...<br /><br />HOW TO RESET THE TONER COUNTERS<br /><br />Open the toner compartment door. When the LCD screen shows the toner door open status message, press the SECURE and CANCEL buttons simultaneously. This will take you to the toner counter menu. Use the up and down buttons to navigate the menu. There are three counters for each toner cartridge. Reset the counters for the 'empty' cartridge and it will allow you to print. You will want to reset the counters again after replacing or refilling the cartridge. There are videos on YouTube that show you how to refill the cartridges. Just do a search for TN-315 refill.<br /><br />Hope this helps some folks.;;5.0;;February 5, 2012;;10;;10;;1.0

R2UFZJ22IK816J;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/AV252YPWNODEV;;Printer;;B0044XSNHG;;HP LaserJet Pro CP1525nw Color Printer (CE875A);;Good value, install on MAC not easy (install instructions);;For the price this a good color laser printer (I have given up on inkjets . . . inks run out too fast etc).  The device is not too big or heavy - we have several different color lasers at work and they are all monsters.  The toner cartridges sit in a tray and are really small, but should be very easy to replace.  Hopefully they will not dry up like my ink.<br /><br />The issue is that the provided documentation and online documentation is *surprisingly* bad.  Not sure if this will help anyone, but this is the install on a MAC.  First - the CD provided as usual had old software, so I downloaded the new software.  I read the readme file (useless) and online FAQ, and it is replete with errors.  It says to connect the USB cable when the software instructs you to.  On a MAC, it never does, and the screen simply is blank as it cannot find the printer.  So, just plug in the USB cable, adn the software will see the printer.<br /><br />Continue with the install.  It will ask if you want the device to be wireless (of course you do, that is the whole point of this printer).  Click yes, and the software will turn on the wireless card in the printer, and locate your Wifi SSID, if you have it broadcasting. (You can also try AOS setup but that has never worked for me).  Enter your password.  When it tells you to, disconnect the USB, and now your MAC printer driver should see the device.  So far, so good, and not too bad (just the error about wait for software to tell you to plug in USB).<br /><br />On the next screen it asks if you want to set up web services printing.  Here is where the trouble starts.  If you click that, the program will download a firmware checking software and run it, and at least for me as of 3/22/2011, my firmware was out of date.  So, you click update, and it downloads the firmware.  Problem 1:  If you try and update the printer at this point, it will report "Device busy, try again" - and the device is busy becuase the driver installer is left open.  Go back to the driver installer, click continue, and eventually ok, and that will close.  Now go back to the firmware updater, and it should update the firmware.<br /><br />Problem 2: At least on my WRT54G wireless device, the firmware initiates a new DHCP IP address, so, the printer now has the new firmware, but also a new IP address.  The MAC printer driver has the old IP address.  So, as I did not know how to change the software, I simply logged into the web server on the printer (using the new IP address), went into configuration, checked manual, and put in the old IP adddress.  You should also exclude theis IP on your router from DHCP assignment.  I suppose the other way is to uninstall, then re-install, the printer driver, and it will use the new IP address.  The moral of this story here is that on at least some routers, the device will be assigned a new IP.<br /><br />Problem 3 - at this point, a new tab appears on the device's web pages, for web print services.  If you click on that, there is an enable button.  What that is suppose to do, is to assign the device a unique email address through HP.  It never worked for me, it just reported "Unable to Connect, Try again later" - and I even pulled out an old windoze machine to make sure it was not some windows specific issue.  Never worked.  On top of that, when I tried to create an account at the HP ePrint site, the website simply was non functional on a mac . . . never could enter a new account there.  I tried safari, Firefox and Opera on the Mac.<br /><br />I had misunderstood what ePrint is.  I wanted to be able to print from my iphone and ipad.  Turns out, you can, without eprint enabled.  Works fine, and my ipad and iphone easily found the printer and printed fine.  ePrint is apparently just for web printing (i.e. you email a print job to the printer at the special email address it is suppose to create for you, that I could not ever get created).<br /><br />So, the device itself seems to work nicely and print fairly well (I do semi pro photography, and this printer is not really going to be easy to calibrate, I printed out the calibration page and noted in the whites that at least 4 boxes had no gradation).  However, the pictures look pretty good for everyday use.  I may try later with some satins and real calibration to see what I get.<br /><br />Finally it seems some manufacturers are waking up to the market share MAC users have and this device is almost there, but the documentation is horrible.  I also did try and search for FAQ and other users having issues, and some users reported some issues, but the FAQ on how to do a wireless install and firmware update on a MAC is just way too complex and wrong.<br /><br />- mike;;4.0;;March 23, 2011;;4;;5;;0.8

R1ZUZSZUOO0VHJ;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A2JSLC9F2VWPFZ;;Printer;;B0040XYTIW;;HP Deskjet 3050 All-in-One Printer (CH376A#B1H);;Here are some tips to get the wireless to;;Buy it if you want to use the USB cable but if you want to use Wireless... well I'm sure you saw the other reviews here.<br /><br />I spent hours trying to set this printer up.  I wouldn't pay more than $20 for the thing because of the headache it took to get it going.<br /><br />It connected to my router easily and without problem, but I couldn't get computers to connect to the printer.<br />After a lot of searching and asking questions I found this information that helped me get it working through the wireless.  Hope it helps you!<br /><br />For Windows XP:<br />-Download the latest version of the drivers and software from the HP website.  (I got version 22.5.0).<br />-Install them and this time it will give you the option to connect to the printer using its IP address.<br />-Type in your printer's IP address and the software will tell you it still can't connect to the printer.  (You can find the address by printing a diagnostics page from the printer or checking the connected devices on your router.  Use Google if you don't know how to do these.)<br />-Tell the install program to use the IP address you entered and install anyway.<br />-This was all I had to do to make it work.  (Just make sure your printer's IP address doesn't change)<br /><br />For Mac OS (I was using 10.5):<br />-Go to System Preferences, then go to Print and Fax.<br />-Click on the '+' to add a new printer<br />-Click on the IP icon on the top.<br />-Make sure that the protocol is "HP Jetdirect - Socket"<br />-Type in the IP address of the printer. It should recognize the printer, give it a meaningful name and hopefully you will have success!  I did.<br />-Another tidbit I heard:  If it doesn't recognize the printer, go to the drop down menu Print Using, chose select printer software, and type in f4500, and it should be the only one on the list.  Then click add, and it will think for a second and the printer should get added.<br /><br />Follow-up March 2012:<br />We got a new router a few months ago and I still had the same issues installing the printer so it doesn't seem router related, but I upgraded to Windows 7 last month and it installed fine.  I didn't have any issue installing it then so I wonder if the issue is OS related.;;2.0;;February 5, 2011;;32;;38;;0.842105

R2I53QBG8735TC;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A147Y8COSWI6O5;;Printer;;B004GXAY9E;;Brother MFC-9970CDW Color Laser All-in-One with Wireless Networking and Duplex;;Don't Buy Genuine Brother Toners!;;This printer is great and worth 5 stars based on the printer's abilities alone, seriously, but Brother is a apparently "very enthusiastic" about regularly (and frequently) replacing half-full toners with new Genuine Brother toners, to the tune of about $70-80 each.  Yeah, right.  I happily bought a refill kit which has worked fantastically in both volume and print quality.  I'm not changing, nor am I wasting an extra $150-$200 every 2-3 months for my toners.<br /><br />I'm writing this review because a Brother Customer Support Technician wouldn't help me reset my toners.  After hearing his lecture on Genuine Brother Toners and his adamant denial to help, I offered him an analogy.  I simply asked if he went to a car dealership for "Genuine" oil, brakes, service, etc. EVERY TIME he had his car serviced.  He of course had no answer after recognizing his own hypocrisy.  So, to help others that may end up in my situation, here's how to reset your toners.<br /><br />If you have the starter cartridges, you will need to buy a refill kit of some sort, and a flag gear, or reset gear (see below for links).  If that is done and you are still receiving the "Replace Toner" message, here's what to do:<br /><br />1- Turn on printer<br />2- Open front door to access toners<br />3- Hit the "Start" button for the Black and White copies on the right side of control panel<br />4- Quickly type in the number "10" on the numerical keypad  (1 then 0, quickly in succession)<br />5- You will see a toner menu.  Simply pick you color(s) and capacities and reset as needed.<br /><br />You can now refill your toners to a high capacity level for about $20 each, vs. $80 for "genuine brother" toners.  Your cost per page probably dropped to about 3 cents each.<br />THANK YOU Brother Customer Support for motivating me to post this review.<br />All the best everyone!<br /><br />ADDITIONAL INFO 2 MONTHS AFTER ORIGINAL POST:<br />Print quality on multiple types of paper is just as good as "Genuine Brother" starter toners.  The photo print quality of this color laser printer is lacking, but that is true for most color laser printers.<br /><br />I don't have any affiliation whatsoever with any of the following companies/entities, but they posted the info I originally found, so, here's some links to take you step-by-step.<br />You can get toner and a flag gear here:<br />[...]<br />OR, I'm sure if you type in "Brother TN-310 or TN-315 toner refill" into ebay or google you'd come up with some links, possibly cheaper, better, etc.<br /><br />Here's instructions on changing the toner and reset gear (AKA "flag gear"):<br />http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v9esBMg13ek&feature=related<br /><br />Instructions on changing the flag gear only:<br />[...]<br /><br />I have to say thanks to everyone who has rated this review as "helpful" on Amazon, it keeps it at the top of the listings and allows more printer purchasers to avoid getting taken for a ride on the Brother-Toner-Money-Train.<br />Take care-;;4.0;;November 14, 2011;;933;;940;;0.992553

R34FLRO34QRNAB;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A1KTZR0W57XWKQ;;Printer;;B003E1S2K2;;Lexmark Pinnacle Pro901 All-in-One Printer;;Some very good, some very bad - but mostly bad;;3/3/2011. I was managing to work with that until I started to get wide blue streaks across the pages.  Must be the print head, I thought, so ran the head cleaner utility provided by Lexmark.  After that was done I got a message that the process did not work and gave instructions how to remove the head and clean.  I did as instructed, put it back in, and since that time I only get a message that "there is a problem with the print head".  When I searched the web for solutions I read many reports of a similar issue with the print heads, with no one having a suitable solution.  Then I tried to find a replacement print head but they did not seem to exist. Long story short, I now have a $200 printer with unused ink cartridges and all together nothing works. You can take a chance and see if you can get one that works, but if I were you it is not worth the significant hassle.<br /><br />Below is my earlier review<br /><br />First of all, I got this printer mainly to print in black, except for the rare occasion that I want to print greeting cards in color, and to use the copier. The problem that I have is that if the printer jambs, which is does frequently while printing on heavier card stock, the print spooler seems to get stuck and I get the "printer is unable to communicate with the computer" error message.  I am then unable to delete the item from the sprint spooler, and the only way to continue printing is to reboot the computer.  This same issue arises if the computer goes "to sleep" - all communications with the printer stops until a reboot.  I did not have this issue with any of the other 2 printers I have had in the past on this computer, only the Lexmark.  I did manage to print 45 greeting cards in color (with much difficulty) and the ink usage, both color and black and white, was very minimal, so the price of each color cartridge do not concern me.  Like other printers with a front load, the heavier card stock has to do a 180 turn to pass by the print head and that is where the jamb seems to occur.  If making cards is something you want to do I recommend getting a back loaded printer instead of this one.  I have not tested it at all yet with photos, however.  I have rated the installation as three stars because while the instructions were clear and the installation seemed to go easily, the problem with the necessary reboot to print so consistantly happening I just decided to blame the setup routine for not addressing this issue. R3JBKBK5535XPZ;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A19J3PQJXPWNES;;Printer;;B0044XSNHG;;HP LaserJet Pro CP1525nw Color Printer (CE875A);;So Far so good;;I copied the following from the support forums :<br />[...]<br /><br />This is good information.<br /><br />Re: hp cp1525nw printer setup assistant incompatible with mac os 10.7 lion<br />Options<br />10-30-2011 09:46 AM<br /><br />Got it!  The process is a little convoluted, but it works.<br /><br />0. DO NOT install the HP software!  It predates Lion.  Just plug in the printer via USB and let OS-X do its own updating, it should work fine, but it will take a little while to download and patch.<br />1. Connect an ethernet cable between the printer and your computer.  Give it a minute to pick up an IP address.<br />2. From the printer, print the Network Summary report, under TCP/IP(v4) it should list a 169.254.x.x address, enter this address into a web browser.<br />3. You're now in the printer's web interface and can set up the wireless configuration to connect the printer to your router!  But you're not quite done yet...<br />4. You now have the printer configured to accept wireless connections through your router, now you need to add the wireless printer to your computer configuration.  Go to System Preferences/Print & Scan and click on the + to add a printer.  It should come up with HP LaserJet CP1525nw (xxxxxx).  I don't know what the xxxxxx is, some sort of address.  Anyway, this is your WiFi connection.  Once OS-X is done, you should be good to go.  Disconnect any cables between the printer and your computer, and you should be good to go!<br /><br />(and I'm recreating the steps above from memory, but they should get you close, if not entirely there);;4.0;;December 4, 2011;;5;;5;;1.0

R2BARN6F4VMEPJ;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A36JORW3Q8F56A;;Printer;;B004QM8J8S;;Brother Printer Wireless Monochrome Printer, Dark Grey (HL2280DW);;Works as Advertised;;I was actually looking for a single function laser copier - but, unless you are looking at a high end office machine, they are getting as rare as dodo birds.<br /><br />In any case, it works as advertised. Of course, you aren't told this.<br /><br />The installation procedure also installs two software programs on your PC which enable control of scanning operations from your computer.  There is a little program called Control Center 4 which effects basic scanning commands and permits cropping before storing the file.  In addition, there is a commercial program called PaperPort 12SE.  Paperport has a really useful feature which allows a "pre-scan" operation.  You then bracket the sub-part of the image that you really wanted to scan (e.g. a stamp on an envelope).  Then you do a second scan.  The results at 1200 dpi are quite spectacular on items like stamps. Assuming you wouldn't pay more for a drum than for a new printer, that limits the lifespan of the printer to 12,000 pages. At best.<br /><br />Overall a good value, for a relatively low output small office or home printer.;;4.0;;April 25, 2011;;13;;14;;0.928571

This wouldn't be a big deal if the printer worked as advertised, but it doesn't.<br /><br />As other negative reviews have stated, you can only use this printer for 10-15 minutes at a time with WiFi before it goes to sleep. Once it goes to sleep you MUST cycle the printer's power before it will work again... which pretty much negates the key usage of a WiFi enabled printer. Sometimes, the printer doesn't come back on via WiFi even after a power cycle, so you have to set it up all over again!<br /><br />I am no amateur when it comes to setting up printers, but using this printer is a frustrating nightmare that never seems to get better. Hopefully Samsung will eventually come out with a fix for this Wake On Lan (WOL) issue, but until they do, steer clear of this printer at all costs if you plan on using it via WiFi.<br /><br />In my home I have 4 Windows 7 PCs, 2 Windows XP PCs and a Windows Home Server, and they ALL have the same issue with this printer. Even still, I would print 5 or 6 pages, and then it would clog again, but printing 20 pages unattended, I'd come back to 15 ruined prints, on expensive paper no less. It also feels like it "replenishes" ALL the ink cartridges when replacing even just one. I only use the printer a few times a month, so it seems like I'm not getting the maximum usage from the ink because of that. I purchased a much lower cost ink-jet now for day to day printing, but even that one, also a Canon, sucks up the ink like its free, though at a MUCH reduced cost compared to this one. R3GS75AMLABSFW;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/ARMA0E0V71FLZ;;Printer;;B0044XSNHG;;HP LaserJet Pro CP1525nw Color Printer (CE875A);;Product Installation CD was corrupt. Slight Inconvenience.;;Like many others writing reviews here, I was tired of dried out inkjet cartridges after weeks or months of no use, so went looking for a LaserJet printer for intermittent home use. InkJet still seems very popular, at least by my physical searches at CompUSA, Costco, BJs and Staples. There are less expensive laser printers out there (Okidata & Brother to name two), but a quick look at the supplies shelves at CompUSA made me shy away from all but HP due to expensive toner cartridges. Not saying HP has good prices, just better pricing than lesser known brands.<br /><br />Searching for wireless capabilities, so that I can place this printer anywhere, without having a dedicated computer operating as a print server, combined with a four-star rating led me to this printer on Amazon. Two weeks before Christmas they were sold out at the $178 price point.<br /><br />Second week in January, I searched for this printer again. They were available around $205 shipping included. When spouse informed me she would like a printer "tomorrow," I searched in Google, clicked the "Shopping" link on the left of the page, then clicked the "nearby stores" and found this printer at several box stores for $224.95. Staples was closest to me, so I went there and picked one up. Heavy-handed sales pitch for the extended warranty was not appreciated, but after 27 years in sales, I can say no to things I don't want or need.<br /><br />Picked up a sales leaflet on the way out the door and the next day noticed that there was a $50 recycling credit if you turned in an old printer, so went back to the store and got another $50 off the purchase by turning in my parallel port HP DeskJet 820. I had already thrown away the workhorse HP DeskJet 970Cse which had the ink spitoon overflow on my desk and white carpeting - ruining both.<br /><br />Unpacking the printer was easy. Zip through the tape on top of box, and diagrams on an inside flap tell you how to dump out the printer; but I was able to do so easily when I overlooked the diagrams.<br /><br />There was another quickstart diagram taped to the paper output tray, which highlighted almost all tape and toner sealer removal. Suffice to say, all blue and orange tape must be removed and the toner cartridges must be unsealed (pull the ring tab) to use the printer.<br /><br />Load up paper in drawer #2, plug in, turn on and load CD into computer. DO NOT HOOK-UP THE USB CABLE. HP PRINTERS LIKE TO HAVE SOFTWARE INSTALLED BEFORE CONNECTING TO THE COMPUTER/NETWORK.<br /><br />Software was about half installed when I got a fatal error: Error 0x80070570 The file or directory is corrupt and unreadable. File name: dpinst.exe . Tried again, same error. Pulled the CD - there was a tiny drop of glue or something on the CD face, but after removal, still error. Tried copying the CD to the harddrive and the copy program said the same thing: corrupt or unreadable file or directory structure. I.E., the CD was hosed. Incidentally, the corrupt CD was the updated 3.03.5253 version of the full install drivers and firmware update. IF you want to utilize the ePrint functionality, you will need the latest firmware update, at least version 20111215 or better. HPdotCom is the place to secure the latest drivers.<br /><br />Once the driver was downloaded (140MB), installation was easy. Mine was accomplished over the wireless network (Netgear WNDR3700 Dual-Band). Was also able to connect to the wireless repeater, though am having some issues locating the printer when it is connected to the repeater vs. the gateway router.<br /><br />==========================Later=========================<br /><br />Printer has been powered now about 4 hours. It has spontaneously "calibrated" itself three times, and does go into "Power-Save" mode after maybe 15 minutes. Even though in power-save, the wireless functionality remains on, so it will wake on demand.<br /><br />Sample pages look good printing on bright white 28lb laser paper.<br /><br />Now to the next computer...<br /><br />I could not find the printer from spouse's computer until I installed the driver (grabbed it from 1st computer across the network so I did not have to download 140MB again. After installation of software (which required installation of Microsoft Net Framework 3.5 on XPPro computer), the same initial setup screen appeared and I repeated some of the steps again. The software could not find the printer, so it asked to be connected via the USB cable in order to retrieve the network setup from the printer. This process probably took about 5 minutes, after which there was a message saying to disconnect the USB cable. Clicked the FINISH button with check boxes for "Make this my default printer" and "Print a Test Page" selected. The XP test page was printed, and set-up was completed.<br /><br />Now (so far, fingers crossed) whether I log the printer into the repeating router or the gateway, regardless of which router the computer(s) are logged into, everything works transparently - as designed.<br /><br />I even sent an iPod document to my new ePrint.com email address, and it immediately printed from the printer. Just like being able to print to a remote printer across an intranet or the internet! WOOT!<br /><br />==========================UPDATE after 30 days=========================<br /><br />Still happy with the printer. BUT, all users should know that you can adjust when the toner cartridges show that they are out of toner, as well as the action to take when they are out. They are set default from the factory to show that they are Very Low at 21% remaining toner. Like the HP CP2025DN printer one can set this printer to keep printing as the toner is almost exhausted (Stop Override), as well as set this printer to indicate the toner is "very low" at one percent (instead of the 21% which is the default value). Step by step is below. When I was researching printers, I ran across this tid-bit thanks to a comment written by Rob when responding to a review written by usna 76. Rob gave the step-by-step to usna76's last paragraph regarding "several hundred pages of printing left" after the printer "stops at Out." [permalink: http://www.amazon.com/review/R2TU1FE13T1ZOQ/ref=cm_cr_rdp_perm?ie=UTF8&ASIN=B001F0RI1I&nodeID=&tag=&linkCode= ]<br /><br />To enable the cartridge out override (which allows you to keep printing beyond the indicated toner out message as long as there is toner left:<br />1. On the control-panel menu, press OK.<br />2. Press the Left arrow button 3 times to get to System Setup, then press OK.<br />3. Press the Left arrow button 3 times to select System Setup At Very Low and then press OK.<br />4. At Very Low Black Cartridge is the next choice, press OK.<br />5. Choices are "Continue" "Stop" or "Prompt." Having read that HP's default has been that between 20-25% remaining toner in a cartridge the printer "Stops," I knew I wanted to override "Stop" by choosing "Continue."<br />6. Cycle through the choices until you find the one you want. "Continue" will allow you to utilize most of the toner you paid for. Notice that your choice at each menu level is indicated by an asterisk (*) to the far right of the LCD display.<br />7. Press OK to "save" your choice, then the right arrow 1 time which should give you "At Very Low Color Cartridges." Press OK and make the same choice as in steps 5 and 6 above. Then press OK (to save your choice) and wait two seconds to return to "At Very Low Color Cartridges." Then press the Return Arrow (to the far left of the menu buttons between the OK and X button).<br />8.If you want to adjust what your printer identifies as "Low" Toner level, press the Right Arrow once and you should see "User-Defined Low." Don't worry if you see Language, Courier Font, Contrast, etc. The choices "wrap" so you will eventually get to "User-Defined Low." When you do press OK.<br />9. You will see "User-Defined Low Black." Press OK. If your printer is set like mine, it will be set to 21%. By using the left and right arrow keys you can adjust the percentage to whatever you feel comfortable with. I chose 5% for Black and each of the three color cartridges.<br />10. By now I am sure you know to press OK to save your new percentage number which after a couple of seconds will back you out to "User-Defined Low Black." Pressing the Right Arrow button will take you to Cyan and so forth. Remember to double-check that the asterisk appears next to your choice as a confirmation that the correct number was set.<br />11. Press the Return Arrow (Return to previous screen arrow-(to the far left of the menu buttons between the OK and X button) about 4 times to take you out to "Ready."<br /><br />Here's hoping this helps you get an extra 20%+ from your toner cartridges!;;4.0;;January 15, 2012;;9;;10;;0.9
R3ISDE6ZJCAGYX;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A37G96J3PVIAG6;;Printer;;B003YT6RLK;;HP Officejet Pro 8500A Plus Wireless e-All-in-One (CM756A#B1H);;Lemons to Lemonade;;I purchased this printer AIO as a replacement for an aging Canon which had served us well but had become a hassle to find/order replacement ink cartridges.
