I haven't done envelopes as I use a label printer so no idea how well envelopes work. Network installation in a home office was simple and straightforward. I us os X  and the driver has a nice booklet printing feature that I find very useful. The printer does business cards on card stock which I have found problematic on other lasers. It also has the option of a straight paper path which is highly useful for some kinds of jobs. It can be set to a quiet mode that slows things down to about half speed, but even that speed is fine for most jobs and can be easily reset for the few big ones I do. One negative is that even in quiet mode it is a little loud, not overwhelming, but that is the only (very slight negative). Another downside is on the windows side (which I run from a virtual machine now and then). The windows drivers have an intrusive autoupdate feature that I have not figured how to disable. Also, it comes with a starter toner cartridge (maybe 1600 pages) which means having to add the cost of a full cartridge pretty soon. The positive here is that there are two replacement toners, a 2500 pager and a huge 6300 pager. Too bad Amazon doesn't sell these directly so I can't use Amazon prime. My final complaint is the lack of a printed manual - you have to rely on the .pdf on the install disk. Unfortunately, this seems standard for all manufacturers. R1TQPIOKO1NZFI;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A250L81G74UYKG;;Printer;;B005N3FMDE;;HP Photosmart 7510 All-in-One with eFax Printer;;Great Print Quality (But Follow These Tips for Easy Setup);;I bought the 7510 to replace an ailing Lexmark 4550. Print quality is excellent, for photos as well as documents.  The pictures I've printed so far look better than those I've gotten from Walgreen's or Snapfish.  Although I probably won't be printing dozens of photos at a time,I can see that the capability will come in very handy for those times when I want to print selected photos, and don't want to bother with going out to Walgreen's or mail ordering them.  For example, if someone admires one of my photos, I can give them a copy of it on the spot.<br /><br />Scan quality is great; it lets you specify the resolution of the saved scan file.  So, you can use a lower quality for things such as letters or maps, and increase the resolution for photos where you want to capture lots of detail.<br /><br />I haven't tried any of the more esoteric functions such as e-fax (and in all likelihood will never need them), so I can't comment on how well they work. For the basic functions of print, scan, and copy, it works great.<br /><br />In another review someone groused about paying $100 for the five ink cartridges.  That is really a bit misleading, since there are separate cartridges for high quality photo black, the three colors (cyan, magenta and yellow), and a large black ink cartridge for regular non-photo printing such as text documents.  If one of the cartridges gets low you can replace just that one cartridge; you do not have to replace all the others like you would with a single "combo"  cartridge (e.g., if one color gets low, you just buy the one cartridge and keep on using the other ones). This is important since you aren't likely to use up all the colors at the exact same pace. And, for only a few bucks more, you can get the XL cartridges that contain a lot more ink, and will last a lot longer between replacements.<br /><br />NOTE:  the lady at Officemax suggested I replace the original black cartridge that came with the printer with the larger XL cartridge from the very start.  DO NOT DO THIS.  The instructions in the downloaded user's manual specifically state that the cartridges that come with the printer are special "setup" cartridges and must be the ones that are used when the printer is first configured.  If another cartridge is used, the printer won't be set up the way it is supposed to.<br /><br />The color touch screen menus are very easy to use; one thing I especially liked was how well the virtual keyboard works.  It requires just enough pressure so that it almost totally eliminates accidentally entering the wrong letter or number.  A very gentle push is required; the letter / number then appears in a magnified highlight for a split second so you also get a positive visual confirmation. It is much better in this respect than the touch screens on my camera or e-book reader.<br /><br />I could go on raving about the features and quality of the printer but other reviews have already covered them.  So, let me now move on to setting the thing up and attaching it to an existing network.  In my case, I was installing it on an existing home wireless network, controlled by a Linksys router.  The main PC is a Dell running Vista 32 bit Premium Home Edition; the laptop is on Windows XP. I was pleasantly surprised by how easy it was to quickly integrate the printer into this network.  The only big problem was that the CD that came with the printer was apparently corrupted; after going through the bulk of the software install process I got an error message telling me to "contact the vendor".  So, I did what I should have done in the first place and downloaded the software package from the HP 7510 support page.<br /><br />I also downloaded the user's manual pdf file at the same time.  I would suggest you do this as well, and read it prior to installing your printer.  There is information pertaining to the printer installation and network setup that is not in the skimpy printed little paper manual that comes packaged with the printer.  And, as discussed in a previous paragraph, there was the very important tip about the importance of using the setup cartridges that came with the printer.<br /><br />Once I had the software downloaded to the main PC, I ran the .exe file and everything worked great.  I turned the printer on and went to the Wireless menu.  The menu screen showed my home network's name; I selected it.  When prompted I input the security code for that network.  A few menu clicks later lo and behold, the printer was connected to the network.  I've powered the PC, router and printer off and on several times over the past few days; in all instances the printer has effortlessly re-connected to the network.<br /><br />Getting the laptop in the other room to recognize the 7510was easy as well. I copied the downloaded software onto a thumb drive and plugged the drive into the laptop.  Ran the file, followed the prompts and the laptop was also connected to the printer.<br /><br />Anyway, my experiences with the printer thus far have been very positive.  Hopefully the above hints will help you as well.;;5.0;;March 7, 2012;;23;;23;;1.0

ROKPXH289C1TS;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A2OPDDPM098FBB;;Printer;;B001F4WGJS;;Lexmark E260D Mono Laser Printer;;A fine printer - that does print Envelopes on a Mac!;;I had a Lexmark E232 for 6 or so years and it was a great, reliable printer for my modest home office needs. The first time I tried an envelope ... argh! ... exactly as other users have said, the print was off the side of the envelope. Looking further around now that I had the issue, there seemed to be no solution posted on the internet.  I was worried.  BUT ... I contacted Lexmark support and, within a few minutes they had a solution.  And the solution, seemingly for the first time on the internet is:<br /><br />In the print dialogue, from the menu that initially reads 'Layout', select 'Paper Feed'.  From the menu that appears, change 'Auto Select' to 'Manual Envelope'.  And that's it.<br /><br />Now, Lexmark has had 2 years to fix their paper 'Auto Select' which seems to fail to 'auto' select Envelope when the page size is set to Envelope ... but still - their support was excellent and the printer is a bargain for what you get. You can directly email a scanned document to someone without having to save it to your computer 5. The ink was cheap.<br />I do not print too much but this month my kids had some homework and I had some work that I brought home and so I must have printed about 50 pages a week for about 3 weeks.<br />I do not use it to fax or for photo printing. At Best Buy there was a Lexmark rep. who sold me on this printer and so instead of a cheap $70 Lexmark all-in-one I ended up buying this printer.<br />Installation: It was a breeze to install and get it up and running. I have it running on Windows XP, Windows 7 and Mac OS 10.6.5 ( I run Win XP on the MAC with Fusion 2.x and now under Fusion 3.x the printer works with both).<br />Experience :<br />Everything was fine the first week. It scanned, the paper feed works, worked wirelessly (woke up from sleep and printed etc etc. I was happy as a lark). After the first week, the print head went bad and I had to physically clean it to print properly again. Customer /Tech support promised to send me a replacement within less than a week. Guess what it did not arrive and when I called they just promised to replace the printer instead as the printhead kit was on back order. (But they did not proactively let me know that, I had to follow up on it). Ok so I get the replacement printer and voila what a pleasant surprise. They shipped me the Lexmark Platinum Pro 905 and informed me to keep that instead and send the Lexmark 901 back to them. Now I was really happy that they did this and the printer arrived on time!!<br />Guess what, within less than a week the printhead went bad. This time it could not even be cleaned !! I chatted again with Tech Support (now Lexmark really has neat tech support. They remotely logged into my computer and ran a scan and took a copy of my printhead and saw how it was damaged). They said it was a known issues that the printheads heat up excessively causing the ink to stick. They said the entire batch/few batches were bad batches and they would ship me a new printhead from a batch where the known quality issues had been fixed !!<br />That was a surprise. Apparently Lexmark has not bothered to do a recall or let the customers know about this issue but have instead let the customers experience this problem and then call them to get the issue fixed.<br />So once again I am out of a printer and this time I cannot even print as the printer gave an error that the printhead was bad and would not let me print (but would scan). Of course Tech Support once again promises to ship me a replacement printhead within 1-2 business days. Of course once again it does not arrive and I have to follow up and they said how about we send you a new printer instead. Boy I said this is Groundhog Day!! I have been through this and no please do not ship me a new printer as this will not solve my problem as I am pretty sure the printhead in the new printer will also be bad. Why not just ship me a new printhead kit where the quality issues have been fixed. So they say ok, but will take 2-3 weeks before this can be done. I am frustrated as hell, but said ok, I will wait (its the holidays and I do not have any urgent printing to do).<br />Now as luck would have it, Lexmark had also shipped me a replacement printhead and luckily it just arrived so I replace the printhead and I am able to print once again. But guess what, this time it would not print RED. It would print all the other colors but not RED. Instead of RED it would substitute Yellow. Boy was I mad. I had replied to a survey that Lexmark had where I mentioned that it would be good if some one were to call me and followup on the issues I was having with my printer.<br />They were very prompt about it and sure called me at the appointed time and walked me through the issue and asked me to replace the RED ink with the ink sent with the new printhead kit (remember I was still awaiting the replacement kit from the most recent printhead on the new printer gone bad and they had simultaneously shipped me a replacement kit for my original Lexmark 901 printer). So luckily I had the spare ink and voila the printer works fine now. So this time I had a bad RED ink.<br />So at this time it is now over 30 days and I cannot return my printer.<br />I do like this printer do not get me wrong. I just want it to work like my Pixma did without any issues. But my life seems consumed by the number of issues.<br />Granted it may be bad luck on my part that I had to have so many issues with Lexmark products all in one shot. I am willing to work with Lexmark and they have been good about support and I do not have complaints other than they do not proactively tell you if a shipment will be delayed or not.<br />I am still awaiting a replacement printhead kit ( and I hope I get it on time or the current printhead does not die on me like the previous ones have).<br />So if any of you are considering buying this printer be aware of the issues the Lexmark printers have with the Printheads because if I had some urgent printing to be done I would have gone berserk. I am patient, but there is a limit.<br />Lexmark should be more open and issue a recall on the printers or printhead and send replacement kits to all who own printers having a printhead from known bad batches of printheads.  I am sure they should be able to track these, after all I have registered my printer with them.<br />If this printer continues to operate without further issues then I will revise my rating.<br />But for this main issue I would have rated this printer with 5 stars, but I simply cannot do that given the circumstances. Maybe its a comedy of errors with my printer and my experience is just unique. I am willing to give Lexmark a chance and hopefully this time the printhead will last over 5 years. What's good about a 5 year warranty if you constantly have issues with the product.<br />P.S. I have not isolated this issue but at times it does not auto print double sided. I have not been able to get the printer to be stable enough to spend time to figure out why this happens or under what circumstances. It is random  and rare for me at the moment.<br /><br />Update Jan 15, 2011:<br />My kids have been heavily using this printer for the last 2 weeks and we have not had any issues at all with this printer since Lexmark replaced my last printhead. So I feel comfortable to overlook the initial issues with the printheads (can happen to any manufacturer) more so given the follow up that Lexmark has done both via phone and email (was truly pleasantly surprised by their genuine concern for customer satisfaction). One does not get that kind of support from other companies. By the way the replacement printhead came as promised and the printer has been very stable. You do need to ensure your firmware and drivers are updated as Lexmark has issued both updates in Dec 2010 and Jan 2011 (which I applied in Jan 2011).<br />I have revised my rating to 4 stars and if this printer holds up will revise to 5 stars in the near future.<br />Based on my most recent experiences and proactive followup by Lexmark, I would not have any hesitation recommending this printer to anyone for their home office needs.;;4.0;;December 17, 2010;;11;;12;;0.916667

R1O0YXCZKBS5PE;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A2AS53M18HDFYL;;Printer;;B00439GOL8;;Brother HL4150CDN Color Laser Printer with Duplex and Networking;;Fast printer. Duplex very handy. This is especially useful, since the printer will automatically print on both sides of the paper should you want it to, saving a lot of paper. Others have said that the color reproduction is not great. To clarify these statements, I would say that the color is not great for professional photographers or those who require precise color printing. Despite this, the color printing quality should not be a problem for everyday prints, such as school/work reports, personal projects, etc.<br /><br />I have noticed 2 drawbacks:<br />1. The printer was bulkier and heavier than I expected. Make sure you check the printer's dimensions/weight to make sure you know what you're getting.<br />2. The printer is somewhat loud when printing, but quickly dies down after it is done printing.<br /><br />Some useful hidden features:<br />---------------------------------<br />TO RESET TONER LEVELS:<br />1. open front cover<br />2. press the CANCEL and SECURE buttons together at the same time<br />3. use the +/- buttons to navigate the toner color menu<br />4. press OK to reset the selected item<br /><br />TO RESET DURABLE PARTS LIFE (drum, belt, etc.)<br />1. open front cover<br />2. press the GO and + buttons together at the same time<br />3. use the +/- buttons to navigate the menu<br />4. press OK to reset the selected item;;4.0;;April 2, 2012;;17;;17;;1.0
RIU9RH1WH0JTW;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A3NXGOYB8DYX9O;;Printer;;B002ONCDH4;;Brother HL-3070CW Compact Digital Color Printer with Wireless Networking;;Brother HL-3070CW works well, great value [NEEDED REPAIR];;** THIS MACHINE NEEDED REPAIR 2 MONTHS AFTER PURCHASE, SEE UPDATE BELOW **<br /><br />Introduction / History:<br /><br />I already own a Brother MFC-7820N black-and-white multifunction networked laser, which has worked very well for 4 years, with only one change of the toner & drum unit needed in that time. Our occasional color needs were met with an old HP inkjet, or a late night trip to Kinkos, and I print  several hundred color photos a year at Ritz Camera.<br /><br />Now we need color printing more often, so I read the reviews and bought the HL-3070CW, which is a color laser printer only (not multi-function), with 802.11 b/g WiFi connectivity.  THIS PRINTER IS NOT DESIGNED TO PRINT GREAT PHOTOS. You can print pictures for grade school projects on regular paper. For anything higher quality, look elsewhere. For nice looking office documents, this printer is for you.<br /><br />Review<br /><br />At $199 including a starter toner kit, this printer is an unbeatable value.<br /><br />I ordered on a Thursday with Amazon Prime free shipping, and the printer arrived the following Monday, which I thought was excellent performance on the delivery.<br /><br />The size of the box was my first clue that I should have read about the dimensions more carefully.<br /><br />This unit weighs 41 lb and is about 20% larger (my guesstimate) than the MFC-7820N. The best location is a large office table, it would not fit on the 18" deep wire rack in my "IT Closet." The quick-start guide also mentioned that once located and set up, the unit should not be moved, so I had think through the setup up front.  Eventually I went to Home Depot, had a sheet of plywood cut to 20" x 20", and placed it on the wire rack with a few L-brackets pointing down in the right place to prevent it sliding around. Then I set the printer on top of the plywood, and all was well. This took me a couple of hours and if you have the right space for setup you won't need that time.<br /><br />Once the space thing was figured out, the actual installation, using a Windows 7 laptop, was straightforward and took about 20 - 30 minutes. To answer all the Setup Wizard's questions about the WiFi network in your house, you may need to log into your WiFi router, so make sure you know to do that before you start this setup. No need for that if you are going to use wired ethernet only.<br /><br />After the initial setup, I did not use the included disk for the other computers (iMacs and Mac Airs, running OSX 10.6x. Instead I went to the Brother web site and downloaded the latest OSX drivers. I'm not a very proficient Mac user, so it took a while to get some of these done correctly, but bottom line it was not very difficult and worked flawlessly on Mac Air.<br /><br />One problem: on iMac the latest driver downloaded and installed correctly, but every time we tried printing from the iMAC we got a dialog box that the printer was paused, and to click [some button] to resume printing. After about 10 times unsuccessfully trying, I deleted and reinstalled the driver on the iMac, after which it behaved normally.<br /><br />Since setup this printer has worked flawlessly. After checking a couple of sample prints I decided to buy some better (24 lb) paper for the color printer. It looks good. Both the Brothers will, occasionally, not wake up and print a new job. The quickest way around that is to power cycle or otherwise restart your WiFi network or, sometimes, the printer. This does not happen often enough to be an annoyance.<br /><br />UPDATE, NOVEMBER 16 2011<br /><br />After 2 months with no problems, the Printer started flashing the error message<br />PRINT UNABLE 29. I considered return the unit to Amazon and buy another,<br />however the cost had already gone up from $199 to $229. Also, if this is a design<br />or component failure problem affecting a large batch of machines, the replacement<br />could also have the same issue. Repair would probably be a better option.<br /><br />So I called customer service, and identified the authorized dealer, which is Roberts<br />Business Machines, about 10 miles away in San Jose CA. I took the machine over<br />there. They are a small outfit, very responsive and easy to deal with. The technician<br />initially told me that according to his manual, any one of 3 circuit boards could have<br />failed and that he needed to order all 3 for the repair. Two days later he called to let<br />me know that the factory had instead instructed him to replace it with a new machine.<br /><br />When the new machine arrived I went over there. The box was opened in front<br />of me. Since this was a replacement machine it arrived without the starter<br />toner kit etc. My original toner kits were transferred over. Initially upon startup<br />there were some unexpected lines on the test page, so he cleaned my toner<br />cartridges, after which everything looked normal. I brought the machine<br />back home and repeated the WiFi setup process, and it's been working OK since,<br />about a week now.<br /><br />All things considered although the failure was an unpleasant surprise and I<br />expected the worst at that time, the whole repair experience was quite smooth,<br />though it did cost about 2 weeks' down-time, which was not a problem for me<br /><br />UPDATE APRIL 2012 "Printer Offline" problem and solution<br /><br />This printer developed a new problem - refused to wake up from sleep.<br />When sending a new print job to it, Mac OS reported "printer offline" and<br />Windows XP reported a similar error message after a few minutes. To make<br />the job print I needed to physically turn the power switch off and then back on.<br />I re-installed the Mac OSX 6 driver a few times, with no improvement. So I took<br />the machine back to Roberts Business Appliances.<br /><br />After a day or two the service tech called to inform me that the problem<br />was not reproducible in his shop, it worked fine with both wired and<br />wireless ethernet. After talking to him I learned that he'd manually logged<br />into the printer and changed the network settings to AUTO-SWITCHING<br />and WiFi Communication mode as INFRASTRUCTURE. Unfortunately he'd<br />not recorded what those had been set to during the automatic CD<br />installation but bottom line is, with these settings he saw no problem.<br /><br />I have written down below how to get at and change those and other settings.<br /><br />When I brought the printer home, the wired interface worked fine but<br />the wireless interface was completely non-operational, even after I<br />used the CD automated setup. Clearly, whatever they had changed<br />over at Roberts was not being restored by the CD.<br /><br />Since I had some time on my hands (and did pay for the WiFi interface !)<br />I did some troubleshooting on the WiFi interface and eventually got<br />everything working again.<br /><br />1. Most important: learn how to log into the printer and directly<br />  set up the network configuration the way you want it.<br /><br />  To log into the printer, type its IP address into your browser<br />  window, for example 192.108.1.104, and the browser will<br />  take you to the printer's home page.<br /><br />  How do you find your printer's IP address ? If it's a fixed IP<br />  address, I guess you'll know what that is. Mine is a dynamic<br />  IP address, assigned by the router using DHCP, here's one<br />  way to check it and all of the printer's network configuration<br /><br />  -> At the router front panel, press the "down arrow" button<br />  -> the menu will show "Machine Info"<br />  -> Press the "OK" button<br />  -> Menu will show "Print Settings"<br />  -> Press the "down arrow button again:<br />  -> Menu will show "PrintNet Settings"<br />  -> Press the "OK" button<br />  -> The printer will print 2 sheets of paper<br />  -> "IP Address" is written down near the top<br />  -> Also printed is the status of the wired & wireless interfaces<br /><br />  What if the wireless is not working at all, as happened to me<br />  after I brought the printer home from Roberts ? Simplest thing<br />  is to attach a wired interface from your router to the printer,<br />  wait a few minutes, and then go through the above steps.<br /><br />  (I did not wait long enough: initially the address was 0.0.0.0)<br /><br />  If necessary, you can also use the front panel keys to<br />  manually enter IP address and subnet mask. I did not.<br /><br />OK, now that you've figured out the IP address, log into the<br />printer home page. You now have access to all kinds of<br />useful stuff. For now, click on "Network Configuration"<br /><br />You should see two tabs for "WIRED" and "WIRELESS," one<br />of which shows as "Active" and the other "Inactive."<br /><br />2. The wireless network setting defaults may need to be<br />  changed from what the automated startup CD does.<br /><br />  A few important ones:<br /><br />  - NETWORK CONFIGURATION -> CONFIGURE INTERFACE<br />  option needs to be set to "Auto Switching," so it will<br />  automatically detect and switch between wired and<br />  wireless ethernet<br /><br />  - CONFIGURE WIRELESS - these settings may need to change<br />  depending on your particular WiFi setup at home. I have a<br />  cable modem, connected to a Linksys E3000 router. So my<br />  settings are as follows...<br /><br />  COMMUNICATION MODE set to "INFRASTRUCTURE," meaning<br />  using a WiFi router or access point, not "AD-HOC"  where<br />  your PC directly communicates to the printer, using a WiFi<br />  USB or similar dongle.<br /><br />  Per the technician at Roberts, he has run into the "printer<br />  offline problem before and in all cases was able to fix it<br />  by setting "Auto Switch" and the "Communication mode"<br />  as described above.  He did that to my printer also but<br />  unfortunately did not record the previous state of those<br />  settings the way they were left by the automated CD install.<br /><br />  For the remainder of the settings below... in my case these<br />  had all been originally done correctly with the automated<br />  CD installation, but after bringing the printer back home<br />  the automated CD install did not work any more, meaning<br />  no WiFi access at all until I logged into the printer and set<br />  everything correctly, manually:<br /><br />  SSID name = your home wireless name, eg "Linksys-JohnDoe"<br /><br />  Authentication Method: security must be set to whatever your<br />  home WiFi router is set up for.  In my case,  WPA/WPA2-PSK<br />  and for this option you MUST ensure that you highlight and<br />  CLEAR the hidden contents if any in the WEP Key 1 - 4 fields.<br /><br />  Passphrase = whatever you set up for your home router.<br /><br />After you go through the above (and don't forget hit the "Submit"<br />button), remove the ethernet wire and the WiFi should start working.<br /><br />To confirm you can go through the steps to print the "Network<br />Settings" pages again, it should tell you "Link OK" and other<br />information about the WiFi interface.<br /><br />** Don't forget that the wired and Wireless Interfaces will have<br />different IP adresses. If you want to log back into the printer,<br />check the new IP address on the printout. **;;5.0;;September 30, 2011;;5;;5;;1.0

(I typically print a lot of academic, text-focused articles. Graphic-heavy works might use toner more quickly.) Printer speed is great, and even pretty decent using the 2-sided mode.<br /><br />At this point, my only complaint is that the manual feed 'slot' isn't a 'tray'--thus requiring a bit of attention when using. Regardless, I can recommend this printer for home or small-office users who want fast, black and white printing.<br /><br />----------<br /><br />I recently purchased this printer to make printing over my home network easier. Functionally, the printer warms up quickly, text is clear, and it comes installed with some nice fonts one doesn't normally find standard in Windows, such as CG Omega and Univers.<br /><br />Network setup and installation were easy, you do need to have your own ethernet cable, but you just plug it into your hub, then install software from the supplied CD. I had no problems with installing on 98-SE or XP-SP2 (although the XP computer I had to pay attention during installation to make sure the firewall settings were opened for the print spooler).<br /><br />I haven't had the printer long enough to speak on toner life, but we'll see.<br /><br />Two things keep me from giving this printer a perfect review:<br />1) The images of the printer (on HP's site as well as Amazon) make the printer appear to be the same color scheme as the newer HP PC's, the cool silver and gray-blue. I was looking forward to the more futuristic color scheme.<br /><br />2) When I received mine, the HP logo decal was missing from the front of the printer. The empty space for the logo is a bit annoying. I spoke with HP about this and the service rep was very friendly, but they couldn't send me a replacement logo. My only options were to exchange the printer (at no cost), or live with it.<br /><br />Overall it's a great printer, and the phone service I've received has been courteous. The not-so-cool color scheme and logo fluke aside, I highly recommed it. But spending $500 for a home printer, I expected better attention to details.;;4.0;;November 24, 2004;;23;;23;;1.0

For those not in the know, duplex scanning is where the scanner automatically scans both sides of the paper at the same time. Therefore, all you have to do is stick in a stack of papers in the document feeder and hit go! This is an uncommon feature for multi-function devices in this price range.<br /><br />Lastly, Brother makes very reliable products. I can get the printer function to work fine over the network using Windows 8's built in discovery utility but cannot get the machine to scan over LAN. The only option I have for that particular computer if I want to use print AND scan is to connect via a USB cable. R17KXI620ATUFQ;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A2KAOIY8M4D044;;Printer;;B001J8D856;;Lexmark X543DN Mfp Color Laser 21/21 Ppm P/c/s Duplex;;Lexmark Color Laser with scanner/copier (X543DN);;The features included fast printing, full color, automatic double sided printing (w/o fax option). It will work as a network printer, too.  It was clearly designed to work with Windows, but it is also sold as Mac OS compatible, and the User Manual walks you though set-up steps with Windows or Mac OS at the same time. It is thorough.  Thank goodness it's in HTML format, too.<br /><br />I'm a long time HP printer user (30+ years) and I wary of other brands.  But, I haven't had a good experience with HP over the years - they just don't keep their printers drivers up to date (at least, not for Mac or Unix systems).<br /><br />Mac users won't have any problems with this printer, and the Mac installer is included. The printer driver did not include a double sided printing option. You have to be working from one of the Microsoft Office applications, to notice a third line of options called "Copies & Pages" > "Printer Features".  Opening up that list provides all the printer functions like printing form the options sheet feeder (envelope) and you can turn on double sided printing (from the"Layout: menu), if you look carefully enough. You can also choose binding on the long or short side, too.<br /><br />My first mistake was that I assumed the envelope in the single sheet option feeder would give it priority to the main paper bin (as it does on HP printers).<br /><br />While I am impressed that this printer worked right out of the box (no set-up required).  I followed the instructions to the letter, installing the "software" before plugging in the printer.  But, it might as well be using the Generic Postscript driver - nothing special about the driver.<br /><br />While unpacking, it took me about 15 minutes to follow all the colored tape to pull about a dozen plastic shipping pins.  Not real hard, but I was still surprised at how many of those pins where installed.  It is easy to snap off the plastic pins, so use care when removing them.<br /><br />I was not impressed with "pinch and lift" access to the toner drawer - it sticks.  But, I do like the small square toner cartridges, which fit snugly in their respective slots. Each toner box is keyed, so you can mix up the colors.<br /><br />The print quality is excellent.  Finally, I'm printing off web pages that look just like they do on my monitor.  No calibration needed.  That's impressive.  Color copies and photos look great, as well.  If you were used to printing color photos off in B&W on a monotone laser printer, you'll find the color version more interesting.<br /><br />The manual also neglects to point out the importance of using high quality, polished paper for laser printers (probably because HP sells so much of it).  Good paper is really important for sharpness and brightness.  When you print to a bond or cotton stock paper, it will look fuzzy, because of the paper texture.  The printer has an option for gloss, but I haven't tested that with a photo.<br /><br />It copies great, speed is good once it warms up, but warm-up can take 20-30 seconds.  Once it's running, it does good.  I printed out a 40 page PowerPoint file that had heavy black frames.  It often took 30-50 seconds to render a page, but others came out steady.  On a Mac, the PDF rendering is done in software, not through a chip in the printer.  So, some of the delay was no doubt, on the computer end.  However, my Mac Pro has a lot of CPU power and RAM to match.<br /><br />Scanner?  - I haven't found any Lexmark installed Scanner applications, but I was able to choose the scanner from the "Import" function in Adobe PhotoShop and Preview, but not from iPhoto.  It works, but it's a bit awkward.  HP's software takes you directly into a suite of applications that help you edit the picture and print to photo paper of any size, and the have all kinds of printing options like masks.<br /><br />I don't like the rather small, vertical output tray in the back and because of that feature, I did not order the extra paper bin.  You can't expect to stack up much output, before you will need to clear the tray.  40-50 pages, max.<br /><br />The sheet feeder worked perfectly.  If you fax or copy multiple documents, this is a powerful feature.<br /><br />The control panel layout is well done.  The set-up menus are a little awkward to use, but fortunately, you won't have to use the tiny character panel very often (2 rows of 16 characters).  It reminds me of setting the clock on my VCR.<br /><br />The confusion didn't begin until I wanted to order a new set of cartridges.<br /><br />First, they are hard to find in stores.  I checked in every store that sold office supplies and Lexmark printers.  But, even ordering them on-line was difficult.<br /><br />Here on Amazon, they don't have the cartridge listed in their printer cross-reference tool.  (great tool, otherwise, but apparently, it's incomplete).<br /><br />On Lexmark's web site, it doesn't take long to find cartridges, but then you start to think you are getting cross-eyed.  They seem to have cartridges with different amounts of toner (ink) in them!?  Oh, no.  Is this like the way HP was selling Photosmart inks cartridges that weren't full?  I hope not.  When I see a toner or ink cartridge, I expect that it's a full one, otherwise, its impossible to compare prices!<br /><br />So, not only are the toners hard to find, but you need to be very careful that you are comparing the toner capacities and price.<br /><br />The "High Yield Toner" was pre-installed - they do not have a replacement part number on them!?<br /><br />For example, they list:<br /><br />C540X1_G Toner for Extra High yield  (C544 and X544 only)  -$130<br />C540H1_G Toner for High yield  (C540,C543,C544,X543,X544 printers) - $72<br />C540A1_G Toner  (C540,C543,C544,X543,X544 printers) - $58<br />C540X2_G Toner for Extra High yield  (C544 and X544 only)<br />C540H2_G Toner for High yield  (C540,C543,C544,X543,X544 printers)<br /><br />I bought these for regular Toner refills:<br />C540A1CG  Cyan  (Blue) - $58<br />C540A1MG  Magenta (Red)  - $58<br />C540A1YG  Yellow  - $58<br />C540A1KG  Black  (slightly bigger) - $78<br /><br />(*These are NOT Amazon prices - they are current prices for comparison purposes only)<br /><br />Bottom-line, double check before you shop for replacement toner.  This is a very confusing product, in that respect.  Lexmark pushes recycling and the boxes have labels to return the toners.<br /><br />My over all impression is that I really love it.  The copy functions are simple and familiar symbols or labels.  Software (printer drivers) are easy to update - I hope they will!<br /><br />This design is a little bit outdated, but for the price, it's a great way to get into an affordable color laser printer, that is clean, simple, and intuitive.  The only interactive display is a tiny 10 letter display (most new printers have an LCD).  The user manual is in HTML format, so find the menu map and print it out.  You can get there through that tiny front panel, but it takes a lot of time and a little patients.  (I hope it has a Factor Reset option, if I ever mess this up...)<br /><br />Overall, I think this is a very affordable color printer. And, a full set of replacement toner cartridges (a set of 4 can run $3-450) almost costs as much as the original printer.  So, you may not want to stock up on new toner - just plan to buy a new printer.  Seriously!<br /><br />But, don't worry about the printer functions - it's laser sharp.  The ink is durable, but it will smear if you get the paper wet.  It won't survive a coffee spill.<br /><br />Pros:  Solid color laser printer; accurate scanner with sheet feeder, copier functions. Mac drivers.<br />Cons:  Toner is hard to find, confusing/deceptive; no single sheet over-ride; no scanner app.<br /><br />Note: I did not test this printer with Windows.<br /><br />Since I wrote this review, I have upgraded from Mac OS 10.6 (Snow Leopard) to 10.7 (Lion).  A lot changed - the scanner function now is found on the printer driver (click on the printer in "Printers" or from the icon on the dock).  The SCAN function is at the top of the usual PRINT window.  Regardless, the scanner function is unreliable - it frequently just quits responding with no error messages.  I have to cycle power on the printer to get it scanning again.<br /><br />Second MAJOR disappointment.  It will not print double sided without jamming.  When I use the single sheet feeder (letterhead or envelopes), it ALWAYS jams and the paper never comes out of the printer.  Something is badly misaligned or designed wrong.<br /><br />FYI:  An office I work in just about the X544 (this year's model of the same thing) and it failed even worse.  Sheet feeder will not work.  They sent it back and opted for an HP that cost twice as much.<br /><br />My high rating (4 stars) reflects the value of the printer.  It's a great printer for single sided work and medium capacity office printing.  Just don't expect the other features to work (i.e. single sheet, envelope or double sided printing).<br /><br />Also, it has developed a squeeky roller wheel after running about two cases of paper through it over 2 years.<br /><br />GOOD Value, just not as feature rich as it would appear.;;4.0;;March 15, 2010;;31;;33;;0.939394

R37IJMDCHTNVQ1;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A2DW1OHHBVS3XH;;Printer;;B004JQPEBQ;;Kodak ESP C310 All-In-One Printer;;Amazing print quality, low cost ink, great all in one printer;;This is for you if: you want a high-quality (document & photo) printer/scanner/copier with WiFi and low ink replacement costs.<br /><br />The Kodak ESP C310 is an amazing all in one printer. Wireless connectivity allows you to print without needing to be connected via a wire. The printer produces exceptional quality photos as well as crisp and clear documents. The scanner/copier are well-above average. The user interface is simple and intuitive despite being full of features. And finally, the ink is very affordable. What more could you want?<br /><br />More details:<br />Although this is an all-in-one, there is no fax. To me, that's not at all a negative, but if you're looking for a fax this is not for you.<br /><br />The wireless feature is one of those "how did I ever live without this" features. I can sit at my desk and print a document, or I can be all the way across the house and print something and know it will be there waiting when I go to get it. One printer is enough for the whole family -- everyone can access from their own computer.<br /><br />When I think of multifunction printers, I tend to think of a device that can do everything pretty well. This, however, does everything incredibly well. I have printed countless numbers of photos that are at least as high-quality as professionally printed photos. 4x6, 8x10, wallets... everything comes out bright, crisp, clear, and the ink dries immediately so no worries about smearing on your fingers. They've even added the ability to print photos in 3D (which is nice, but mostly just fun to play with for me). The included software also allows you to edit and adjust your photos if you are not using some other photo editing software. The tools are basic but do include most of the simple adjustments you might make. There is a card reader, which makes it nice if you want to print directly from a memory card. You can preview the photos on the LCD screen and select just the ones you want to print.<br /><br />Document quality is exceptional and the print speed is quite fast. Scanning produces clear, high-quality images. There is no document feeder so you do have to lift the lid each time, but the included software makes it easy to quickly scan multiple pages into the same file.<br /><br />The printer also has some nice features you'd expect on higher-priced models. For example, you can print from a set of "printable forms" directly from the printer, without even turning on a computer. No more going to buy a whole pack of graph paper when you need one sheet -- just print your own!  Also, if you start printing a letter-sized document but have forgotten and left 4x6 photo paper in the printer, it will detect this and alert you before wasting your photo paper.<br /><br />The ink is also great. It uses Kodak's new 30-series ink (Kodak Black 30b Ink Cartridge - Retail (8345217) and Kodak Color 30c/Xl Ink Cartridge - Retail (1341080)) It dries instantly, even on those brightly colored photos that used to take forever to dry. It's long lasting and inexpensive, leading to a very low cost per page (the best way to measure ink cost).<br /><br />Overall: exceptional printer, amazing quality, low cost ink.;;5.0;;August 19, 2011;;38;;42;;0.904762

And I've printed fewer than 100 4 x 6 photos!  This thing really does hog up ink even if you mostly print black and white text.  I called Canon Support and they told me that the printer uses the color ink to make a composite black.  Why would they do that?  There are two black ink cartridges in this printer.  I assumed one was for text and one was for photos.  According to Canon Support you can change the printer settings to not use the color ink to make black.  I encourage you to call and complain that these aren't the default settings and ask them how to set your printer up to print using the black ink for black and white pages!!!  And beware that your print quality may not be good based on their instructions.  They won't tell you that you have to play with the "custom" settings to set the print quality to a higher quality.  Even at the higher quality setting, they text is not the dark black you get from the composite black that uses up so much ink. Ink cartridges are expensive? So the heck what. If you google "250ml refill ink for MG3120" you will find a 4 pack of 250ml bottles, one of each color. WITH instructions, a thumb drill, and 4 injection needles. The directions are straight to the point. My roommate has had his printer here which we share for about a week. Printed off 40+ 4x6" photos and even though the cartridge warning light says it's out of ink, it was still printing. I refilled the cartridges with the ND Brand refill ink from the 250ml bottles and there is NO GRADE LOSS of photo quality. the 4x250ml refill pack is $28.99 Free ship on ebay LOL. I'm estimating about 30-40 refills of each color and double of that for black.<br /><br />Ok so now that we got the expensive/non-expensive ink issue outta the way...On to number....<br /><br />2) Full automatic duplex printing. One word "FANTASTIC" it jammed once the first time we tried it, it pulled 3 pages in at once slightly offset from each one...That brings me to number...<br /><br />3) If your paper gets jammed in the barrel, it's so freaking EASY to unjam the printer. On the back of the printer there is a extremely simple way to open the barrel and pull the paper jam out. It hasn't jammed up again at all.<br /><br />4) Wireless setup, if you follow the directions to the letter, it's simple. If you try to put more than one of these on the same network, you MIGHT have a little bit of an issue if you use the same computer with software installed that you used on the first one. Simple resolution: Uninstall the software, reboot, reinstall :P<br /><br />5) Speed? Faster than most other inkjet printers out there, in my opinion. Definitely faster than Laser printers LOL unless you have a high grade super expensive one :P<br /><br />6) Photo quality, simply as good as sending your photos to walgreens or walmart if not better.<br /><br />7) Haven't had a chance to use the scanner system yet. and the on-device menu has "code" so you have to understand what the codes are, which I don't yet.<br /><br />NOTE: Printer head alignment, don't we HATE having to eyeball which number or letter looks the most solid and do it 2 or 3 times to align the print heads? NOT ANYMORE. What you do is press the "maintenance" button a few times til you see a lowercase "u" then press the color or black go button. it prints an alignment sheet. Take that and place it on the scanner bed as it shows. Hit the go button again, and the printer aligns the heads automatically. Never seen anything like it.<br /><br />Right now we have 2 of these on our home network, and to be honest: Using the ink refills some may be negative about, We don't have a problem with it at all and if it keeps going that way, we'll continue to use it. Even if color laser printers came down in price, I don't think I'd go for one. 5 stars, 2 thumbs up, by far the best printer I've ever had. RWM4YB5QKJOY5;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A2TL7CT7QWYR9R;;Printer;;B003YL412U;;Canon PIXMA MG6120 Wireless Inkjet Photo All-in-One Printer (4503B002);;not perfect, but decent;;We use this printer for copying, printing, and scanning.<br /><br />Copying: The copy quality is great, but be aware that for a standard 8 1/2" x 11" piece of paper, the copier cuts off 1/4" of the copied image/text on the right side and 3/16" of an inch on the left side. Obviously, this is quite irksome. To solve this, you have to decrease the magnification to around 95%, and then figure out exactly where to place the paper on the copy bed so that the left side isn't cut off. OR, I suppose you can decrease the magnification further, but I didn't feel like wasting more paper to figure it out.<br /><br />Printing: Very happy with the quality. No complaints. Both Black and Color printing are good.<br /><br />Scanning: Honestly, disappointed. I scan handmade cards, and on several, the image has been kind of blurry. I don't know if I need to adjust settings or if that's just the way it does it. I miss my old $50 Memorex scanner.<br /><br />INK: This seems to use ink VERY quickly. We don't print color very much and already the color tanks are low (although the color-black and the yellow aren't as low). One interesting thing is that the main-black cartridge indicator has said that it's been empty for several days, although we've been able to print without changing it. We're waiting for the printer to refuse to print before we change it.<br /><br />Bottom line, it's not a bad copier/printer/scanner and it works well enough for our needs, but the drawbacks listed above are a disappointment.;;3.0;;April 14, 2011;;10;;10;;1.0

RZ2NZ8Q8B5CFD;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A775ZXPWCX9R8;;Printer;;B000UZH526;;HP LaserJet P1006 Printer;;P1006 envelope solution;;This printer is cheap in both price and quality, but it works OK for the most part.  We were having problems printing envelopes from MS Word (Tools-Letters and Mailings-Envelopes and Labels)  We kept getting an error message telling us to load the envelope in the manual feed tray and then hit the OK or GO button.  The envelope was loaded, but there wasn't an OK or GO button.  When you hit the button on the top of the machine, the red error light stops blinking, but it also cancels the print job.  The only other button is the power button and that just shuts the machine off.<br /><br />There is another review about setting the printer up to print envelops before sending the print job, but that didn't work either.  Here is what to do.<br /><br />Since there is no OK or GO button to press, after the job is sent and you get the error message about loading an envelope in the manual feed tray, just open and close the top of the printer.  This resets the machine and it accepts the envelope job and the envelope will print.<br /><br />It took us a while to figure this out - that opening the lid and closing it is this machine's "GO" button.  Hope this helps somebody else.;;3.0;;September 24, 2008;;24;;25;;0.96
R3NSJQU2G3EFLR;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A11NXTW8HFC3E0;;Printer;;B000B61X1S;;HP Deskjet 460c Mobile Printer (C8150A#A2L);;Don't buy this printer!!;;This printer is billed as being a portable printer, with the option of wireless connection. That's what I wanted - a wireless mobile printer. I know I should have checked further and found the other models with all the capabilities. But I didn't. This "moblile printer" has to be plugged in to 115 V, because it has no battery. (Batteries are extra, or are included with an upgraded model.) It also doesn't come with a wireless adapter card - Bluetooth or Wi-Fi. (Wireless adapters are extra, or are included with an upgraded model.) So, this "mobile printer" has to be plugged in to the wall and to your computer. That doesn't make it very mobile. In fact there are great ink jets for 1/2 the price that are available if you want to plug in cables. The CF slot on this printer is Type I, which is not noted anywhere on Amazon. The industry standard Wireless G cards are Type II, so they don't fit. Only the special HP Wireless G card is Type I, but even that isn't noted anywhere on Amazon. Buy the HP 460wf (wi-fi) or the HP460wbt (Bluetooth) instead. They include a battery and a wireless card. By the way, the printer itself is very good. But I hate the way it is being marketed!;;3.0;;November 9, 2006;;88;;100;;0.88
RC8JT2S49AGS2;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A1Q9TOICNOFZQS;;Printer;;B0010Z1W06;;Brother HL-2140 Laser Printer;;Great for students!;;UPDATE: Windows 7  now downloads the full Brother driver so it gives you Device Stage, toner-save, curl reduction, etc (as of 2011).<br /><br />Entering my senior year of college with two senior projects, there was obviously going to be a lot of printing to do.  My inkjet printer worked okay, but it tended to run out of black ink really quickly.  Plus, the printer didn't support the high-capacity cartridge that my parents' higher-end printer used, so I was buying 2-3 black cartridges a year.  They went on my Christmas list, for heaven's sake!<br /><br />Enter Brother HL-2140.  I found it for a decent price (not here at the time, the going price seems to shift like sand w/rebates and all).  I calculated my inkjet was costing me 10c/pp while this unit (with high capacity toner) would cost a mere 1.2c/pp.  It spins up in about 10 seconds, page curl is noticeable but tolerable.  Print resolution is very good (and no ink smears).  I have not experienced the problem of feeding pages that just printed back through for duplexing and having them jam as some people have.  I just feed back through and it works fine.<br /><br />The footprint is small for a laser--one of the smallest I've seen (but not the absolute smallest).  It did emit a "pine tree" smell for the first few prints, but that's gone away.<br /><br />This printer plugs in and works without an install CD with Windows 7 x86 and x64.  However, Windows 7 will not install the most functional driver.  It will work just fine, but there will be no options for tonersave, duplexing and the like.  Get the driver from Brother.  Oh, and the driver (both) are Device Stage capable.  Works fine as a shared USB printer over a network (even with hacked DD-WRT routers acting as wireless bridges).  Note that the printer itself does NOT have network capabilities--it has to be plugged into a PC.<br /><br />Nagging Complaints: Does not come with a USB cable (I knew this in advance but it reminds me of toys or accessories that need batteries, but come without them).  There is no way (that I know of) to view the exact toner level without using "Print Settings" in the control panel (and thus using more toner).;;5.0;;October 15, 2009;;5;;5;;1.0

R37UZ6XH50IPQS;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A2RU4U1JZ3DMP5;;Printer;;B004IZN3RK;;Epson Stylus Photo R3000 Wireless Wide-Format Color Inkjet Printer (C11CA86201);;THE perfect photo printer for serious amateur photographers.;;At school I've been using an Epson Stylus Pro 3880 and have gotten kind of addicted to printing my photos. The R3000 is half the cost and almost exactly the same except for it's narrower 13" maximum print width (vs the 17" 3880). Both use the "UltraChrome K3 with Vivid Magenta" ink set which is the same one used by almost all of Epson's "Pro" line of printers. Honestly, I don't know why the R3000 isn't in their "Pro" line since it could reasonably be used by a pro who never needed to print anything wider than 13".<br /><br />I printed some color test charts at the Sam's Club photo lab (which should be reasonable quality since they actually calibrate their printers at least once a day and when they change paper rolls) and on my R3000, then compared them to an actual X-Rite produced ColorChecker chart, and the output from the R3000 significantly beats the output from Sam's Fuji Frontier minilab photo printer. The Fuji Frontier print is noticeably duller with generally darker colors and a narrower range of saturated color reproduction. You don't have to be a color expert to see the difference.<br /><br />For the R3000 the ink cost is about $1/ml which comes out to about $0.01 per square inch if you get it at a discount (search for "red river Cost of Inkjet Printing Epson R3000"). That makes a borderless 8x10 cost about $0.80 in ink, and a borderless 8.5x11" cost about $1 in ink. A sheet of Epson Ultra Premium Photo paper costs as little as $0.60 if you get it at a discount, so printing a borderless 8.5x11" ends up costing as little as $1.60 in supplies. (Not to mention that you can get third-party paper that's just as good or better than Epson's official paper for less money.)<br /><br />The cheapest photo labs charge around $1.50 for an 8x10 (my local Sam's Club currently charges $1.46). If we use a whole 8.5x11 sheet of official paper and a full 8x10 worth of ink to print an 8x10, we get $1.40 in supplies per 8x10 which is slightly cheaper than even Sam's Club and significantly higher quality. Good third-party paper would be around $0.35/sheet meaning that you could also do as well as $1.15 per 8x10, maybe even better.<br /><br />Admittedly though that doesn't incorporate the cost of the printer, which you won't have to incur if you just use a photo lab. If you bought the printer for say $800 and you've gotten your per-8x10 supply costs down to $1.15, then you'd need to print about 2,580 8x10's before your total costs started to get lower than Sam's Club's $1.46.<br /><br />When you get larger than 8x10 though then the printer really starts to pay off. One place online that isn't too expensive and has a good reputation charges $6.30 for a 12x18 on glossy photo paper printed with a photographic lab process. It's possible to get decent 13x19" gloss ink jet photo paper (same stuff that costs $0.35/sheet for the 8.5x11) for about $1.50/sheet. 12x18" of ink costs you $2.16 so total cost for a 12x18 on the R3000 with that paper is $3.66. At that price you need to print 300 or so of these large prints before your prints start costing less than $6.30, and again the ink jet prints will have better color quality than the photographic process printer. You also have the entire lifetime of the printer to make all these prints that we're talking about. If you make on average about 10 8x10" prints every week then it would take about 5 years to make this cost back, but if you made two of the 12x18" prints per week then it would take about 2.8 years to brake even compared to the lower quality protographic process prints ordered online.<br /><br />But none of these estimates take into account the value of the convenience and additional quality you get from having a modern photo inkjet printer right in front of you. Add in costs like transportation to pick up photos, time spent driving, any sort of cost of inconvenience by having to wait for prints to arrive in the mail, the additional value of better color quality, and other hard to quantify things then the real savings may be better. Depending on how much these costs add to the cost of photo lab prints, a decent ink jet printer like this might pay for itself much more quickly.<br /><br />Still, you have to keep in mind that owning your own printer like this only makes sense if you're going to be doing a certain volume of printing. If you only ever print maybe 10 8x10s a month then the printer will never be worth it solely from a cost-per-print savings perspective. Also, if all you ever print is 4x6 then even just your ink cost without paper is going to be around 2.5x the cost of getting 4x6 prints made ata cheap online lab or drug store. So for small prints like 4x6 the printer will absolutely never pay for itself from the supply perspective, and probably not even from the convenience perspective.<br /><br />The only problems I've heard of with this printer seem to involve priming the print head (pumping ink into the initially empty hoses that run from the ink cartridges to the print head, basically) and the printer going through unnecessary cleaning cycles, but Epson support is great about addressing these. My R3000 went though an unnecessary priming cycle when I first set it up, wasting about half the ink in the cartridges. Support got back to me in less than a day and offered to send me a full set of full replacement cartridges. I haven't seen anyone complaining of clogged nozzles or any of the usual inkjet problems.<br /><br />The color gamut of the R3000 when used with the Ultra Premium Photo paper significantly exceeds the AdobeRGB colorspace in areas of dark blues and greens. This allows you to make the most of your camera's sensor capabilities IF you convert your RAW files into a format using the ProPhoto RGB color space (the most common one that actually holds those colors) AND print to the printer using proper color management with the appropriate ICC profile. Photo labs almost always require all files to be encoded as sRGB (which is smaller than both AdobeRGB and ProPhoto RGB), and printers like the Fuji Frontier have smaller gamuts than sRGB anyway, so they can't possibly achieve the wide range of colors that a high quality professional inkjet can when it's wielded by someone with sufficient color management skill.<br /><br />Anyway, excellent printer, reasonable cost of ownership and operation, higher quality printing than you get at a photo lab, convenience, and excellent support from Epson. When you consider this part of your "digital darkroom" and compare its cost to the cost of materials and equipment you'd spend for an "old fashioned" film darkroom, the cost is quite reasonable.;;5.0;;December 2, 2011;;70;;70;;1.0
R319KRVWO0JULI;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A1IHT22I290TR7;;Printer;;B004HO58VQ;;Canon Pixma iX6520 Inkjet Printer (4895B002);;Great Buy;;I am amazed at the quality and the overall operation of this printer, from installation to printing, it is a breeze. Fortunately, the MX870 allows me to minimalize my compromises.<br /><br />First off the price is unbeatable for the feature set. A comprable HP will cost at least twice the MSRP for this unit.<br /><br />I like the way the printer looks. This is a big improvement from the permanently open bays of the HP C7280.<br /><br />Printing is a breeze. Very quiet, fast, and great quality. I was a bit worried about a drop off from the HP, since it is touted as a "photo" printer. Setting up my Canon on the home wireless network was a breeze. The Canon software is not even close to being as massive and bloatware-heavy as the HP software that never seems to get off of your computer.<br /><br />However, this leads me to my only gripe about this unit: NO OCR SOFTWARE! Come on, Canon, why did you stop with the OCR? Scanning a document to Word is a very useful function and one that the HP handles easily. However, for some reason Canon does not support it.<br /><br />In conclusion I am very happy with this unit. For half the price, you get twice the printer compared to the HP C7280. I can live with the OCR issue, as it is not a deal-breaker for me. This is my first Canon printer in a long time and I am impressed and thankful that there is a good value alternative to HP.<br /><br />EDIT: Have used this product for almost 2 months now and I still stand by my review.<br /><br />5/17/2012 UPDATE: Had this printer for over a year now and I still stand by my review.;;4.0;;February 21, 2011;;6;;6;;1.0

R1UX4I4N8TZXL7;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/AU3ITV9CGFWCC;;Printer;;B005PP7SI2;;Brother MFC-J430W Inkjet All-in-One MFCJ430W;;cheap printer and cheap ink, works well;;The only complain I have is the software on the CD. R3KN5YMRC531B8;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/AEOCEVUWO5B7P;;Printer;;B005O55U4C;;HP Officejet Pro 8600 Premium e-All-in-One Wireless Color Printer with Scanner, Copier & Fax;;Compares very favorably to Epson Workforce printers;;I was on the hunt for a couple of new all-in-one printers that could work in a mixed Mac/PC environment and wanted to get machines that were fairly well built and had relatively low print costs.  I did not plan on even considering another HP printer since the last HP I had deployed had a number of problems, most of them related to extremely bad Windows drivers and print software.<br />I was strongly leaning towards the Epson 845 Workforce printer, but I thought it made sense to do a comparison with the HP since it also seemed to have all of the features that I needed.  After doing a head to head evaluation between the Epson and the HP 8600 I ended up going with two of the 8600 units.<br /><br />My criteria was that I needed well built all-in-ones that had relatively low operating costs, worked well with Macs and PCs as well as iDevices, had to have good fax and scan capabilities and, very importantly, had to be pretty well built so that in a busy dental practice the unit would not fail prematurely.<br />I did a direct "bake off" in which I purchased an Epson Workforce 845, and an HP 8600 and ran both of them through their paces.<br /><br />In the end I chose the HP 8600 over the Epson Workforce printer.<br />Why?<br /><br />The biggest detriment to the Epson Workforce printer is that it is relatively cheaply built.  It has flimsy paper trays that don't feel particularly solid.  The entire printer actually weighs about 50% of what the HP 8600 weighs.  While `weight' is not a direct indicator of product quality, on something like a printer, which gets a lot of mechanical use of the paper trays and ADF, a more solid feeling, heavier unit, should usually hold up a bit better to normal wear and tear.<br /><br />In other comparisons I observed that the Epson had better draft quality, but the HP was much faster, and seemed to use less ink when it was used in the economy/draft mode.  In Photo printing, neither printer was outstanding, but both would meet our needs for printing casual snapshots or business type photo materials on glossy 4X6 print paper.<br /><br />The single biggest `deal killer' for me with the Epson 845 is that Epson has very lackluster Mac drivers, and their `network scan to PC' software does not currently work with Macs newer than OS X 10.5, which is going on 3 years old.  Epson's inability to update this software (they claimed a new version was in testing) left me with an extreme lack of confidence that if we discovered problems with the Mac OS X software or drivers, that Epson would be prompt with fixing the issue.<br /><br />We also liked the touch-screen on the HP 8600 much better (although sometimes it's a little too sensitive) than on the Epson, as it was larger and could be angled easily.  A final advantage of the 8600 was the included e-print capabilities, such as the ability to set the printer up with its own free HP email print address, so that people can simply send an email directly to the printer with an attachment and have it print emails, pdf files, word documents, etc.  We were also able to easily set the HP up to archive faxes to a network share, as well as creating a "one touch" scan option where the office can scan documents directly to a network share, which is really handy for archiving documents as well as when a receptionist scans something in but someone else on another PC will need to look at the document later.<br /><br />Another plus to the 8600 that's worth mentioning is that ink tanks are loaded directly into the front of the unit.  Simply open up the front service door, and the tanks are ready to be changed.  This beats having to open up the whole printer (as is the case with the Epson and Canon units) and another, added bonus, is that the HP ink tanks are sealed until they are installed into the unit, meaning no smeared or dripped ink from popping off tabs and other parts on the cartridges when you are getting ready to put them in.<br /><br />What's not to like about the 8600?  Not a whole lot, but there are some nits.  If I fax directly from the machine, using my Ooma phone service, I can dial a *99- which dials *99 to disable the Ooma features, followed by a pause, and faxing works.  However, dialing the same way with the print to fax feature on my Mac, does not work, I suspect a problem with the print drivers for OS X.  Fortunately I don't do a ton of print-to-fax jobs, so it's not a deal killer.<br /><br />I do not like how deep the 8600 is with the output paper tray extended for regular size paper.  It's deep enough that in the office location I put it in I am nervous that one of the employees could come around the corner and smack into the paper output tray, possibly breaking it eventually.  I should also point out that the ADF slide adjusters have a little bit of a gap so if you are persistent it is possible to accidentally insert the paper UNDER the ADF feeder, I have also observed that the way this printer feeds documents in to the ADF tends to pull the paper in and crease it, resulting in crooked scans, so it's important to make sure that the ADF guides are snug against the paper you are loading for scan.  This is the first printer I have owned in years that has had this kind of a problem, but since I have two of these and they both work this way I know it's not a defect, but a design issue.<br /><br />Other than that, I don't have too many complaints.  The ink tanks seem to last a really really long time and they are relatively inexpensive when bought in bulk at our local warehouse store.  The costs so far appear to be roughly half of what we were spending on toner for our Brother color laser printer, so the printer will pay for itself in just a few months.<br />All in all we are quite happy with these.  It's worth noting that I bought one HP 8600 Plus and one Premium.  I wanted to add the second paper tray to the 8600 Plus and discovered that I could actually order it from Provantage for about $59 shipped, it's too bad Amazon doesn't sell this part.;;4.0;;February 8, 2012;;8;;9;;0.888889

It's cheaper than most of the inkjets that I was looking at before it (don't buy an inkjet!)<br />-Extremely economical. The cheapo included "starter cartridge" lasted me my entire freshmen year. I printed over 1200 pages with it.<br />-Replacement toner is dirt cheap! I bought the "Brother TN360 High Yield Black Toner Cartridge" for $44 (about what you'd pay for the average inkjet set of cartridges) and just swapped it last week (Over a year later).<br />-Energy Star Approved. Need I say more? (all you cheapo college kids without electric bills might not appreciate this until you start renting an apartment!)<br /><br />Reliability 5/5 stars.<br />-I've had 1 (one) jam. That's it. 1 single jam in over a year of use, and it was while I was trying to print on an envelope (see point below in Cons).<br /><br />Print Speed 5/5 stars.<br />-Relatively fast printing. For $60, this printer is more than fast enough for even my lengthiest reports. It's not a business workhorse like the HP P4014's on campus, but then again it's about $550 cheaper.<br /><br />Ease of Setup 5/5 stars.<br />-Setup takes less than 5 minutes:<br />  -Take it out of the box<br />  -Pull the safety tape off of the tray and toner.<br />  -Insert toner and paper.<br />  -Plug it in.<br />-The printer is the PERFECT SIZE. It's almost perfectly square, so it stacks well. It's not heavy. It easily fits right on my desk without getting in the way.<br /><br />Ease of Use 5/5 stars.<br />-Windows 7 found and installed it automagically (including the correct printer thumbnail).<br />-Ubuntu 10.04 Desktop found it right away.<br />-Toner Saver Mode (which is an ABSOLUTE MUST), was very simple to turn on.<br /><br />The Cons:<br /><br />Features 4/5 stars.<br />-First of all, know that I didn't dock the star because of the lack of color (that would be unfair since this is CLEARLY a monochrome printer).<br />-It doesn't print color. Big deal, 99/100 college reports and documents have 0 pages that need to be printed in color. Why waste money on expensive color ink if 50% is used on those stupid color advertisements in the page margins? I'll run to the library if I need to print 1 or 2 pages in color. Plus, for the family type, why do you need to print in color? If you're not printing out Birthday Cards or Cheesy Certificates, I'd save the money and just print in B&W.<br />-Printing on envelopes using the dedicated slot is a pain. I've tried multiple times and never had a good experience, or awesome results. This printer loves 8.5 x 11.<br /><br />Noise 4/5 stars.<br />-When in use, it's a tiny bit noisy; however, all laserjets are.<br />-At idle, this thing is silent, and power-up time out of stand-by is fantastic.<br /><br />Overall:<br /><br />This is THE BEST investment I've made in my college career. It's cheapy cheapy, extremely reliable, relatively fast, so-easy-to-setup-that-a-caveman-could-do-it, the perfect size, and OS friendly. Yes, the lack of color might bother some (it doesn't bother me), just ask yourself "why should I print in color?" And it's a little bit noisy (meaning that staying up till 4AM printing out sources for your research paper might irritate your roommate (if you have one)). Do either of those matter even the slightest in the grand-scheme-of-things? No. At least not in my opinion.<br /><br />Do yourself a favor and buy this printer.;;5.0;;August 17, 2010;;10;;10;;1.0
R2B2FFKPGX9EOA;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A3N7AQGZV4YBRI;;Printer;;B004ULP9QA;;Brother Printer DCP7065DN Monochrome Laser Multi-Function Copier;;Can't believe there aren't more reviews for this printer!;;As the title suggests, I cannot believe there aren't more reviews for this printer, good or bad.<br /><br />I've been drinking the HP coolaid for many many years now.  I don't print much to be honest with you, but always thought that a color printer was something everybody should have in the home.  I've owned about 4 HP multi-function printers over the years, and my last one was the worst in respect to ink.  Not only were there 6 cartridges, but even printing in Black yielded a drop in the color inks!  Due the infrequent usage of the printer, my inks would also "expire" so that I had to replace them.  All this coupled with the fact that when I did buy new ink, most of the time the cartridges (which were small in the first place), only came half full!<br /><br />OK, so you didn't come here to read about my issues with HP, although I think most people can empathize!<br /><br />So, in looking for another printer, I looked for the following:<br /><br /> - Scanner<br /> - Printer (Laser)<br /> - Networked (Wireless or Hardwired)<br /> - Reasonable Price (under $300)<br /> - Not an HP!<br /><br />What I got in the main, exceeded my expectations.  Granted I only got this today, but from unpacking to printing the first page, was an absolute breeze.  It's a lot smaller and lighter than I was expecting but quite a bit taller than my HP all-in-one.<br /><br />I have multiple Windows machines (no Mac or Linux to test with right now) on my network, and each one picked up the printer during driver install first time.  I downloaded the drivers directly from Brother so I had the latest ones, and I also ensured that after everything was running, I updated the firmware of the printer too.  All this was done with ease.<br /><br />The print quality is as you would expect from a laser printer, very clean and sharp.  I especially like the duplex feature which allows printing on both sides.  I even tried the multiple pages on one (4 to 1 in this instance with duplex), and it downsized the PDF file whilst keeping it still pretty readable.  The warm up from sleep to print was pretty quick.  I would say less than 10 seconds.<br /><br />The build quality is pretty good.  It's not as solid as an Enterprise type laser printer, but what do you expect for $179!?  I was a little worried about the scan cover only lifting 45 degrees (as mentioned in the first review), but it lifts way more than that (probably about 65 degrees), plus it has a vertical lift on the hinges so you can scan thick books etc. which is nice.  I do agree with the other review, the spring loaded lid is brutal, so you need to be careful when lifting the lid, otherwise you could damage the hinges.<br /><br />However, with that said, the scanning feature is not quite as nice as the HP one.  I need to play with it a bit more, but there doesn't appear to be a preview feature, and if you scan multiple pictures it doesn't allow you create multiple files (because there is no preview feature).<br /><br />All-in-all though, with the fact that you get a starter cartridge that will last quite a while (with no expiry!), this printer is an absolute bargain for $170.  Given I would have had to replace my HP cartridges anyway, which would have been $70, you can understand why this is, in the long run, a very cost effective printer.  With high yield toner cartridges that print about 2500 pages for $50, I can't see me ever going back to an Inkjet.<br /><br />In conclusion, don't be put off by the Brother brand and their relative obscurity compared to HP, they've been around for a long time.<br /><br />I'm dinging the product 1 star because of the lack of preview and multi-image in the scanning software, and the spring loaded lid.  I'm hoping there is an alternative/remedy to this.  But for that, it would be five stars.<br /><br />Pros<br /> - Great printer, especially with duplex, and n to 1 printing<br /> - Fast print speed and nice quality<br /> - Scan and copy multiple documents using the auto feeder<br /> - Long lasting, non expiring toner cartridge (700 pages from the free one!)<br /> - Enclosed paper tray with pretty good capacity (250 sheets)<br /> - No large output tray sitting on the side of printer, output is almost enclosed in the middle of the printer<br /> - Not an HP! :)<br /><br />Cons<br /> - Scanner software doesn't have preview or the ability produce multiple images at once (that I can tell)<br /> - Brutal spring loaded scan cover<br /> - Not color (but wasn't a requirement for me anyway)<br /> - No wireless (again not a big deal, but might be for some)<br /><br />UPDATE (08/07/2011):  I've found the preview feature!  As I'm a bit of a computer geek, I generally switch software to "Advanced Mode" to gain more control over it.  It seems this mode doesn't show you previews which is a bit odd.  However, by selecting "Home Mode", the preview is there.  Granted the multi-image scan is still not there, but it's still an improvement.  FYI, the mode can be found under Configuration > Mode Select.<br /><br />UPDATE (04/04/2012):  So, just to let people know that I've had the printer for about 7 months, and just today, after printing 311 pages with the STARTER toner cartridge (with Toner Save OFF) that ships free with the unit, I got my first warning that the toner was low.  Almost certainly if I had still had my HP printer, I would have gone through at least 2 or 3 of the colors, and the other ones would have probably expired and needed replacing, costing me about $10+ per cartridge.  I am still incredibly happy with the print quality and the print options.  It's still lacking the killer option of multiple separate photo scans in a single pass, but frankly I've not had a lot of photos to scan in recent months, so do not miss it currently!  Lastly, with the price drop to $129 (which it had been down to recently), it's even more of a bargain than it was when I bought it.;;4.0;;July 15, 2011;;104;;105;;0.990476

If you want to receive faxes in a format the device can print, you must purchase a 'premium' service from eFax. Short of that, neither HP nor eFax will support you when you indicate that the device does not print inbound faxes.
