R21YCLSA7YGKMK;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A255MXZ2359C3Y;;Printer;;B001F0RI1I;;HP CP2025DN Color LaserJet Printer;;Excellent photo print quality for a color laser;;Any color laser will do the job if color accuracy and tonal range aren't important, as when you're printing simple color charts, and all you need is solid blocks of recognizably different colors.  Photos are a different story, however.<br /><br />A color laser is never going to give you the sort of lab-quality prints you expect from a high quality injket photo printer matched with the right paper.  However, it can come close enough when simply "very nice looking" is all you need, and you want the results faster and cheaper.  For example, a real estate brochure or something similar.<br /><br />Unfortunately, not all color laser printers are up to "good enough" when it comes to photos.  I owned a Xerox 6110n, for example, which did a terrible job with the subtle color ranges in flesh tones.  As a result, faces looked flat and cartoonish, completely unacceptable.  I'm pleased to say the HP CP2025dn is much, much better.  I doubt you'll get better color reproduction with any other color laser printer.<br /><br />It has two paper trays, which means you can stick envelopes in the multi-purpose tray and ordinary paper in the built-in tray, and you won't need to change back and forth as I did with printers with just a single tray.  There have been some rumors to the effect that early copies of this printer had problems feeding from tray #2 when there was anything in the multi-purpose tray, but I had no such difficulty.<br /><br />Setup was rather easier than my previous network printer.  I didn't have to set up a fixed IP address and re-direct a fake USB port to that address; the installation program found the printer without difficulty.<br /><br />It's fairly compact, unlike many color lasers.  Amazon gives the box dimensions, but the printer itself is actually 15.5" wide x 18" deep x 12.5" tall.  You'll need a little in back for the cables and up top for the paper output, but it fits easily in my somewhat small under-desk printer stand.<br /><br />The toner cartridges are in a fairly simple tray system, and you can access all four of them (cyan, yellow, magenta, and black) at once.  When the time comes, replacing any of them will be trivial.<br /><br />Automatic double-sided printing is pretty nice.  You have to select it in "printer properties" before OKing a print job, but the option is easy to find once open the properties dialog.  I printed my tax returns for my records this way, and cut the amount of space they take in my file folder in half.<br /><br />I did a fair amount of research before deciding on this as a replacement for the Xerox 6110n, and ruled out some cheaper color lasers on issues of reliability and print quality.  Since my HP 4L is still running without trouble after 17 years, I have high expectations for the reliability of this printer.<br /><br /> - Gus;;5.0;;March 11, 2010;;8;;9;;0.888889
R6J9OVZWRZBJ9;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/AR6GC8Z40HL0D;;Printer;;B0010Z1W06;;Brother HL-2140 Laser Printer;;Great printer, Great Price;;I picked this printer up for $69.00 with free 2-day shipping from Amazon shortly after realizing how much it was costing me to print B&W pages on my HP all-in-one printer. I'd guess that my ink costs are now about 10 to 15% of what they used to be. Print, Copy, Scan, Fax functions all work well.<br />- Toner-low shut-down hassle of previous models is now solved with a menu setting<br />- Warranty: 1 year<br /><br />CONs:<br /><br /> - Noise: Fan noise for several minutes; chunk-a-clunk noise while printing. (average $20 more)<br /><br /> - Non-duplex version (MFC-7360N) (low tide around $100)<br /><br />- - - Pricing - - -<br /><br />Price is very bouncy. Low tide is around $138. Amazing deal. There's an "Online Price Alert" that will email you whenever this or any amazon product dips below your target price. Google it. It's nicely done. Or try camelcamelcamel.<br /><br />- - - Tips - - -<br /><br />  - Toner refill powder such as TN-450 Toner Refill with Reset Flag Gear & Lever by AAAtoner or Laser Tek Toner Refill Kit 4 Pack for Brother TN-450 reduces cost even further.<br /><br />- - - Notes - - -<br /><br />Note 1: Cost per page (Toner + Drum) can be...<br /><br /> - 2.3 cents -- Brother toner and drum replacements at average amazon price<br /> - 1.9 cents -- Brother toner and drum replacements at lowest price and extended usage; (3,000 copies per cartridge, 15,000 per drum -- reduced quality at tail end)<br /> - 0.8 cents -- Use toner refill powder at lowest price and extended usage.<br /><br />Brother Toner TN-450 is $42.50-47.00, 2600 pages. Brother DR-420 drum is $ 69-74, 12,000 pages. When replacing the gougy-priced drum, it's sometimes cheaper to buy an entire HL-2230 or HL-2240 printer on sale for $70 or less (includes DR-420 drum and a 700 page starter cartridge).<br /><br />Toner refill powder: $8-12 (assume 3000 copies -- average 0.30 cents per copy). Starter cartridge requires Flag Gear Kit, about $3-6 (one time).<br /><br />Printer comes with drum and 700 page starter toner. Subtracting the value of these, the hardware itself costs about $57 ($138-69-12)<br /><br />Save more ink (and paper) by shrink-printing (2 to1) when appropriate.<br />.<br /><br />Note 2: Standby energy: My old Brother MFC-7820N pulled 7.3 watts on standby. That's $35 to $105 over 5-years (24x365x5 @ 11 to 33 cents per kilowatt hour). This MFC-7460DN draws 1.2 watts on standby ($6 to $18 over 5 years). R296ELPPXXOZI9;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A2W9I628I6SE1U;;Printer;;B005GOPXRA;;Canon PIXMA MG6220 Wireless Inkjet Photo All-In-One Printer (5292B002);;Very Nice Progression from the MG5220;;I own and am very happy with the Canon PIXMA MG5220 so when the opportunity to test and review the latest version of the scanner/copier/printer presented itself, I jumped at the chance. Where it matters, there isn't much of a difference between the MG6220 and the MG5220. In my book, that's a good thing. The MG5220 is already an amazing home printer so I'm glad Cannon didn't mess too much with a proven formula. The print options, wireless capability, print quality and basic layout are pretty much the same. I'm running OSX 10.5.8 and have had no real issues setting it up and using this peripheral. It took about 45 minutes from the un-boxing, through the calibration, to after the drivers installed before it was up and running. Responsiveness seems to be improved, and functionality is as good or better than the previous model. The new centralized layout and incorporated buttons are nice, but don't really give much more of an advantage over the old configuration. It is an aesthetic improvement though, if that matters to you.<br /><br />The number of inks, removable media slots, paper handling, and the location of the paper drawers and scan bed are more or less in line with the previous model, so there are no surprises for MG5220 users. I had the opportunity test an Epson Artisan 730 alongside the MG6220. Both printers are very similar when it comes to functionality and target market, but there are a few things that set them apart. The Canon has a photo black an extra grey ink for richer black and white prints. But place two color prints side by side and they look much the same. If you want to print a lot of B&W images, then the Canon should be your choice. Set-up and use was a bit easier (for me) with the Canon, and the Epson is a heavier and larger printer, though not by much.  Both also function comparably as scanners and copiers. I've yet to test the Canon's HD movie clip or CD/DVD printing aspect, but it is nice to have that capability.<br /><br />If you want a compact printer/scanner/copier that is easy to use and has great features and image quality, then I would not hesitate to recommend the MG6220. If you are a satisfied MG5220 owner and have worn out your old printer, then this upgrade should be a no-brainer.<br /><br />~ Kort;;5.0;;October 9, 2011;;134;;152;;0.881579

RP3BEIVT50T8F;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A27CZFO2UDHDYS;;Printer;;B005IVL0RS;;Epson WorkForce 845 Wireless All-in-One Color Inkjet Printer, Copier, Scanner, Fax, iOS/Tablet/Smartphone/AirPrint Compatible (C11CB92201);;Programmed to Die at 20,000 pages;;IMPORTANT PLEASE READ THIS PEOPLE!<br /><br />After a few months of using this printer in the household, I started receiving error messages about my waste inkpad reaching the end of its service life.  Finally, I couldn't exit the menu and all it does now is flash its buttons everywhere. The waste ink pad is where the ink that is used for non-printing tasks, such as ink head cleaning and borderless printing, is placed -- into an absorbent rag or sponge that holds the ink.  Regardless of how often you do borderless printing or cleaning your print heads, the printer is programmed to die once you've printed 20,000 pages.<br /><br />That's bad enough for an office "workforce" printer, but what's more is that I really don't think I printed 20,000 pages.  I mean, this is just a household printer.  Sure, members of the family print from this for maps, articles and schoolwork, but we're not printing 200-page business books or anything.  I can guess that the little counter built in the printer is inaccurate.<br /><br />The scanner will not work either when this happens.  Fax too.  Good luck removing your cartridges too.<br /><br />Customer service acknowledges that the printer self-destructs at 20,000 pages.  Just hope that you get to this death message before your 12 months of warranty are up.<br /><br />So if this is for the office DO NOT BUY IT.  If this is for a large family DO NOT BUY.  If it is for you and one or two people, it will be ok for a few years, until you reach that self-destruct limit.  If you think you'll never print 20,000 pages, be my guest and buy this.<br /><br />Furthermore, the stuff you probably already know:<br />PROS:<br />Fast printing, good color and photo printing, good text quality, large paper capacity, excellent scanner, doesn't jam much<br /><br />CONS:<br />Print head jams quite often (making streaks in your prints), uses a lot of ink, ink is expensive, macintosh cannot use both paper trays, send-email function cannot print double sided or with both paper trays and is limited to 10mb files.<br /><br />If it didn't have a self-destruct mechanism, I would give it 2-3 stars.<br /><br />The fact is that all these positive Amazon reviews are subject to a bias -- they perhaps have not had the printer as long as I've had it or have not printed 20,000 pages and do not know that the printer will terminate itself in the next few months/years.  Trust me, if any of these 5 star reviewers (who are the reason I bought this in the first place) encounter the same "problem" I've encountered, they wouldn't be giving this 5 stars.  However, by the time their printer dies no one will care about this old model of printer anymore.<br /><br />IF YOU ARE GOING TO PRINT A LOT, DO NOT BUY THIS PRINTER<br /><br />If you don't believe me, Google it.  The semi-good news is that there is a reset utility, but you must provide your printer serial number which will void any warranty.  The bad news is that it's a pain and not worth it, because it only extends your printer life by a ~hundred pages before you have to do it again.<br /><br />UPDATE:  Epson has given me a new 845 workforce, citing that my life duty cycle ended before the 20,000 pages for some reason (as I suspect the internal counter was inaccurate).  All I had to do was wait for the replacement printer and then ship the broken printer in the same box with the included FedEx label.  But still, 20,000 page LIFE duty cycle??  That just means this new printer will die in a year or so.  Boo!;;1.0;;June 16, 2012;;129;;145;;0.889655

Vendors claim the best print longevity is when you use their papers and inks (for the latter paper, that's 25 years under glass, 100 years in storage).  Regardless, definitely use quality paper to get results worthy of this printer's abilities.<br /><br />Software installs and runs without issue on Windows XP. R2DQJB3J24KRBM;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A19X4H69MADIOK;;Printer;;B005O55TDO;;HP Officejet Pro 8600 e-All-in-On Wireless Color Printer with Scanner, Copier & Fax;;EXCELLENT PRINTER / LOUSY SOFTWARE;;I switched to HP when my Epson died after years of good service. The printer is excellent - great quality and features in a tough package. I love receiving my daily Motley Fool Newsletter from ePrint automatically. The scanner multipage feed and two-sided print is great. Installation of the hardware went according to the directions (with some guesses). The on-screen display and keyboard give me all the information needed with the WiFi connected indicator letting me know that it's ready.<br /><br />The reason for the 3 of 5 star rating is the problems with connectivity. I use the printer via WiFi for my desktop and laptop. Frequently and intermittently, I get an error message on the laptop that print did not work. Yet while that message is staring at me in two windows, the printout is coming out just fine. Also, sometimes the scan process works great and other times it does not work at all. In both cases, the desktop does not recognize that the printer or scanner is available. This cost me over 5 hours working with the HP Help Center, to no avail. Their multitude of diagnostic software identified issues, but resolved none of them. Many 'uninstall/reinstalls' did nothing. Sometimes everything works perfectly; other times not at all. Also, the problem appears to be only with my desktop. The printer functions perfectly with my laptop. HP Help Center tried saying that the problem is with my desktop. They were embarrassed when I told them that it is an HP Desktop while the working laptop is a Dell. Also, these problems do not go away after switching to Ethernet from WiFi. The main difference between the laptop and desktop is that the former is on the network via WiFi while the desktop is wired to the router. It would cost me money and performance to attach the desktop via WiFi (added card), but I am curious as to whether that is the issue.<br /><br />I really don't want to return the printer. It has all of the features and strength that I want; however, it is frustrating to not have function when you need it.<br /><br />HP needs to improve their software development! Clearly it is lacking in software quality control! Total connectivity via a home network is a complex process that HP has not yet conquered.<br /><br />UPDATE JANUARY 23, 2012:<br /><br />After over 5 hours with the HP Help Center, not arriving at a solution to the printing errors and scanning problems, I was ready to return the printer to HP. However, I persevered. The printing was perfect as long as I did not let the error messages bother me. The scanner was not functional. Then a few days ago, I came up with an idea. IPv6 has  been in the news lately due to the lack of internet addresses under IPv4. I wondered if my laptop and desktop were using the same IP versions. Sue enough, the laptop that did not have problems was using IPv4 and the desktop had IPv4 and IPv6 activated. So, I disabled IPv6. Ever since, the printing errors have disappeared and the scanning functions perfectly! YEAH!<br /><br />I am not ready to declare 'VICTORY' yet, but after a few days, everything is still good. So, I will raise the product rating from 3 to 4. Too bad that the HP Help Center and their diagnostic software could not have saved me so many hours of frustration.<br /><br />UPDATE JANUARY 27, 2012:<br /><br />VICTORY! VICTORY!<br /><br />Since implementing the solution of IPv4 above, I have not seen a single error message for print or scan. The device is working just great. At some point, after a long period of stability, I may test whether IPv6 alone works as well as IPv4 on a home IPv4 network. For now, I am enjoying the printer. I hope that you do not have to suffer my experience.;;4.0;;January 15, 2012;;43;;43;;1.0

R1ZGH6QGRQBKU7;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A3O3WZWEE64TKF;;Printer;;B0032AN4M6;;Canon PIXMA MX870 Wireless Office All-in-One Printer (4206B002);;Shockingly good device;;This is my third all-in-one since the category was introduced in the 1990's. The HP machines I've had were both slow and very noisy and the scanning software was buggy.  So I was generally dissatisfied with the HP equipment, but the issue that brought about the replacement was a clogged print head.  After several support calls with HP, I finally got to a technician who knew enough to conclude the print head was clogged and needed replacement.  When I asked for a referral to a repair facility, or the number for an HP repair depot, I was told "These machines are not designed to be repaired, they are designed to be replaced and recycled."  I asked to speak to a manager, and when he called back a day later I was told the same thing.  So I called the office of the CEO of HP in California, and was referred to another organization who said the same thing.  Then I called a local independent printer repair shop and was told "the print heads in the HP all-in-ones are not replaceable, and that I should consider buying a new machine. For want of a $0.10 print head, the entire device had to be scrapped.  Now Eco-friendly is that ?!?!?!?<br /><br />Since I was generally dissatisfied with the HP all-in-one's I had owned I decided to temper my brand bias and research the field and make an informed decision based on other user reviews.  This lead me to Epson and Canon.  The newer HP equivalent replacement model I tried at an Office Depot and it was as slow and noisy as my previous two HP machines.  While there, I looked at the Epson models, and while I liked their photo printing capability, I was more interested in low-duty-cycle printing and not having to scrap the machine when the ink dried out when I was traveling.  The Epson machine does not have a replaceable print head, and I had read a review here on Amazon that the Canon machine did have a replaceable print head.  So sight unseen, I ordered the Canon.<br /><br />The reviews are correct when they give high praise to the Canon Pixma line.  I have been delighted with the performance and it's significantly less noisy than all the others.  What really has impressed me is the scanning with the automatic document feeder - it's flawless.  The HP could never scan more than 3 pages with the ADF without the software crashing or the wireless connection faltering and creating errors.  With the Canon, it has worked like a dream and in less than an hour I've scanned in twenty years of income tax returns - something that would have taken a day to accomplish with the HP.<br /><br />Setup was easy and the wireless connection worked from the first try.  I've used the machine now to fax, scan, copy and print and I'm very satisfied.  During installation I discovered that the print head is indeed separate - you have to install it as part of the ink cartridge installation, and it's offered as a spare part that the user can easily replace.  Printing is about twice the speed as the HP machine I tried in the store that's in the same price bracket.<br /><br />I have not tried using this printer for photo finishing.  I have a high end Epson I use for that which handles 11x17 inch media.  My guess is the Epson is better for photos because it has more ink colors and they are generally known as the photo printing leader.  But the ink cartridges are more expensive to replace since there are more colors involved.<br /><br />I would also comment that the software for the Canon machine comes with the device and needs installation.  I'm using a Mac and support for the Epson and HP machines is part of Snow Leopard operating system.  But the software installation was easy and the Apple OS discovered that there was an update for it and downloaded it and installed it automatically without a hitch.  The only thing I would like to see added or improved would be an ability to fax directly from the computer (HP supports this, Epson and Canon don't).  But this is a minor issue compared with having a machine that in all daily use categories exceeded my expectations by a large margin.  It's still is astounding to me that such a useful and functional piece of equipment as this is under $200.  After this experience, my brand preference for inkjet office printers/scanners is now Canon.;;5.0;;May 10, 2010;;69;;69;;1.0

R4JKZ02JPC7XD;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A1JUBRIZMO0RJV;;Printer;;B005K95U88;;Brother Printer MFCJ425W Wireless Color Photo Printer with Scanner, Copier and Fax;;Pros & Cons - Not Bad;;While I love technology, I had been using a HP Deskjet 5150 for nine years.  The problem is for the past several years a supported Mac driver was no longer offered, so I had to use drivers for other printers that caused issues.  Thus, my decision to finally spring for a new printer.<br /><br />There was a lot to choose from.  However, this Brother MCF-J425W stood out as an exceptional value.  I also considered a professional Brother model that printed 11x17 sized images, but the footprint of the device and height was too tall for my desk area.  This unit, while still larger than some units, fit in my tight space.<br /><br />Motivation for purchase and Pros:<br /><br />1) The brother ink cartridges do not have the ink head nor a computer chip. This makes it possible for third parties to reproduce the cartridges at insanely low prices as seen on Amazon.  With other brands, you have to have remanufactured cartridges if you want to save money (essentially refilled).  These refilled cartridges quality varies dramatically and the results are usually not worth the hassle/savings.  Therefore, your price per print on Brother (which is easy to get good third party ink) can come out insanely low compared to say HP where you probably want to stick with OEM ink.<br /><br />2) Wireless features.  Yes, most printers in this category are wireless now.  It was easy to setup and I quickly downloaded and updated the firmware on the printer to utilize Apple's Air Print from my iPhone and iPad.  Works fine.  Wish you could change settings on the phone and iPad though.  I have no idea what setting it uses when you print from a phone or tablet?  Maybe "normal?"  The other major wireless feature is Brother's own free application from the app store that lets you print and more impressively scan documents right from the phone. Therefore, if you have the printer setup away from computers and whatnot, do all the scanning work right on your phone or iPad via the brother App!  Pretty cool, though I personally have limited use for that.<br /><br />3) Price.  With the instant savings that come and go, this product was cheap to say the least.<br /><br />Observations & Disappointments upon arrival and use:<br /><br /> 1) Print Speed - They quote numbers better than my 2003 HP printer, but it feels slower.  It will take 10-15 seconds just to start printing and if you want Normal with color, it's not too fast printing either.  I've found grayscale copies on "Normal" setting are acceptable speed, though not fast.  Grayscale copies on "High," is annoying slow, and on "Best," it's impossibly slow.<br /><br />2) Print Quality - This relates back to speed.  Don't even bother with "Fast/Draft," unless it's something you are going to throw away soon and were just proofing.  Fast/Draft documents are ugly on this machine, unlike my nine year old HP.  I don't even want to read a draft on it.  The letters are all pixelated and horrible looking on this fast setting.  I refuse to use the fast setting.  I think "Normal," is closer to what draft was on my HP.  I cannot tell a difference between "High," and "Best," for text, so on the most important report, paper, or business document I would use "High."  Less important day to day things, "Normal," will probably be ok.  Too bad that "high," will take so long.  Finally, there is suppose to be an "Ink save," feature that only outlines images when printing a fast/draft, but this setting seems unavailable on Mac.  This could be made clearer.<br /><br />3) Scanning.  Scanning works fine and if you're on OS X, the built in drivers or the ones you download from Apple.com work perfect.  I can scan right from the Mac without problem.<br /><br />4) Faxing is pretty straightforward though there are many advanced settings, so be careful.<br /><br />5) No duplexing.  More and more printers offer duplexing today.  I know this is an entry range wireless, but I would have really liked to have duplexing.  In the real world though, I guess I might not use duplexing that much even if I had it.<br /><br />6) Paper Tray - The paper tray must be nearly completely removed from the printer to add paper.  It holds just shy of 100 standard sheets of paper.  While it's not horrible to replace normal paper (100 sheets will last me a while), it's mind bogglingly frustrating to swap paper, envelopes, and photo paper.  It's just too involved, the paper tray is too clunky, to do a swap quickly.  I do print envelopes at least monthly, so I find this frustrating.<br /><br />7) Photo Printing - This is not something I had planned to do with the printer as for so many years I had not had much interest.  However, with the excitement of a new printer, I got out some old HP photo paper and got going!  Wow.  There is something about seeing your photographs on glossy photo paper. It's more satisfying than on the computer screen or uploaded to the HD television.  I printed several 4x6 and one 8 1/2 x 11 photo.  Wow. The 8 1/2 x 11 photo is impressive to me, just seeing a photo that size in hand. Now, the quality.  I can't say exactly. The quality is VERY GOOD.  I wouldn't call it perfect or striking, but very nice indeed.  I would love to compare the quality to other photo printers.  This might just peak a renewed interest in photo printing for me.  It's fun.  Now, photo printing is very slow too, but that doesn't bother me because we're talking about high resolution photographs and of course photos are slow.  The 4x6 in photo or best mode seemed fairly quick though.  The 8 1/2 x 11 in best mode took about ten minutes.  Again, this doesn't bother me.  Printing a two page black and white report that takes one minute bothers me.<br /><br />Overall, the feature set of the printer for the price makes it highly attractive.  The price of third party ink (used at your own risk) and wireless features are fantastic.<br /><br />The biggest drawback for me is the print speed.  It just feels slow especially the time between clicking print and the actual beginning to print.  The second drawback is the print quality.  You have to use a higher setting for acceptable quality compared to other printers, which slows the speed down even more.  The third major drawback is the paper tray.  It's a headache to use compared to my old HP that had most of the paper tray exposed, ready to adjust and swap stock.  The final drawback is lack of duplexing.  Recommended product, but realize its drawbacks and limitations before deciding.  The true rating should be around 3.5 stars.;;4.0;;May 17, 2012;;7;;7;;1.0

R8FZQ3P76HWK1;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/ABVYGB2TKBO8F;;Printer;;B004HO58UW;;Canon Pixma MX882 Wireless Office All-in-One Inkjet Printer (4894B002);;A step up from the MX860;;We've had a Canon MX860 for three years. It died and was too costly to fix. That multi-function printer served us very well for three years during which time we used it quite a lot due to home schooling, and running a ministry which required quite a bit of printing each week. We appreciated all the functions, especially the duplex printing which saved paper and made our handouts smaller and less bulky. We often used the feeder to make double sided copies. We just won't buy a printer that is missing the duplex feature. The printer worked like a charm for tens of thousands of copies with perhaps two or three paper jams over the entire three years. So when it died we were happy to seek out a similar printer from Canon.<br /><br />The MX870 would have been the closest match to the now obsolete MX860, but for just a few dollars more this MX882 had a few features we liked, such as higher resolution printing and scanning, and faster throughput. This MX882 looks almost identical to the MX860 except the old one was silver and this one is shiny black. It doesn't matter to us much because it is in a slide out drawer in a cabinet. But those who will have it out where it is exposed the black might be a fingerprint magnet.<br /><br />Strangely when connecting it to our home WiFi network it gave me two choices, Easy Setup or Other Setup. I tried Easy Setup which asked me to input the password; a bit tedious of a process. But the Easy Setup failed. So I tried the Other Setup which used the automatic feature of my wireless router and it worked quickly and easily. Turns out the Other Setup was easier than the Easy Setup.<br /><br />I found the operation of the MX860 to be slightly easier to use than the new MX882 but they are very similar so this is no big deal. To me there is just a little confusion over the addition of the new Dual Function Panel, and the absence of the 2-sided button.<br /><br />We don't print photos often which it turns out is one of the great strengths of this printer. I loaded the Canon print app on my iPod Touch. It immediately and automatically found the MX882. I picked a photo and sent it to the printer. Using the supplied Canon photo paper, the photo from my iPod Touch printed out quickly. I was stunned by how great the photo came out. The colors are great and it is sharp and with high contrast. The photo is as good as anything I've seen come from a lab (and photography is one of my hobbies).<br /><br />A negative aspect of this and the older printer we had is they both will use color ink when printing greyscale. This is a waste of ink and money. We dealt with this issue on the older printer, and user comments about the MX882 indicated the same problem exists here. We just lived with it though because these printers just have too many other great features that we want.<br /><br />Another comment about ink is when printing greyscale, or copying or printing anything that is truly just black and white like a Word document, the large black cartridge is used along with the Cyan, Magenta, and Yellow, but the little back cartridge isn't used. For a while we were buying the ink multipacks with the four small tanks but we had to stop and buy individual color ink cartridges. The small black was not often being used and they were piling up in our ink storage box.<br /><br />I can't add anything about the FAX feature. On the older printer we did use the fax sparsely and it worked fine with our traditional Verizon and AT&T phone lines. However when we switched to VOIP using the Ooma Telo system (super cheap and it works great) I never could get the FAX to work well. Further I think the printer was interfering with our voice calls, causing them to drop. So, as we have little reason to fax out, and most people can email instead of fax, we just ignored this function. We don't run the phone through the printer so it won't interfere with our VOIP. I don't consider this a Canon problem but rather a VOIP issue.<br /><br />It is clear that this printer is faster than the MX860, and I suppose the MX870, because I have printed quite a number of copies of single sided sheets and a bunch of duplex tow sided sheets which perhaps 20-25% faster.<br /><br />Overall we are very pleased with our purchase. It is the only printer in operation in our house with a total of four computer using it.<br />We go through a 5,000 sheet box of paper about every six months so it is in heavy demand. We use the automatic feeder often which works flawlessly. As I indicated we also print about 1/2 our material in duplex which makes a more professional look to our handouts for the ministry, and saves paper.<br /><br />Some added comments April 23,2012.<br />For a printer that (on Amazon) advertises that it can make two sided copies from two sided originals it isn't easy to use. The MX860 had a key marked 2-Sided. The MX882 has the two sided control buried in the Print Settings menu.<br /><br />Oh and the instruction booklet is one of the worst I've seen. But I'm of the impression that to use an all-in-one if you have to revert to the manual something is wrong with the design. I did look for 2-sided printing in the manual but got frustrated with the horrible format of the manual. I finally discovered the 2-sided printing options by poking around with the actual printer. The on-screen manual is a bit easier to use, especially because one can use the serach function.<br /><br />Further comment April 26, 2012<br />I picked up the role of family tree historian along the years. When it does print an envelope it comes out wrinkled - always.<br />  Like other laser printers, its noisy compared to an inkjet.  However, it eventually goes into a silent sleep mode.  The only real advantage I see in this over an inkjet is the pages won't run if wet.  An advantage in legal documents and envelopes.  However, if you don't do a lot of that type printing, I'd take another look at an inkjet.  Text printing and basic graphics like pie charts or cartoon type images are equal to inkjet BUT only if you go into the print software and specify darker black or color printing. I still don't know what that means. My current process is to scan a jpg file onto the Windows desktop, drag the file out of the Windows window onto the Mac desktop and manipulate the file from there.<br /><br />Would I recommend this unit? Forget using this printer for native printing of photos taken by a high quality camera - even at the highest dpi settings, the prints come out dark and somewhat undifferentiated. I'll use Photoshop to try and compensate for the poor print quality.  On the ugly side, this is one big heavy sucker!  And when its running and even prior to going into sleep mode; it draws so much power it causes my nearby UPS/power conditioner to cycle endlessly until the printer goes into sleep mode. Finally, on the cheap side ... while I have a few of these on the shelf and you really don't need it to set up wireless printing; if you follow the OEM instructions, Brother tells you to hook up a USB/IEEE cable they don't provide in the box!  So, for about $2.00 they save; that will drive the average buyer nuts - but not to worry it is a stardard printer USB cable and you can probably snag it from one of your other printers or from a friendly neighbor.  In conclusion; Would I buy this printer again? - the answer is "no," ... R1WUG1EYTRGVWM;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A2JZOZX1QCQSWV;;Printer;;B004HO58UW;;Canon Pixma MX882 Wireless Office All-in-One Inkjet Printer (4894B002);;Faxing functionality compromised on Macs;;This is a nice, cheap multi-function printer in many respects -- you can read other people's reviews for the specifics. But I want to warn prospective buyers who plan on using the printer in a Mac environment about one glaring problem with fax functionality: don't expect to be able to use this printer to fax anything without physically printing it out on paper first. (Note that this shortcoming does not seem to apply to users on the Windows side of the aisle)<br /><br />If, for example, you're planning on sending a 30 page fax you can't just "print to fax" the way you can with some other multi-function machines (like the HP 8500 I used to have) and have the document faxed directly -- you have to do it old school and print everything out on paper first and then fax the stack of paper. This is an outrageous and unnecessary waste of paper, ink and, most importantly, time if you send any volume of faxes. According to (the very vague and unhelpful) Canon tech I spoke to there "may be a way" to support this functionality but it requires "additional hardware" and a necessity to talk to Apple about it. In other words, they pass the buck and are very dismissive about it. They said there are no plans to implement the functionality in the future.<br /><br />Also, if you intend on receiving faxes directly to your computer -- again bypassing the unnecessary waste of paper and ink and saving you the time and trouble of having to scan a poor quality fax into your computer to file it digitally -- you are similarly out of luck. Other multi-function machines offer this capability (although it's sometimes well hidden -- printer makers want you to use up the expendables whenever possible) but at least it's an option. R39NR48A11N0KB;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A20OWI75MC72WW;;Printer;;B005J31B0Q;;Epson WorkForce Pro WP-4020 Wireless Color Inkjet Printer (C11CB30201);;Nightmare install with Mac OS 10.7.3 Lion, but decent printer;;Product operation: 4.5 stars  Product install, support, and documentation: 0 stars, so I'm saying a weak 3 stars overall.  4+ hours of frustration trying to get this thing to wirelessly communicate with my brand new iMac, running OS X 10.7.3 Lion.  First impression out of the box is yes, this unit is indeed big, but it is super quick compared to our previous inkjet.  Print quality looked outstanding.  Feels solidly built.  Holds a ton of paper. That's the good part.  The bad news is I almost put a bullet through this thing in frustration before I could discover any of those nice operating characteristics.<br /><br />Here's my nightmare install story, incredibly involving an iMac, on which peripheral installation is normally a no brainer.<br /><br />The shipped install CD has "compatible with OS X 10.7" written on it, but a note apparently slipped in last minute by Epson says, "ATTENTION APPLE MAC OS X 10.7 LION USERS.  Do not insert your Epson product CD.  Go to the Epson support site for special instructions".  So they knew the CD didn't work yet shipped it anyway?  Not impressed so far.  Went to Epson's website, followed their instructions, downloaded the new driver, ran the Epson installation wizard, ran an Apple software update, and....no wireless communication.  Uninstalled the Epson drivers to get a fresh start and did it again. No luck.  Uninstalled again and tried using only the Apple update with the printer hooked up via USB (i.e. nothing from the Epson website).  Apple update again provided something that referenced Epson printer software, but the driver installation was incomplete as now it wouldn't even communicate via the USB port.  Spent a couple frustrating hours searching web forums for a solution as Epson online support documentation was vague and no help.  No luck.<br /><br />Finally stumbled upon a solution purely by luck.  Here's what I did:<br />1) Uninstalled everything to start fresh<br />2) Downloaded Epson's driver combo package, BUT DID NOT RUN EPSON INSTALL YET<br />3) Ran Apple Update, which found updates for Epson printers and installed them<br />4) Continued with the Epson Install process<br /><br />Bingo.  Good wireless and USB connectivity.  So you need to download a partially outdated driver from Epson, stop following the install wizard (no prompt from Epson to do that), run an Apple software update, THEN continue the Epson install wizard.  Epson, SEND A CORRECT INSTALL CD, PLEASE!!!!;;3.0;;February 14, 2012;;7;;10;;0.7

R1IUL7OEF26QV5;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A1RM8OCBPYVC8X;;Printer;;B000J1HPK8;;Canon Pixma Pro9000 Professional Large Format Inkjet Printer (9995A001);;There's a Real Flaw in the PixmaPro 9000...;;There's a real flaw in the PixmaPro 9000, that Canon simply does not want to address...<br /><br />This thing is advertised as an 8 color printer... that is, it's an 8 color printer only if you use it as a paperweight on your desktop.<br /><br />Canon's strategy, as has become obvious to those who have struggled to deal with their Tech Service department, is that to "advertise" capabilities, and then not deliver, will result in enhanced initial sales, then deny issues exist, when they clearly do.<br /><br />The issue? Red and Green ink. They simply are not used.<br /><br />Try printing a pure Green or Red section. 100C + 100Y, or 100M +100Y... and what? Zero Green or Red ink expended...<br /><br />Try converting to RGB space, and put down 255R or 255G... same result... Canon squirts copius amounts of C,M and especially Y down, and while the Red & Green inks sleep, they collect ink cartridge fees to finance the Pixma Pyramid scheme. For heaven's sake, even the Photo Cyan and Photo Magenta are guzzled at a rate 100 times the Red and Green ink meters nudge down...<br /><br />Canon's explanation is that the Green and Red inks "extend" the color gamut of photo images... slightly... only under certain conditions... and certain paper types... and certain paper sizes... sometimes. Right. They even claim that their Red and Green inks are NOT represented by any known combination of CMY inks, or an RGB value. Wow. Green is not Green. Red is not Red.<br /><br />Too bad for you (as far as they are concerned) if you decide NOT to be blind stupid happy campers and refuse to drink the Canon Koolaid... Red and Green Koolaid...<br /><br />In reality, you will expend 40+ cartridges of the 4 color process inks, for every Red or Green cartridge expended.<br /><br />Can it be overriden? No.<br /><br />Do alternate drivers or color profile settings exist that tweak it out? No.<br /><br />Do you consume enormous amounts of CM&Y ink carts making process reds and greens? You betcha.<br /><br />So why, for crying out loud, are Red & Green inks marketed?<br /><br />To minimize ink saturation on heavy R/G color sections?<br /><br />Nope.<br /><br />To save enormous amounts of print head firing, by laying down 2 picoliters of R instead of 2 picoliters of M plus 2 picoliters of Y to make a RED dot on the paper?<br /><br />Nope.<br /><br />You figure it out. Canon has their (our) cake and they eat it too... pay them extra for an 8 color printer, and STILL buy their ink by the bucketload.<br /><br />What a business plan. Do they hear the Voice of the Customer? No way.;;1.0;;July 5, 2010;;15;;22;;0.681818

The software did not install correctly the first time, but that's OK, I uninstalled, rebooted, reinstalled, rebooted, plugged and unplugged things until it installed OK and my computer recognized that I have a brand-new printer. I went through the tech support rigmarole, and even after a registry change, my printer wouldn't scan. I didn't have another hour to kill on this so the next day I just scoured the internet with as specific set of queries as I could put together, and found a helpful tidbit. Turns out that you can go through good old Paint, in Start>>All Programs>>Accessories>>Paint>>File>>From Scanner or Camera, and your scanner will scan for you! So the scanner works! Everything works, it's just the shoddy software. Since I can't scan through the HP software, I can't seem to align my cartridges, and in general, scanning through Paint it very limiting and not really a solution when one can simply return the beast. R2RSDFWIXX6GGO;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A3FR7D30WTA25D;;Printer;;B0036TGGVO;;HP LaserJet Pro P1102w Printer (CE657A#BGJ);;Buyer Beware;;I usually don't write reviews but this printer has me so irrigated that it definitely deserved a horrible review.  To start off the printer is advertized with E-Print and AirPrint capabilities.  These are not active out of the box.  After some short research I found that you must complete a firmware upgrade to use these functions.  This sounds simple enough but instructions are horrible.  About mid way through the firmware upgrade (over wireless) the printer looses wireless connection.  I would recommend trying the update over USB maybe you will have a better outcome. Because of the loss of connection your computer assumes the firmware upgrade never completed.  This is my experience maybe others had a different experience.  During the update the printer assumes a different IP address.  Not wanting to change the IP of the router and my laptop I figured I would just delete the printer from Printers and reset the printer to factory settings.  This seems like a good idea but the printer does not start its auto configuration when you plug it in for the second time.  After time consuming research I found that the printer needs to be deleted form add remove programs and then you can run the install and set up the printer again.  Then next problem appears when you turn the power off on the printer the wireless never reconnects.  After more extensive research I found that the only way to get the printer back is to power cycle the router after the printer is power cycled.  The printer wireless light is always solid blue but it will not communicate unless you power cycle the router.  This appears to be a glitch in the software update.  Just figured I would let you all know and maybe save you some time trouble shooting.;;1.0;;January 29, 2012;;5;;8;;0.625

No confusing commands, no usless and unnecessary steps.<br />I would say, my third grader indeed could read and follow them.<br /><br />* Wireless function. I am done with cables. Awsome! you can just stick it in and either print from them directly skiping computer or you can use the slots to transfer photos from your camera into the computer so it acts as a reader for  your medias. Keep in mind that there are basically two lines of HP printers..<br />those that are PHOTO Quality always having PHOTO in their names.. and those who are geared towards<br />those who do not print that much photos at home and take their  photo printing needs elswere for highest quality photo printing yet they need to print mostly paper documents with occassinal photo jobs for their needs.<br /><br />From my experience and in my opinion you can't have both.. and you should take a good look at your printing and cost needs and decide what is good for you.<br /><br />It is easy, if you mainly print documents and a lot of them go with OfficeJet printers as they are much more cost effective and much much faster then photo ptinters for this kind of jobs. Now if you use them for photos they won't give you as great picture quality but they do come close.<br /><br />However if you do need to print pictures all the time and occassionally do print a document then go with Photo printer.. this will give you better and more consistent photo quality printing but those printers are way slower overall for printing and the ink usage tends to be much less economical.<br /><br />Before you buy any printer do check HP how much cost the ink replacement cartriges and how much copies you can print out of one on avearage and this will give you idea if thsi is what you want and need.<br /><br />In our case we mainly print tons of paper in our home and we can get really nice pictures for our home album from it, but for wall frames we send our pictures to some site like Kodagallery or alikes<br />and they ship t hem back home. There are tons of sites that will do it for you jus as good, this was just an example.<br /><br />Lastly if you opted for the Office Jet and trying to decide between HP 4500 HP 6500 and HP 8500<br />here is what I can say after my own research and comarisons:<br /><br />4500 is the smallest of the three.. takes minimal desk space and does superb job in terms of printing<br />speed and print quality, some people complained that it shoots pages on the floor after printing but they don't know how to simply find and extend the paper catcher within the catching drawer.. yes it is there.. just need to look for it. it is folded and in.. so you need to pull it out and open...<br /><br />what is not so great about it: it does not come with separate color ink cartriges just one for color and one for black.<br />what is great about it: price, size and quality, cost per page, regardless of just two inks the cost is minimal, also you can use XL black cartrige and you can't change it for HUNDREDTS of pages!.. I think it was something like 700 or so.. what a convenience! it is also wireless printer.<br /><br />btw.. some people complaint for jams of paper in it.. I did try it and it prints fine.. and beware.. any printer will jam paper if it is not fresh from the batch and wrinkle free. Never used tired and<br />even bitsy wrinkled paper to lad to your printer. That comes after my many years of work at print shop.. the easiest and sure shot way to avoid any jams of paper - use perfect flat and unhandled paper.<br /><br />HP 6500 -<br />what is so great about it: it is wireless but you can also plug it via usb, it has separate color ink cartriges for each color and one for black (and yeah.. black is not a color :)<br />cartriges last seemingly endless, cost per page, durability, speed, very very fast printer,<br />great for document printing. comes with fax, copier, scanner and web printing..<br />comes with media reader slots for your camera memory cards.<br /><br />what is not so great - nothing really, very good printer overall however it is big so if size is what you care about then it is about half size bigger then H P<br /><br />HP 8500 - This is a beast! think of it as bigger and faster HP 6500.. It is much bigger physically as a unit and it prints faster and does other jobs faster. However it might be great for someone who has a small home business it seem to be an overkill for a regular family needs.<br /><br />Whichever printer you will go with do always checck the return policy that you don't need untill things do go wrong and s ometimes they can..  and do try it and see how you like it and test it well before commiting. R1T5Q58WS4STFJ;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A18PWNPVPY5OBS;;Printer;;B001F0RI1I;;HP CP2025DN Color LaserJet Printer;;Nice print quality / Cost prohibitive toner;;After decades of great success with Hewlett Packard gear (both as a salesman and technician) I decided to pick up this printer to help keep costs down for my non-profit. We do very little printing and certainly cannot afford the $0.62/pg that the copy shops are charging.<br /><br />Opening the box... Disappointed with how flimsy the unit feels. Yes, I know it's on the less expensive end of color laser printers, but I was hoping it would be sturdier than your standard "free" inkjet. It doesn't. The paper tray, manual feed and cartridge drawer feel so light they could break if you looked at them wrong.<br /><br />In use... Very noisy, but very fast. Print quality is dark, but I think that can be adjusted through the HP ToolboxFX program that comes with a full driver install (cannot customize install or you don't get this software). Still have to tinker with it to achieve the results I want. Duplex option is terrific and a real time saver. Strangely powers itself on randomly throughout the night even when not in use. Also runs through about 30sec of "clunking" or "knocking" after it completes a print job. Sounds broken.<br /><br />Toner... My #1 complaint - holy cow these things are expensive! Looking at about $500 for a complete set. And in what I think was very limited use, have already replaced each one (bought the machine in Nov). That has covered me for approx 1000 prints at about 30% coverage. That's about on par with the local copy shops for expense.<br /><br />My suggestion is to spend the extra $300 for the professional grade printer so you don't waste all your money on cartridges. Plus, my experience is that the professional stuff isn't nearly as flimsy. I like the print quality and the speed, but ultimately the cost has tainted my opinion of the machine.;;2.0;;February 23, 2011;;5;;7;;0.714286

But plug an ipod into another USB port, or sometimes even a USB drive (if it has jpg files on it) - and Lexmark gets confused that those just might be from a camera.  So, if you are trying to sync your ipod shuffle, it will keep disconnecting.  I can't autofill anymore.  I have to manually drag songs over, maybe 10 will copy over, before Lexmark "gets smart" even though I selected preference for it NOT to try to read that drive letter.  So, I manually drag songs from my music library in itunes, then click 'skip' in case I grabbed some that did make it over before. The printer, fax, memory card reader always worked on the HP, just not the scanning after a while.<br /><br />And ALL the Lexmark models that look like this (I looked in all of them at the store), have no way to open up the middle. He said, he's had one for months and never had a jam.  Sales guys are required to lie, apparently.<br /><br />Stay away from this printer manufacturer unless you like junk. R1YO95917HC6IJ;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A35ZL2OOVOWK9C;;Printer;;B0036TGGJQ;;HP LaserJet Pro M1212nf  Printer (CE841A#BGJ);;Buyer Beware!!;;This product does not come with the cable you need to connect to your computer or router!  I was completely shocked and dismayed (and spent an hour on the phone with HP to tell them so) that HP wouldn't include a CRITICAL piece of equipment with this product. I repeat, you CANNOT connect this printer to your computer or wireless router without buying a USB cable separately. You wouldn't know it from the advertising for this product, so I'm telling you. If you don't already have the right cable at your home/home office/business, you need to buy one if you actually want to use this printer.  I am supremely annoyed.  HP wants it both ways: they want to exclude critical equipment so that they can advertise the lowest price BUT they don't want to tell you that they've excluded a critical component from the box.  What they get now is an irate customer.<br /><br />UPDATE: Several commenters have pointed out that excluding cables is standard, but I bought an HP laserjet printer 3 years ago that came with all required cables, so if it is common practice to exclude cables I wouldn't have known it from that previous purchase.  That said, I finally found a cable to connect to my new HP LaserJet Pro M1212nf printer and want to review the actual printer now.<br /><br />I own only Macs. The "easy/instant" install feature that is advertised for this product does not apply to Macs.  So, it was a tedious, old school process to install on my home network.  However, it worked. All the features work. Print quality is good. Biggest negative: this machine is LOUD! I was surprised since I've only ever owned HP laserjets and have always found them to be pretty quiet. Even my husband was startled by the loudness when he heard the printer start printing for the first time.  And the paper bin doesn't hold a big load of paper. I found myself thinking I would return the printer, but then remembered that I didn't pay very much for it, and that I should be setting my expectations to match the price point.  So, I upped my review by one star.  If you're willing to put up with the noise and a low-volume paper bin, and the headache of installing on a mac, then this is a good printer for the price.  Me? I like quality and I wish I had splurged for something a little higher up the quality scale.;;2.0;;October 2, 2010;;10;;67;;0.149254

I purchased this printer about 2 weeks ago for $199.00<br /><br />*** Epson WorkForce 845 All-in-One Printer ***<br />After our old HP Printer died and some extensive research (cheaper ink, CNET Best "All-in-One Printer, paper capacity, etc...) I purchased this printer about 2 weeks ago for $199.00. The Epson 845 looks to be a good all-in-one, with dedicated fax, fast printing and 2 drawers with 500 sheet capacity, WiFi, easy setup, and a small form factor. Not a photo quality printer, but with most camera shops able to take care of this for you at a lesser cost it was not an issue for us..<br />I have not had it long so I cannot accurately say what the longevity of this printer is, but I am confident we will have relatively few issues with this all-in-on. Over all I am please with the "Epson WorkForce 845 All-in-One Printer".<br /><br />***Price***<br />At a price of $199.00 I believed the "Epson WorkForce 845 All-in-One Printer" was neither over nor underpriced. Though my HP printer was much cheaper the ink cost 2X more and at a third of the volume of what this Epson offers, so I knew I would be saving in the long run.<br />That being said, after going in to my local "Big Box" Staples for some supplies I needed ASAP (otherwise I would have ordered from Amazon) I saw the same "Epson WorkForce 845 All-in-One Printer" for a little over $100.00. Even after 5% sales tax that is a considerable savings in my eyes.<br />Taking this into account I give the " Epson WorkForce 845" 2 stars if purchased through Amazon do to its cost to quality factor.  If purchasing from Stapes 5+ Stars, a very good deal.<br /><br />***Postscript***<br />So...  A long review,  more about my opinion and disappointment that a big box store beat my beloved Amazon on price by a considerable margin. I have until now been confident that Amazon was going to have the best price to customer service and shipping cost (Free, most of the time for me) ratio out there, especially over the local big box stores.<br />A lesson felt is a lesson learned, and I felt this one in my wallet pretty hard.<br />My advice - If you have the time shop around at your local Big Box Stores, they may have better prices and some awesome deals that would have otherwise been missed. I know I will.<br />I'll be sure to be more diligent in my research and not default to Amazon.<br />Also, the same Staples store had a Cisco 8 port gigabit switch I was looking at getting for about 25% less then Amazon pricing. That was there every day price from what I could tell, not a sale or promo.<br /><br />***To Amazon***<br />If you (an Amazon employee - representative) read this. What each of these means is not intuitively obvious.<br /><br />So far, I'm getting crisp text output very quickly.  That's good. R2833XY8NAW1LK;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/AABXKBCKZL1VH;;Printer;;B003ZYAK08;;Samsung CLX-3185 Color Printer with Scanner & Copier;;Missing contact pin for toner chip (on inside door) renders printer useless;;Bought this printer on sale...was working fine but then I got a message saying that the toner was low.  I replaced the toner with a new one, and the message still said that the toner was low.  I replaced the toner again with a new one and this time the printer said to "replace toner"...the printer thinks that my toner is empty when it is brand new.  The problem, it turns out was a missing contact pin...a simple pin on the inside of the front door that makes contact with the toner chip.  Somehow, that pin fell off and I can't find it. I called Samsung support, but they said this was due to "consumer use" and that they would not cover it.  Where the heck can I get this tiny litle part?  I asked if they would sell it to me, and they don't even carry it.  What a joke!  My new color printer now won't print...rendered useless all because of a $0.50 pin that's missing. Yet we're on our 5th or 6th set of cartridges. Well, $90 every two months or so is way, way out of line. Not only will I never buy another Canon printer, I will never buy another Canon anything. R1RBO6J8XZNJXA;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/AR4H01W1PUSWR;;Printer;;B001A11KA2;;Epson Stylus Photo R2880 Wide-Format Color Inkjet Printer (C11CA16201);;Amazing prints;;I've had my R2880 for about six months now and have put it through its paces. I can't say enough about this printer. The print quality is outstanding...far better than any commercial print I've ever purchased. And that's not just color. B&W is fantastic...deep, rich blacks all the way through the gamut. The fact that I can now produce large (up to 13 x 19, though I generally stay with A3, or 12 x 16, paper) versions of my photographs with such startling results has me in a printing, matting, and framing frenzy!<br /><br />Admittedly, the ink is expensive. Each set of 8 cartridges runs about $110, but I consider it very worthwhile. Additionally, the Epson software (I'm using it with a Macintosh) makes it spectacularly easy to order new cartridges from Epson. If you order more than three colors, Epson ships them overnight or two day for free! The only problem I've had with the R2880 is trying to print on Epson's Velvet Fine Art Paper. The few prints I tried on it bled. I haven't tried to troubleshoot this with Epson, as I've fallen in love with their Ultra Premium Photo Paper Luster and do nearly all of my printing on that paper.<br /><br />I can't recommend this printer too highly. I've you're a serious photographer, you need this printer. I haven't used one, but I'd imagine the R3880, which is even larger format, prints similarly but for about $400 more. 13 x 19 is plenty large enough for me right now.;;5.0;;November 4, 2009;;3;;5;;0.6

RFG0WC6QIR12;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A14UY4NASEW3B4;;Printer;;B004QM8J8S;;Brother Printer Wireless Monochrome Printer, Dark Grey (HL2280DW);;Huge disappointment;;Our (Brief) Foray into a Brother HL-2280DW All In One Laser Printer<br /><br />The Bad:<br />Can't scan multiple pages in to a single document<br />Wireless is not so easy to configure (I'm in IT).<br />Drivers won't be automatically detected (It's 2011 guys)<br /><br />The Good:<br />It prints quickly<br />It scans (one page) quickly, with decent image quality.<br /><br />Review:<br /><br />We have been printing and scanning quite a bit so decided we would get an AIO.  We wanted a laser printer as an ink toner cartridge that lasts 500 pages won't go far with 30-40 page documents.  That said we spent quite a bit of time looking around and we found the Brother HL-2280 Printer was a small and inexpensive device which takes a Brother TN-450 toner cartridge that provides a decent cost per page.  My girlfriend went to Staples to play with and purchase the said printer and the cashier, the clerk informed her that the starter toner in the printer would only print 20 (twenty) pages before running out, and therefore she should purchase a new toner to go with it; he offered to sell her a TN-420.  Really?  Lying Thieves, thankfully she wasn't suckered in by this gimmick.  For reference, the printer comes with a TN-420 toner cartridge which according to staples.com prints 1,200 pages.  I can only assume that the pimply geek with huge gauge holes in his ears was flat out lying in order to get her to purchase a toner cartridge and improve his sales attach rate.  Also, the two year warranty is only 29.99.  Thanks, we'll pass. I hope it dies before two years is up so it can fill a dumpster somewhere.<br /><br />Step 1) Plug in, configure wifi (Fail #1)<br />With the printer at home I plug it in, and turn it on.  Open the menu, go to wifi and use the wifi protected setup menu, which i've admittedly never used.  I choose the option where it gives me a code that i type in to the router, and then the devices pair.  60 seconds later my belkin router says device connected successfully, and the printer spits out a page saying failed.  I tried a couple variations of this and eventually gave up.  Ultimately I connected to the printer via an ethernet cable, connected to the web interface with the default username of admin and the default password of password and managed to configure the wireless from there.<br /><br />Step 2) Connect to computer (Fail #2)<br />I used the add a printer wizard in Windows 7 and to my delight it was quickly detected.  Except the printer driver wasn't found.  I went to the brother website and download the printer driver, installed it via computer management and I'm off to the races!<br /><br />Step 3) Print a document (The only successful step)<br />It prints. Oh, and it can print on both sides / duplex perfectly.<br /><br />Step 4) Scan a document (Fail #3)<br />I press the scan button expecting the scan to email function similar to other brother AIO's I've used.  It says check connection.  This device can only perform the scanning functions through the brother software.  No problem I say! I download the 130MB software, install it (reboot required... ugh it's 2011), and scan a document.  All of the defaults scan to JPG, including scan to email or file.  I change it to default to PDF and go to scan my document.  As it turns out, this brother All In One HL-2280DW IS NOT CAPABLE of scanning multiple pages in to a single document.  Say you want to scan and email a 2 page document, you will need to scan it in to two separate files and email them separately.  The scanner we had some 12 or 15 years ago was capable of this simple functionality.  Press scan, it scans the document, asks you if there are any more pages, and either scans the next page or finishes with the file.<br /><br />Step 5) Return for full refund.<br />Reason stated on return claim: defective.<br /><br />My Backstory:<br />I have installed and used multiple brother all in one laser devices (which don't have the majority of these issues) and figured I'd give them a shot since at the budget end their cost per page is far lower than the competing HP model (1.7c/page vs 5c/page).  I have no previous hatred of brother until this new device was purchased (and about to become returned).<br /><br />UPDATE:<br />It turns out it is possible to scan multiple pages.  The preferences menu doesn't show the option, but if you right click on the email or file button for example, and go to settings you get almost the exact same menu you find under preferences, but it has a checkbox for manual scan.  It does work.  The downside is you must return to your computer to press the next page button, and the software on the computer effectively does a new scan job and stitches the two together.  This is clearly a piece of equipment meant for scanning one page things, and the software isn't well designed (why does the checkbox only show up on right click -> settings, instead of the main preferences tab you get?;;2.0;;July 11, 2011;;19;;29;;0.655172

R3HDGYIWT4L0CU;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A320ATPB6MZDTK;;Printer;;B005K95U88;;Brother Printer MFCJ425W Wireless Color Photo Printer with Scanner, Copier and Fax;;OMG Please Don't Buy This;;I don't usually take the time to write a review, but this has probably been the worst product I have ever purchased on Amazon.<br /><br />First, you should know that I spent over 2 hours on the phone with Brother support.  They were very respectful.  Only problem is, this machine is a piece of crap.  It's supposed to be a multi-function device, but the only "function" that works on this thing is the printer--so why pay more for the other, dysfunctional, functions?<br /><br />FAX<br /><br />The first problem is this machine HAS NEVER SUCCESSFULLY SENT A FAX.  I have tried at least 30 times, and some of the faxes are practically blank.  Now, like most people these days, I have digital phone service and one of the settings is for "basic" mode so it can be used with "inferior" digital phone service.  Yet even in basic mode, it has never once successfully sent a fax.  The support people blamed it all on the digital phone line.  I was treated to a 5-minute lecture about digital voice and bandwidth, which started with the statement "we do not support [digital phone service]".  While they blamed the problems on the phone service, they could not explain why I get 5 different error messages for the same "problem."  They also could not explain why I have never before had this problem in 7 years of digital phone service.<br /><br />The worst part is that this machine keeps resending the failed faxes over and over, without me asking it to do so, and it then prints several stupid 1-line reports repeating that the faxes failed.  Well duh!  There was already an error message on screen and a beeping noise telling me that each fax failed--again.  Customer support tells me that these settings (atomatic repeated attempts to fax without change of settings, and wasting paper and ink on numerous/redundant 1-line error messages) are permanent and cannot be changed.<br /><br />SCANNING<br /><br />Not only does the fax not work, but some SCAN FUNCTIONS HAVE STOPPED WORKING.  I use this machine for online banking, among other things.  My bank's website controls the scanner remotely when I deposit a check online, but the scan/deposit function has recently stopped working and I get various error messages instead.<br /><br />OTHER<br /><br />There are also a lot of quirks about this machine that I just don't like, but which are not primary functions.  For example: I have my home-office phone running through the fax machine.  Every time I use the phone, the machine and its display click on for the duration of my call; they then shut off as soon as I hang up.  It's creepy and it feels like the machine is monitoring my calls, so I leave it turned off most of the time.  The machine also routes the phone calls somehow.  After half an hour on the phone with my first support call, the representative instructed me to turn the machine off.  When I did so, the call was dropped.  The phone works just fine if the machine is already off, but DO NOT SHUT IT OFF DURING A CALL.  If you do, your call will be dropped.<br /><br />And finally, this thing is just poorly designed in my opinion.<br /><br />*The user interface is not at all intuitive.<br /><br />*The machine periodically turns on by itself and seems to warm up (and use ink?) for no apparent reason and without being sent any data.<br /><br />*It also prints A LOT of reports.  It prints a report every time a fax fails.  It prints a report every time the network settings are changed.  Some of these reports are 1 line and say something like "network setup OK."  I find myself asking, why did it waste paper and ink for this?  My hours on the phone with customer support revealed that all of these are permanent settings and cannot be changed.<br /><br />*Good luck using basic driver functions.  I hate how hardware manufacturers want you to use their memory intensive junkware bundles for something as simple as printing and scanning.  Give me drivers and software that allow me to send a print job and scan when I want to, without 8 perpetual processes that slow and monitor my every click.  I'm not even sure you can scan on this thing without a mega-suite of software.<br /><br />Brother makes some great products.  We've had the same Brother sewing machine for like 10 years, and I have a Brother laser printer that I am very pleased with (except the aforementioned and ubiquitous software issues).  But the MFC-J425W is not a good Brother product.  Save yourself a headache and get something else.;;1.0;;May 11, 2012;;14;;19;;0.736842

This usually does little to help. The manual also says that if this continues, I should call for tech support.<br /><br />So I called for tech support. My first call was apparently to the wrong group. The second technician walked me through loading a new driver onto the Mac and doing a hard reset of the printer. <br /><br />The manual doesn't tell me how to do a full reset of the printer (restoring it to factory state) and I didn't realize this was going on (the tech would tell me what to do next, but not what we were doing at the more global level, maybe she didn't know) until we were fairly far along. RB5O5HU0T341C;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/AUR87RUPDAWO1;;Printer;;B003YGZIY0;;HP Deskjet 1000 Printer (CH340A#B1H);;Yes it's a 'bargain' printer but...;;Buying a 'budget' type of item it is expected that the top bells and whistles will not be present-- under $50 an expectation of scanner/copier/camera dock/etc. would be foolish.<br /><br />But there are certain expectations that even a budget item should meet, in the case of a piece of computer hardware it should be that it contains everything necessary to plug and play straight out of the box (with the possible exception of an online driver database instead of a disk).<br /><br />The decision not to include a USB cable here isn't so much about the added expense of that additional cable (as I just dug one out of the trusty junk drawer), but rather a certain measure of quality that reflects poorly on the product, and assuming the target audience to be joe-average it could also create a fair amount of confusion on the part of a consumer that would end up arriving home only to realize they need to go back out a second time for that cord (possibly a third if they ask their handy helper for "a usb cord" and getting a generic male-male cable.<br /><br />Aside from that overblown rants, the machine itself is nice and fairly compact, with its ability to fold up trays into a discrete cube handy for someone who needs portability.<br /><br />The print quality is fine, about what you'd expect of any deskjet.<br /><br />The last item of note is the catcher tray, which does not fold down all the way, dangling about half an inch above the desk it is on, whether intended or not it just adds one more feel of cheapness to the product and I could see a potential for breaking the tray because of this.<br /><br />All that said, as long as one is aware that they will need a male-female USB of their one to go along with this product, it is a respectable and compact setup that at Amazon's current price costs about the same as a combo-pack of printer ink on its own.;;3.0;;December 16, 2010;;13;;21;;0.619048

HP, the most unuser friendly company!!!<br />Report Inappropriate Content<br />Message 11 of 32 (5,618 Views)<br /><br />Reply<br />Crazy_Brave<br />Visitor<br /><br />Posts: 2<br />Registered: 01-29-2010<br />0<br />Re: Photosmart C309a CD/DVD Printing Software<br />Options<br />01-29-2010 09:50 AM<br /><br />Here's my story - I found this problem immediately last summer when I bought my c309a (printing off-center on a disk using third-party labeling software). I figured it might take a while for sofware patches to be released to allow third-party vendors to catch up with the c309a. I recently purchased a new HP Pavilion Elite computer. One would figure that the bundled software( Cyberlink LabelPrint) would work, right? Wrong. The label printed off center big time. Even on a brand-spanking-new HP computer, they don't allow their software partners to have the HP printer templates. (Cyberlink LabelPrint DOES have the Epson templates, however). I have taken this issue up the entire chain of command of HP'ssupport networks for the printer and the computer. (The computer support people refuse to talk to me, they push me off on the printer support people). CyberLink gave me a boilerplate answer too. After about a week, and sending HP support several angry emails, I got a call from a "Case Manager" at HP. He said in so many words that HP cannot give template patches to third party software vendors. As long as the labeling portion of the driver software works, HP is absolved of any responsibility for this. I went back to the store where I bought the printer last year, and they still sell new c309a printers. The packaging box shows examples of what the printer can do. One of those examples is a cd with a label on it - and the label was made with third party software - NOT the driver program label. As they are bragging that the printer prints DIRECTLY onto the cd, I would assume the disk shown on the box would NOT be an adhesive label. Here's the real issue for me - my car will only play cd's that are printed on directly. An adhesive label will increase the overall thickness of the cd so much that the cd will get stuck in the car's cd player. The quality results on a cd labeled with HP's driver set is very bad for a music cd, to the point of unusability. When every disk has the same label, with almost unreadable text (skinny white words over orange background), I'm likely to drive off the road. I chose this printer over all others because the PROMISED ability to print nice full-color music cd labels directly onto the cd was the feature I wanted. My new computer has a LightScribe drive in it, but they print in monochrome only, and also are limited in the level of creativity you can use in making a label. It also renders my 100-pack of ink-jet-printabel disks obsolete. I guess that I have to break out the Sharpie marker - it works better than the HP printer for putting graphics directly on a disk.<br />Report Inappropriate Content<br />Message 12 of 32 (5,516 Views)<br /><br />Reply<br />Marc_F<br />Visitor<br /><br />Posts: 1<br />Registered: 02-08-2010<br />0<br />Re: Photosmart C309a CD/DVD Printing Software<br />Options<br />02-08-2010 10:08 PM<br /><br />Hey Crazy_Brave, just wanted to post my 2-cents. Marc<br />Report Inappropriate Content<br />Message 13 of 32 (5,432 Views)<br /><br />Reply<br />Crazy_Brave<br />Visitor<br /><br />Posts: 2<br />Registered: 01-29-2010<br />0<br />Re: Photosmart C309a CD/DVD Printing Software<br />Options<br />02-16-2010 09:50 PM<br /><br />I just purchased Nero 9 Reloaded, and thankfully, in the labeling program called Nero Cover Designer, in the pulldown selection list for templates, HP CD and DVD tray is one of the selections.<br />It will attempt to print a front cover, liner, etc - so make sure you uncheck everything except the disk in the File/Print.../Print Elements tab. Just set page size to 13x13cm<br />Choose template of Labels, then (say) Classical (Avery 8931).  Page size comes up as default of 12.383cm (5.12inch is 13mm) leave as is.<br />Choose Print Setup.  Paper as Size: CD/DVD, 120mm.  Source: CD/DVD Tray. At top click Properties tab for Printer C309a, and printer properties page opens.  Choose "Print on CD/DVD"<br />OK, OK, then Filerint<br />Thanks SeanSimon for this tip<br />Of course you have to have Publisher, but it works well.<br />Report Inappropriate Content<br />Message 16 of 32 (5,133 Views)<br /><br />Reply<br />BBooDad<br />Visitor<br /><br />Posts: 1<br />Registered: 03-20-2010<br />0<br />Re: Photosmart C309a CD/DVD Printing Software<br />Options<br />03-20-2010 03:28 PM<br /><br />I tried every way I could to get the built in software printing with Windows 7. R3FNJD60E1DX23;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A2K9I9KD2P58V1;;Printer;;B0044XSNHG;;HP LaserJet Pro CP1525nw Color Printer (CE875A);;Yuck;;I purchased the HP LaserJet Pro CP1525nw printer to replace an older Lexmark color laser printer. Opening the package revealed the printer, the power and USB cables, software CD, and 10 pages of diagrammatic instructions. I inserted the CD as was only given the option of 'install'.  I chose install and the message, "this may take a few minutes" and a progress bar popped up. The progress bar reached 100% and then...nothing.  Nothing else happened.  The computer was not frozen.  Just no additional options presented themselves to continue with the install.  I stopped the install, restarted my computer and the same thing happened.  I waited for 45 minutes (watching some of Lebron James' return to Cleveland) and still nothing.
