I set up a chat session with HP tech service.  After two hours (!) of working with the technician, what we basically did was: run the setup program (fyi...it is the same version on the CD as the download from the HP website) let it get to 100% and then plug in the USB cable.  Once connected, my Windows 7(64bit) desktop recognized the printer and could print.  We then tried to set up the wireless aspect of the printer.  From the menu on the printer, it was simple to turn on the wireless search signal, but the next step was to push the WPS (Wi-Fi protected setup) button on the router.  I have Verizon FiOs as my ISP. I have their newest router with the latest firmware update.  My router does have a WPS button.  Unfortunately, after contacting Verizon as to why their WPS button was not working, I was informed that the button is non-functional.  The Verizon technician was not sure if the button would ever be made functional.<br /><br />According to the HP tech rep, no WPS button leaves me with no wireless option for the HP CP1525nw.  I did install the printer driver on my MacBook and again no wireless install option from the install CD. I also installed the printer driver on my Windows Vista laptop from the install CD.  With Vista, I was given the option of the type of install I would like to perform.  Since I had two other computers up and running, I chose the networked setup rather than wireless (I had wasted enough time already).  I can print from my Vista laptop.<br /><br />If you are considering making this purchase, and you desire a truly wireless printer, make sure you have a WPS button on your router that is functional.<br /><br />The install software from HP worked with Mac OS X (Snow Leopard 10.6), seemed to work well with Windows Vista but barely worked with Windows 7.<br /><br />An additional note, I did want to use the ePrint function from HP to print from an iPhone.  I did a firmware upgrade for the printer to allow HP Web Services to assign an ePrint address for the printer.  But after another chat with HP tech support, I found out that this printer and about 6 other Hp printers are not quite ready for ePrint (the public notification is at [...]).  By giving HP my email address, I will be notified when the HP LaserJet Pro CP1525nw will be ready for ePrint.<br /><br />On a positive note, the printout of the Demo page for the HP 1525 did look very nice.<br /><br />Good luck.;;1.0;;December 3, 2010;;28;;59;;0.474576

I figured out how to get the black to print (press # + 6 when turning on) because apparently this printer has a chip that doesn't print black even after replacing the cartridge if it goes dry.<br /><br />After confirming that this printer was not "iPad" compatible like the new HP (rather, you can only print using the Wi-fi with certain applications like any other Wi-fi printer), I packed this thing back up and returned. R1CBTYHUFXP7QY;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A2IW0IUZ9AE3I5;;Printer;;B001XUQP9G;;Brother HL-5340D High Speed Laser Printer with Duplex;;Breaks after 5 months, paper feeder mechanism is nonsensical;;I think Brother should put into its next commercial song (jingle)  the loud snapping noise this printer makes when it feeds paper. It sounds like something is breaking into a million pieces. So you might argue "so who cares, you only refill the paper tray every once in a while." The problem with that theory is that the sound is a clue to something-- the paper feed mechanism in these machines is prehistoric, crude, and cannot stand-up to time and whenever you have that kind of violent mechanical action in a product, you know it's poorly designed and it won't last long. So after about 5 months, my printer stopped feeding paper. After walking through the process, calling technical support, I noticed as I expected a spring had fallen-out from the contraption and there was no way to find out where it belonged, it's a mess.  Now out of the box this was not a perfect printer. Two-sided printing is known not to work well on these printers and it never worked well on mine-- it jammed frequently. One-sided printing was "OK" until this problem and now the printer is trash unless I want to hassle with a warranty process on a $100 item. Many of us may remember years ago the quality of laser printers- for example, those made by NEC would last a decade. Nowadays you have a choice of junk or junk at a low price. You can't say "hey, I'm willing to PAY for quality, just provide it." Instead, it's a low-ball market of low-ball products that flim-flam their way into your home and then fail. This is another one of those products. At $100 or so you can take your chances, but you know that in the end, you may waste your time and money. Search for quality, I am back on that search again.;;1.0;;October 22, 2009;;15;;30;;0.5

What follows is my experience covering most of the day before finally taking a break.<br /><br />I followed the printed "Start Here" quick set-up sheet. The first steps are simply for the initial set-up and at no point is connected to a computer.<br /><br />Plugging the unit in started the process and shortly the printer software indicated set-up complete and a test page was printed with no problem.<br /><br />The printer now indicated to plug in the USB cable to the computer and then the AiO Home Center opened.<br /><br />I opened a NotePad file.  Selected, "Print". The print window did NOT list the new Kodak printer.<br /><br />Looking at the printers display which indicated "do not plug in USB cable until...", even though the software had already told me to do just that. I pressed OK on the printer, which cleared the alert but I still could not print or scan.<br /><br />Going to the Windows START menu, I selected "Printers and Faxes" the new Kodak printer was not listed. I then selected to install a new printer. I chose to install and make it the DEFAULT printer. From the Install Printer window, I chose to print a test page. The Kodak window opened and gave me the error "Software communication error Code: 105:100009)"<br /><br />I decided to restart the entire process.<br />- I disconnected the printer USB cable<br />- From Windows Control Panel I chose Add or Remove programs and deleted the Kodak software.<br />- I restarted the computer<br /><br />While the computer rebooted, I looked at the printed manual (vice the quick start), and discovered that there are two ports that fit the USB plug, (1) Ethernet, and (2) USB. I had plugged into wrong port. Why? There is a sticker on the back, aligned with the USB port, with a graphic showing a red circle/line overlaid on a graphic of a cord/plug AND there is a red tab extending over (covering) the port. This indicated to me, DO NOT USE, but actually is the correct port.<br /><br />Plugging in the USB to the "correct" port, the computer software immediately detected the printer and started loading the drivers (took about 10 minutes). When done, an alert "Printer not detected" showed up. Pressing ok, the next window indicated, "Your printer software was successfully installed."<br /><br />I chose "Finish" and the AiO Home Center opened again.<br /><br />I next checked the "Printer and Faxes" from the Control Panel... the printer was still NOT listed.<br /><br />I chose install a new printer from the Windows "Add Printer Wizard".<br /><br />When Windows indicated the software was installed, I chose to print a test page. The Kodak window opened but asked me "what FAX number do you want to send..." I canceled the print. Checking the Control Panel Printers and Faxes I discovered that the set-up had installed two printers, Kodak OH 6.1 AiO FAX and Kodak OH 6.1 AiO... and it selected the FAX as the default printer (which I quickly changed).<br /><br />I next chose to print a Notepad document with a few paragraphs of text. The made all kind of noise and actually rocked on the desktop. I heard the printer head move. On the printer the error displayed was "Printhead carriage jam". Opening the printer I found that the paper was crumpled up and jamming the printhead (I had loaded only 2 sheets in the tray).<br /><br />Clearing the jam, I pressed OK on the printer to reattempt the print job. The printer made plenty of noise but the sheet came out blank (remember it had printed a test page prior to being hooked up to the computer).<br /><br />Attempted to print the Notepad doc again. The printhead jammed and crumpled the single sheet of paper (again).<br /><br />Loading another single sheet the next attempt the page printed. The printer was VERY slow in processing and printing this single sheet of only text.<br /><br />I chose to scan a document. This went smooth and very fast.<br /><br />I printed a 5x7 photograph with excellent results.<br /><br />I next chose to "Copy" and placed a business card on the scanner glass. Two button presses activated the process. The results were a nice box of white with the text clearly displayed BUT the rest of the 8.5 x 11" paper was printed in a mid-tone gray. This was a VERY large waste of ink.<br /><br />Every time you print, a window opens letting you know that it's a Kodak printer doing the job. WHY?????? Over the years I've had plenty of printers but I never had one that insisted on reminding me what company the printer was made by every time I print.<br /><br />I went through the steps to connect the printer to the wireless router. This went fine and the printer acknowledged detecting and connecting to the router.<br /><br />Next... I was ready to attempt the set-up with my laptop using Windows 7 via Wi-Fi<br /><br />Inserting the Install Disk into the laptop, you are required to go through the registration process again (didn't see a way around it). The next thing to happen was receiving an alert, "The manifest does not exist or is corrupted (Code: 101-8197). I selected OK.<br /><br />I reran the install software and this second time it loaded fine. It then asked how I wanted to connect to the printer. I chose Wi-Fi. All attempts to connect failed. The printer was not detected. I've spent over 2 hours attempting different settings/adjustments with no success. This included going into my NETGEAR WGR614 V9 router settings.<br /><br />I haven't tested the FAX function or checked out the other options that the software allows yet. My 3 Star rating is mostly based on the install process and I anticipate upping it later (though I was not impressed by having two paper jams so soon). I'll reserve my final opinion until I've had more experience with the unit beyond the set-up (which has been quite tedious).<br />==============UPDATE REPORT BELOW as of SEPT 2012======================<br /><br />My original score was 3 Stars. Now that I've had time to "live with it" for awhile my opinion has gone down. I got my first computer/printer way back in the late 1980's and without a doubt, this has been my WORST printer.<br /><br />Wi-fi: It took less than 3 minutes (ea) to set my 2 laptops, 2 SMART phones, an iTouch, and a Wii game console to my Wi-fi, but I still can't get my printer to work with it. I just recently purchased a new "N" router and I was able to get all the same items very quickly connected... but not the Hero printer.<br /><br />Now, more importantly, this hungry monster BURNS through ink cartridges! I do very light printing, mostly simple black text, but I'm on my 3rd color cartridge (I did NOT print a single photo while using the 2nd cartridge) and already getting alerts that my 4th black cartridge is low. I'm thinking it may be cheaper to just buy a new printer than to keep Kodak in business with my ink needs.<br />=========<br />INTERESTING NOTE: The November 2012 Consumer Report Magazine, pg 33, lists the TOP 15 All-in-one inkjet printers, and NOT ONE Kodak printer is listed, least of all the Hero 6.1.<br />=========<br />On a final note, as I write this, even though the printer only has an average of 3 stars, the highest ranking "most useful" reviews are 5 stars and are the only two displayed unless you choose to see more.;;1.0;;October 30, 2011;;27;;38;;0.710526

R25D7K22EZALYB;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A31PCCSMDTQ1PU;;Printer;;B0060WDIX8;;Brother Printer HL3075CW Wireless Color Printer;;No Maintanance or Installation Problems but Poor Picture Quality;;I just bought my first Brother Digital Wireless Color laser printer this morning,and it only took 30 minutes to  set it up and start making color prints which are satisfactory but look only marginally better than the color prints made on my Brother inkjet printer. You can install this Brother printer with a wireless network or on Macintosh but I chose the USB Interface cable on my 3GB laptop.This Brother printer will also print up to 19 pages per minute in color or black & white, has up to 600 x 2400 dpl resolution, with a 250 sheet paper tray capacity, can print from a USB flash drive,has a 25,000 sheet monthly duty cycle,and is Windows and Mac compatible. Previously I had also purchased 3 HP Digital Wireless Color printers, all of which gave me many mechanical and installation problems,but if working properly as they occasionally did, produced gorgeous high quality color prints with sharp and vivid colors,and with excellent detail most of which would be suitable for framing. HP however comes with a CD Rom that can only be used ONE TIME after which the drivers are erased off the CD Rom and you will have to go online to download any printer drivers on a different computer.The CD Rom that comes with this Brother laser printer can be used many times on different computers.I have never had any installation or maintainance problems with Brother printers whether they be inkjet or as now laser. Another positive feature about Brother printers is that they always come with a small booklet that explains everything in a down to earth easy to understand manner designed for the layman. Whether its installation or maintainance, the little booklet is invaluable.The bottom line then is if you buy a Brother Digital Color Laser Printer,the prints quality will be only marginally better than inkjet, however you should have no trouble installing it. RXO06GHVSU4QG;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A3KW74XYLQO1QP;;Printer;;B0036TGGVO;;HP LaserJet Pro P1102w Printer (CE657A#BGJ);;Consumers should buy with extreme caution.;;HP has a historic record on not supporting driver updates for their printers when a new operating system comes out or when a service pack updates ones operating system.  Case in point is their HP 1012 laser printer that came out over 7 years ago.<br /><br />The HP 1012 was the first laser printer that was designed with a very small footprint, and yet provided great laser printing compared to other models costing hundreds of dollars more.<br /><br />When Vista came out in 2007, and consumers realized that there would be no update for the HP 1012 drivers, thousands of consumers complained about HP's lack of interest in simply updating the drivers for the HP 1012 model. Consumers complaints were not being addressed, and so, HP decided, for no explainable reason, not to provide an updated driver for the HP 1012. This left with consumers having to dispose of a good functioning laser printer and to fork out money for a new one -- a move that HP hoped to add more profits to their coffers.<br /><br />While this review isn't particularly relative to this model, I wanted to warn consumers of this trend that HP practices.<br /><br />I still have my HP 1012 sitting in my closet.  I only buy from Brother or Samsung now.<br /><br />Update: 03-27-2011:<br /><br />While doing additional research online, I found a proven method for my HP LaserJet 1012 FINALLY(!!!) to work with Windows 7 Professional x64.<br /><br />I read that using the drivers for HP LaserJet 3055 will work.  The only thing required is that you have to force your printer to use the DOT4 port.  Here's how:<br /><br />1.  In Windows 7, open Device and Printers.<br />2.  If your old printer is shown, click on the printer, then click on Remove Device.<br />3.  Click on Add Printer.<br />4.  You'll be ask "What Printer Do You Want to Install".<br />5.  Click on Add Local Printer.<br />6.  In the Use Existing Port, use the drop down menu and click on DOT4_001 Generic IEEE 1284.4, then click Next.<br />7.  Go down the list of manufactures, click on HP, then on the right under Printers, find HP LaserJet 3055 PCL 5.<br />8.  Don't bother selecting the option as a network printer.  Just get the driver installed, and print the test page.<br />9.  You can rename your printer later. Save the printer test page in your file drawer in case you have to come back to determine the drivers and printer name for networking.<br />10. I printed documents successfully in Word and Excel.;;1.0;;March 19, 2011;;10;;17;;0.588235

True to form, the shipment arrived on time and as described.<br /><br />I hooked it up and Windows 7 immediately recognized the printer and I was up and ready to print. I bought this printer for two reasons: I need a color laser printer, and also need to do light scanning, maybe 60 pages a week. I didn't want to shell out another $500-$750 for a dedicated sheet-fed scanner. This multi-function printer seemed to fill the bill.<br /><br />I followed the installation instructions, inserted the CD and followed the onscreen directions. Everything installed, or so it seemed. I was able to get the scanner to make exactly one scan, as a bmp. I tried several times, but couldn't get it to work with Acrobat. Acrobat wouldn't recognize the unit no matter what I did. I figured it was just a matter of tweaking a setting here and there, but suddenly the scanner just quit working. I couldn't get anything to recognize it, and even re-installed the software thinking maybe a file was missing, or corrupted. Nope. The final cut was when the printer went into sleep mode, and wouldn't wake up without being switched off and unplugged.<br /><br />The included software disc comes with several programs, including a free version of Adobe Acrobat 9. However, the installation routine never asks you if you want to install anything individually, it just asks if you want to continue installing the Brother software. I forgot that the unit ships with a free version of Acrobat 9, because I already own it. This damned thing installed its own version of Acrobat 9 over mine without any warning. I had to uninstall their version, reinstall my Adobe download and go find the serial numbers of Acrobat 9 as well as Acrobat 6, the version I upgraded from. Thanks, Brother, but some people actually already own certain programs and it's not an upgrade to use an OEM licensed product over the one they already paid for (and customized - that also pissed me off - I lost the settings and everything else that I'd already set up in Acrobat). The scanner software that comes with the unit is PaperPort, which is a kludge I've had to deal with before, and a couple of other minor league programs not worth mentioning. Scanning software seems to be one area of computing that doesn't really work that well, but I generally scan to directly to Acrobat, bypassing that problem. There was a control panel-type software program that allowed the user to access all the setup screens so one doesn't have to stand in front of the printer for an hour setting it up.<br /><br />If you really need a multifunction printer, this one might be okay if you get a unit that works and skip the software as much as possible. I know, defective units happen, but it's frustrating to get one nonetheless. Had it not been for the software hassle, I might have asked for an exchange, but the software suite is so bad I just didn't ever want to see the name Brother on anything I own.<br /><br />I can't say enough good things about Amazon - they immediately took the return, scheduled the pickup and the unit was on its way back to Amazon within 24 hours.;;1.0;;March 25, 2011;;14;;27;;0.518519

Two are one step down but still excellent the 50MM 1.4 and 10 to 22mm 3.5 both by Canon.  Also read some popular books on photography by Peterson and Scott Kelby. In fact digital photos started with telescopes.  Telescopes have a much harder time getting good pictures due to low light, extreme distance, and earth rotation, etc.  To overcome these difficulties "good" telescope pictures require STEADY MOUNTS (i.e. tripod) and good glass (like Legacy).<br /><br />  Everyday digital camera pics can be hand held without a tripod and one unchangeable fixed or zoom lens.  BUT if you want to go to the NEXT LEVEL.  Get a good tripod with a good ballhead and put a good camera on it that uses superior glass.  Superior glass starts around $500 (prime lens) and for the zooms about $1000 and go higher.  One of them most popular Canon L glass zooms is $1600.  With the Canon 40D or current 50D at around $1200.  This next level is expensive.<br /><br />  Taken pictures all my life and studied the technicals about exposures etc.  Higher end digital cameras like the changeable lens Canons and Nikons cost upwards of $750 with QUALITY lens have many features that are not easy to use without some serious effort to learn how.  Perhaps many just use the "AUTO" settings.  Fine for them.  If your do your homework, I needed a couple supplimental instructions manuals for my Canon 40D, you can begin taking pics that allow cropping and large prints with amazing clarity.  Often one manual unclear but with the second manual comparisons learned about hundreds of options that can be programmed into camera for specific types of photography, ref: mirror lockup, white balance, full program, live view, etc.  Different lens allow specific pics advantages.  Peterson's books excellent on this.<br /><br />  Photo editors like Picasa3 make it pretty easy to take medium quality pics and crop to gems within.  Try all the tools back and forth to see what looks more pleasing.  Perhaps ONE PERCENT of original pics are perfect as taken.  The other ninety nine percent can be improved with editing, IMHO.  All the equipment described above will give you original pics of such high quality there is plenty of room for editing.  Proof me for is the difference between pics from the Canon SX10 IS and the Canon 40D with the Legacy lens and this Canon Pixma Pro9000Mk II.<br /><br />  Every time you move a digital pic in your computer you will loose some detail.  When you take the pic and store it on you computer you already have lost quite a bit unless you use RAW format.  All those megs used for each pics which the cameras advertise can be misleading if you fail to realize how reduced the pics are when you transfer off the original camera storage card and then move to digital processors and CROP and edit etc. Pro9000MkII prints with such sharpness that you need all the quality in the original you can manage.<br /><br />  If you take quality pics and edit well the Pro9000MkII will give you some prints that made me appreciate why taking the pics about half the process of creating beautiful pictures. RWDQ42BBX3817;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A1Q5G0ZCRGX8LB;;Printer;;B004G5ZZO6;;Brother MFCJ6510DW Business Inkjet All-in-One Printer with 11-Inch x 17-Inch Duplex Printing and 11-Inch x 17-Inch Scan Glass;;Brother... What a God-Send!;;After 5 years of searching and 5 different printers, I finally found the "gem" I needed.  I purchased this printer in March 2011, so I have now used it for 1 YEAR and 3 MONTHS without a hitch.  I have an online business and use the printer for scanning (200+ photos a day) and printing various size papers and envelopes (up to 200 pages a day).  Never used the fax.  I use it with a Dell PC and Windows 7.  With that background, let me give some comments based on experience...<br /><br />THE GOOD STUFF...<br /><br />... I love the wireless feature!  We have multiple computers and can print from any of them throughout the house without running wires all over the place.<br /><br />... I buy the XXL CARTRIDGES and they LAST A LONG TIME.  Remember, I print up to 200 pages a day (I would guess 80% black, the rest in color), and I have only had to replace my black cartridge 3 times in the past 15 months.  Cartridges are easy to install and although I liked the single full-color cartridge of the HP, I have come to appreciate only having to replace a single color at a time (yellow, blue, or red).  Since I used alot of blue, I've replaced that one 3 times, but the others only twice.  Brother gives you the option of purchasing the color cartridges in a group of 3 or singly.  Nice thing about shopping for brother cartridges... you don't have to wade through 20 different model numbers like the HP!<br /><br />... I can count on one hand how many times this workhorse has jammed.  And those FEW JAMS were very easy to remedy.  The printer itself "walks" you through what you need to do.<br /><br />... I LOVE that this printer will scan and print up to LEDGER SIZE pages!  It will scan 2 full 8 1/2" x 11" pages at a time, which saves me a lot of time.  (A bonus, not related to my business, is that I can scan/copy 12" x 12" Memory Book pages so all my kids can have copies!).  Granted, when it comes to printing, you can only feed one 11" x 17" paper at a time (through the back), but it's awesome if you need larger-size results!  The "touchy" complaint another reviewer gave about feeding the printer through the back can be solved simply by practicing on a few pages until you get a "feel" for it.  I've never had a problem once I got the experience.  And the truth is EVERY printer I've ever owned has some "quirk" you have to get a "feel" for.<br /><br />... ENVELOPES print just fine for me, contrary to other complaints.  But then, I don't specify a size feature on the printer, nor use a special program.  I simply have created a template I use over and over again in MS Word and I run the envelopes through like regular paper in the front tray.  I also run half-sheets of paper through all the time without any problems.  I am so glad that I can do this without having to spend precious time configuring the printer.  Other printers I have had would reject the smaller size pages & envelopes, unless I stopped to configure the printer, which of course is what the manufacturer tells you to do.  But I like simplicity.. and in this case, I love that I can "get around" the configuring and just feed paper and envelopes through without a hassle.<br /><br />THE NOT-SO GOOD...<br /><br />... Occasionaly, the printer pulls through more than one page, but I can avoid that by fanning all new paper (on all sides) before putting in the printer.  Using a higher quality paper (rather than the cheapest you can find) has also helped, especially when it comes to colored paper.  The very fact that the printer will pull through multiple pages (up to 10!) instead of jamming like all the other printers I've owned is a bonus in my opinion.<br /><br />... Cardstock will only work through the back tray, which means you have to feed the pages one at a time.  The finished result is great, but a hassle.  I miss my old HP that would print cardstock in quantities.<br /><br />... Scanning creates a finished picture that is a bit "too yellow" for my liking.  Per others reviews, if you're looking for a printer mostly for printing photos, this one isn't it.  But then all my research brought me to the conclusion that NO printer out there is both great for printing photos AND all the the other stuff, so just get a 2nd printer that can handle high quality photographs.  Anyway, I have a wonderful photo program that only takes a few seconds to "fix" the photo color I scan.  Although I wish I could get the color I want with one step, my fix is easy.  And the advantage of scanning up to ledger size makes up for it.<br /><br />... The reminder that pops up to tell you it's time to replace your cartridges shows up way too soon (I can continue to print for a couple more weeks).  But of course, you can turn this reminder off.<br /><br />RESPONSE TO OTHER REVIEWERS NEGATIVES...<br /><br />... Although this ISN'T a negative for me, I wanted to respond to those who didn't like the fact that you have to pull out the paper tray/carriage to reload.  It's easier than a copy machine, and considering I do it at least once A DAY, there has been no visible wear on the plastic parts and it still works perfectly after all this time.  Putting the carriage back in will "move" the printer on your counter top however, and this was a tiny irritation for me initially.  But I remedied that by using velcro dots to hold it in place.  It would be nice to have 2 drawers, as others have suggested, but I didn't want to go any bigger on printer size (it already takes up twice the space of any other printer I've owned).<br /><br />... About the cartridge mechanism movement that you have to wait on before the printer starts a new order:  Other reviewers have found this irritating, but it helps to understand the other side of the coin.  The reason for the movement that makes you wait on printing, is also the reason that the cartridges last a long time.  Would you rather wait a few extra seconds or buy cartridges more often?  Knowing the advantage, makes me accept the wait time.  The Lexmark I owned was MUCH worse, and did not have the long-life cartridges to offset the cartridge movement.<br /><br />... I too was worried about the flimsy-looking extension you pull out to hold the printed papers, but it's stronger than it looks!  I've even had my 2-year-old granddaughter play with it and pull it down and it's fine.<br /><br />... Someone complained about printer quality options.  There are 4 options to choose from, verses only 3 in other brands.  "Best" isn't the best I've seen in other brands, but still very nice. Be prepared, though, to wait 4 times longer than the "Normal" option for your "Best" page.  The "Fast" option creates a true "rough draft", in other words, a really poor copy.  I use mostly "Normal", and occasionally "High" and am happy with both.<br /><br />... About the scanning time complaint... You can save time with this little trick:  Actual scanning is only the first half of the time, the rest is mechanism return time.  You can remove the page being scanned at the half-way point of the scanning process and get you other page ready by the time the printer is ready to scan again.  So it seems "fast" to me!<br /><br />A FINAL THOUGHT about my "journey" to find this printer:  I had an HP All-in-One 500 model that has lasted 10 years and which I still consider the best purchase I ever made.  Unfortunately, this printer does not work with the new 64-bit computers, even with HP's so-called "fix".  So I went shopping... first to HP because of my excellent experience.  2 different printers that only lasted 2 months each made me realize how far HP has sunk in printer quality.  Lots of research led me to purchase an Epson Workforce.  Worked perfectly for... 1 whole month.  So I took the next best reviewed suggestion and purchased a Lexmark.  Six months later and lots of frustration prompted me to actually buy an older computer that would run my old HP!  Still... I really needed a printer that would work on my new bells-and-whistle computer.  Based on only 1 review at the time of purchase, I went for this Brother machine...<br /><br />... and brother, let me tell you.  What a god-send!;;5.0;;June 3, 2012;;4;;7;;0.571429

No scanning or printing even if the other ink tanks are brand new. If an ink tank is empty, it will give you an error (U163). To get past this error and continue to print, you have to press and hold the Stop button for at least 5 seconds.<br /><br />If you print double-sided, the rear side is printed using color inks, even if you specified grayscale or black-and-white only in your settings. You cannot override this behavior.<br /><br />Also, the company can't be persuaded to write linux printer or scanner drivers for this item. Very frustrating. The European, Asian and Australian versions of these models have linux drivers, but not the US models. A mail merge is where you write a Christmas card to 137 people, lay out an envelope, use the mail merge feature of, say, LibreOffice or Microsoft Word, and print 137 envelopes, each personally addressed so you can match the envelope and the recipient and do in 1 hour what might take days using the method you describe.<br />4:55 PM Yvonne: I don't use Microsoft Office, so I'm sorry but I am not familiar with it's features. The HL-2270DW was not designed primarily as an envelope printer, and where you can feed an envelope 1 at a time through the machine it would not work for large volumes of envelopes. Was there anything else I could address for you today?<br />4:57 PM Ed: A mail merge is a basic office function, not something peculiar to Microsoft software. Yes, you can. Please confirm that each time I want to print an envelope I must start with a new document and print each envelope as a separate job.<br />4:59 PM Yvonne: More then likely yes. If you already have the envelopes created within your application just open them up and print them from there. Load the envelope into the manual feed slot and open the back cover as illustrated in the link provided, then open the envelope you want to print in the application you have it in, then send it to print from there.<br />5:00 PM Ed: Wow. What is the target market for this printer? Is it designed to be used in a home office/small office?<br />5:00 PM Yvonne: Yes, just a basic small home use printer.<br />5:02 PM Ed: I'm curious how they imagine the documents we create would get to the intended destination...I suppose people working at home never need to address more than one envelope at a time. I guess I'm just not using "the machine" properly.<br />5:04 PM Yvonne: Alright, other then the envelope issue did you have any other questions I could address for you?<br />5:05 PM Ed: Nope, I think you've answered my question. R2RGWHN2OSLNTK;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A297MY8QTKGXW4;;Printer;;B000UZH526;;HP LaserJet P1006 Printer;;Important to play the CD first for correct installation info!;;Since I have only had the printer a few days, I can only comment on my first impressions.  I have always been an HP printer supporter from day one.  I have tried other printers but unfortunately I haven't had very good luck with the others and specifically with the Epson Printers.<br /><br />My trusted over the hill HP LaserJet 2100M which I've had since 1998 finally pooped out on me.  I tried to find an equivalent printer thinking that the P1006 is inferior compared to the 2100M, and was hesitant to buy it.  But now that I'm retired and on a limited budget, I really can't afford a very expensive printer and so I purchased the P1006 anyway.<br /><br />Well so far I've been proven wrong in my way of thinking.  This printer works admirably and prints darker and faster than my old trusted HP 2100M.  As far as the noise is concerned, it may be just a wee bit louder than the 2100M but I can't be sure.<br /><br />I used to be a PC and Software instructor for a major computer company and my printing requirements today are not as extensive as it used to be and all I need now is a solid printer that will print out a few pages of my DVD collection, email, receipts for items purchased through the internet and some occassional web pages.<br /><br />I do have two (err!!) three printers.  Two HP inkjet printers and this laser printer.  The important thing to remember with the HP printers is to NOT PLUG IN THE PRINTER CABLE AND POWER UP THE PRINTER ... PRIOR ... to installing the printer driver.  This is IMPERATIVE in most cases or you could have a ton of problems deleting the mess you've created and starting the installation over again.<br /><br />SO BE WARNED in advance as I've run into a couple of problems in the past when I was in a hurry and DID NOT install the drivers first.  VIEW THE CD FIRST as it gives SPECIFIC instructions as what to do .. like removing the Styrofoam inside the printer, a ring and a tape that covers the toner.  If you are NOT aware of these and are in a big hurry, you could ruin the printer and make it a lot harder to get things going than it needs to be.<br /><br />Other than that, enjoy what this printer has to offer.  And for as cheap as it is ... it's a wonderful buy!<br /><br />Oh YES, why it's not a 5 star?  Because it just my initial impression.  I will be back in a month and do an addendum.<br /><br />August 22, 2009 update:<br />Have run into a minor problem in that sometimes the print on the printed material rubs off due to maybe a fuser problem.  What do I mean by that?  A laser printer works similar to a copier in that there is a drum where the images and for a lack of better word are etched into.  This etched area then picks up the black toner and as it rolls on to the paper transfers the image into the paper.  Then the paper goes through a heating element which fuses the toner into the paper.<br /><br />In the olden days of the old Xerox copiers, there was something called fuser oil which helps fuse the image into the paper as it goes through the heating element.  Don't know if the printers of today requires this fuser oil or maybe it's now part of the toner particles.  I seem to have read somewhere where toner these days are a combination of black ink and plastic which is then fused into the paper?  Maybe I read wrong, but regardless, if the imaged is not fused properly into the paper, the images will either not adhere to the paper or will sometimes rub off.<br /><br />In my case it's not all of the printed copies and sometimes only part of the printed copy.  Again, in the old days of the copiers, if the fuser oil is NOT distributed evenly in all areas of the printed material, the print will have a tendency to rub off in that area ... as is what sometimes happens on my printed copies.<br /><br />The question now is whether the problem is with the PRINTER or with the PRINTER CARTRIDGE and or the toner material.  I will certainly find out when it's time to replace the cartridge.  If it ceases, then it would be a good indication that the cartridge is at fault.  Will let you all know further on an update.  Right now I still give it a 4 star.<br /><br />Addendum (7/3/2010)  OK here's the scoop and it's one of those DUH's!  It completely skipped my mind but you really shouldn't try to print on labels that are made for INKJET printers.  That's because some of them are especially coated to keep the LIQUID ink from smearing.  If the paper is not coated then it acts like a blotter and it smears.  Ink Jet printer papers are specially coated to try and avoid this.  So when you run it through a laser printer, the toner will NOT adhere as well and may even flake off.  Which is what I was running into.;;4.0;;August 1, 2009;;3;;5;;0.6

R3CX56MQTBD2SF;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A1ZHF1MR4TK35E;;Printer;;B00450DVDY;;Brother HL-2270DW Compact Laser Printer with Wireless Networking and Duplex;;Printer is good, but be prepared to hack your printer;;The printer is good, if a bit loud. It works as promised, with easy set-up and good speed. This printer, however, is designed to make you send back perfectly good toner when you buy a new cartridge. Some printers continue to print when the toner is low. This one does not. That is not so bad, but there is not an override option. So, when it decides you are out of toner, that is it.<br /><br />On previous Brother printers there was a hack to fool the printer. It involved putting electrical tape over an optical sensor. Those who did this said they got another 1000 pages from the cartridge. Of course, longer cartridge life does not make Brother any money, so this model was designed to prevent that hack. There is no optical sensor. There is a toner flag that you will have to reset.<br /><br />This printer was designed to make you waste toner, Brother figuring that it can sell the printer itself for cheap so long as they make up the difference in frequent replacement cartridge sales. No one will buy a low-volume cartridge, so Brother designed the cartridges so that you cannot use all of them; they get to claim that they give you a lot of toner, and you buy cartridges as though they had not. This printer's design was dictated by Brother's desire to prevent a work-around that people had discovered for previous models. So, if you buy this printer, know that you will have to hack the printer cartridge to get the toner that you pay for. It is a different hack from previous models, this one increasing the chances that you will spill toner on yourself.<br /><br />Of course, there is no flag to set on your starter-cartridge, so there is no way to hack that. When they say it is half full, know that you will only be able to use about half of that half-cartridge.;;2.0;;March 27, 2011;;6;;13;;0.461538
R16LKL00XTCW7W;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A1EQJMUC40ZBPI;;Printer;;B0044XSNH6;;HP LaserJet Pro CP1025nw Color Printer (CE914A);;Horrendous networking;;I'd been on the lookout for a reasonably priced color laser printer.  My wife had a particular need for it for work, and so we picked it up on sale.<br /><br />The print quality is what you'd expect from a color laser, and the toner usage and cost hasn't been bad at all.<br /><br />But it's been a nightmare with regard to network configuration. I've used networked Brother brand printers for years.  With those, it's been incredibly easy and simple to set up from a new computer.  Just add a local printer with a TCP/IP port, choose a printer model that approximates the actual physical device, and off you go.<br /><br />Not so with this printer driver.  The network configuration itself is solid.  I can log into the darn thing via the little built-in web server, ping it, even configure all sorts of settings.  But no matter what I do, I can't seem to get the driver to communicate with the printer reliably.  Here's what I've done:<br /><br />1. Full Feature Software and Driver.  First, it's a 300MB+ download.  You'd expect that the darn thing would be able to search the network and find the printer.  But no.  It prompts each computer to be attached to the printer via USB for initial setup.  Well, OK.  We have laptops, so it's not a huge deal, but I can imagine this could be a problem with reasonably sized networks.  Even this wouldn't be a big deal, except that periodically you need to delete and re-create the printer in Windows.  If I had easy access to the printer via USB, I wouldn't have bought a networked printer.  It would be funny if it weren't sad.  You launch the installer, then selection "Configure to print over the Wireless Network" (as if there were only one "Wireless Network" in the world).  The very next prompt is to plug connect the printer and computer via USB.<br /><br />Sadly, choosing "Configure to print over the Network" yields even sorrier results.  Even when I plug in the IP address, the driver can't seem to figure out there's a printer at the other end.  Remember, the entire time I'm connected to the printer via IP through its embedded web server.<br /><br />Toggling the Windows firewall does nothing in either case.<br /><br />2. HP Laserjet Basic Driver.  So there's a second driver pack, about a 25MB download.  Again, it prompts to connect me to the printer via USB to complete the install.  OK, I do that, but when it tries to detect the printer, no dice, and the only option is to cancel out.<br /><br />3.  The old tried and true.  Create a local printer along with an IP port.  Select "Have windows disk" and then select the .inf from the directory to which I've extracted the "basic install" executable package with 7-zip.  Not bad.  I can print, until I reboot.  At which point I have to re-create the printer within Windows. Jumping Jehosaphat.<br /><br />Now, lest you blame me for keeping a quirky network - it's really clean.  Maybe a half-dozen clients.  I have multiple VOIP devices on it (a Microcell and Vonage device), as well as an old B/W Brother printer that's been working flawlessly for about 5 years now.  The kicker is that the HP Network Diagnostic Utility finds the stupid printer just fine regardless of the Windows firewall state.<br /><br />Long story short, I gave my wife a 6 foot USB cable and she plugs it in when she needs to print color.  Otherwise, she prints to our brother laser printer.  It's cheaper per page anyway.<br /><br />If I had to do it over again, I'd spend the extra $100 on the Brother color laser.;;2.0;;January 14, 2012;;4;;6;;0.666667

R3TGTNV7N8QL78;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A38ZCA48T80A3G;;Printer;;B000J1HPK8;;Canon Pixma Pro9000 Professional Large Format Inkjet Printer (9995A001);;Print Head Clogs;;I have had the Pro-9000 for a couple of years now, and it is a great printer when it works.  The problem is that the print head often gets clogged, or print cartridges have problems. I use only official Cannon cartridges, but they still have a high failure rate.  Many times, the chip will read empty before the ink is really used up.  Fortunately, you can force an override by holding down the resume/cancel button when the error occurs. I have developed the ritual that everytime I am going to print a photo, I first run the nozzle check utility.  This indicates if all 8 colors are printing cleanly.  Most times one color is not printing at all, or several have streaks indicating that the nozzle is clogged.  In that case, I run the nozzle cleaning function.  This usually doesn't work but it does use up lots of ink.  The next step is to run the deep cleaning function which also generally does not work (8 times out of 10) and uses up more ink.  Finally,  I take out the print head and soak it in 95% or better alcohol solution, and then dry with compressed air.  I estimate that at least half of my ink cartridges get consumed in cleaning and trying to get all 8 colors to print cleanly.  I need to budget 2 hours or more whenever I intend to make a print to go through this ritual, and then in some cases after all of the above nothing works so I give up and start over the next time I need to print a photo.  I have had it, but the problem is I have heard that many high quality photo printers have these problems due to ink quality and the tiny size print head nozzles.  Nevertheless I am on a search for a more reliable large format high quality photo printer.;;3.0;;June 19, 2010;;3;;5;;0.6

R3Q8PETXPD4PP4;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A3KOJ2KZLDOBCT;;Printer;;B004ULP9QA;;Brother Printer DCP7065DN Monochrome Laser Multi-Function Copier;;Extremely Annoying Toner-Low Notifications;;I have used Brother printers and multi-function machines for years, and found them to be very reliable and relatively economical, especially on a per page basis.  In the present market for such devices, it is obvious that prices of machines have dropped and manufacturers are relying on sales of supplies for their profit.  This is understandable to a point.  With the Brother 7065 series, the efforts of Brother to sell supplies have reached the point where my next machine will likely be something other than a Brother.  Soon after I got it, my Brother DCP7065DN machine began causing a low toner warning to appear in not one, but two separate popups on my screen.  And this would happen again, and again, and again, and again.  They wouldn't just pop up, one would have to be clicked to make it go away.  An obvious effort to sell additional toner cartridges.  I'd purchased a new replacement cartridge when I bought the machine.  I've been using the machine for a long time after the warnings started popping up, and it has not run out of toner.  Meanwhile, the annoying messages keep interfering with my work.  I searched in vain in the Brother software setup for something to turn off for good the toner warning feature.<br /><br />Another conspicuous change in the Brother line is that toner cartridge capacities have been growing much smaller, while prices of toner cartridges have not. Once, Brother printers and cartridges were an outstanding value because of the long toner cartridge life.  Now that smaller but expensive cartridges that need to be replaced more often are being coupled with incessant and annoying onscreen messages nagging to buy a new expensive cartridge and have it ready, not only is the value gone, but the annoyance is enough that I'll be choosing another brand machine for my next, and I may even dump this one while it is still working fine mechanically.<br /><br />UPDATE<br /><br />An email to Brother customer service produced the following response on how to turn off the warning popups:<br /><br />"1. Locate the Status monitor icon located in the bottom right of your<br />computer next the clock.<br /><br />2. Right click on the "Brother Status Monitor" and select Options =><br />Details.<br /><br />3. In the Details window, click on the settings tab and locate Windows<br />settings and then remove the check from all 3 boxes.<br /><br />4. Click OK."<br /><br />I emailed back to Brother the following response, after turning off the printer warning notification as instructed, but I noted that in so doing I was turning off all warning notifications:<br /><br />"Thank you for the information.<br /><br />Turning off ALL warning notifications is not really a satisfactory response to a nagging "toner low" warning that just won't quit popping up.  You need something on the "toner low" message that I can click that says 'I get it - my toner is low - you don't need to tell me fifty times - don't tell me again'.  If, for example, my drum life becomes low, I want to know, I just don't want to know fifty times."<br /><br />FURTHER UPDATE<br /><br />On receiving the "fix" instructions, and assuming they would work, I upgraded my one star review to two stars.  Now I am downgrading it to one star again.  The fix did not work.  It stopped one of the two popups, the less annoying one, and left the large one popping up that blots out my computer screen annoyingly when I am trying to get work done and requires me to click "OK" to get rid of it, the toner low warning.  To me, the impossible to get rid of "Toner Low" warning doesn't say "Toner Low", it says "Don't Buy Another Brother."  The toner, by the way, may be "low", but it isn't "out" and keeps printing away fine.  I suppose that Brother assumes that I'll run out and keep buying new Toner cartridges each time the popup comes up.;;1.0;;August 6, 2012;;3;;6;;0.5

I have it hooked up to one machine via USB and it is also on the network. It is fast to print, fast to copy, fast to scan. If you don't need faxing, you can go with the less expensive but otherwise identical x363.<br /><br />The bad: Lexmark provides no 64-bit linux scanner drivers, period. This is not revealed anywhere, and I had even gone to the trouble of checking out the scanning manual available at the excellent Lexmark web site. A general lack of scanner drivers is a common state of affairs in the Linux world, but given the explicit support for linux for this printer (one of the reasons I bought it) I assumed wrongly that the scanner drivers would be available in both 32 and 64-bit. Lexmark technical support responded within 24 hours, as promised, but the response was useless and I never thought they understood my question (when would 64-bit drivers be available). There are 32-bit scanner drivers. They're a little clunky, but scanning does work, e.g. via xsane.<br /><br />On the other hand, the Linux printing support (via cups), is excellent.<br /><br />UPDATE: As of mid 2011, there is now a 64-bit linux scan driver, and, while clumsy, it works! To find it, google "network-scan-linux-glibc2-x86_64.deb". Because of this I've raised my rating to 4 stars.;;4.0;;May 4, 2010;;6;;10;;0.6

R1G6D9D0SV07GA;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/AMC179VKCVTLM;;Printer;;B006Y7WZG0;;Epson WorkForce WF-7510 Wireless All-in-One Wide-Format Color Inkjet Printer, Copier, Scanner, Fax (C11CA96201);;Take a pass on this;;I have always been an HP person - had several printers over the past 12 years and loved them. Lately I haven't been hearing good things about them. Once my last HP started to fail I looked around and came upon this all-in-one. I was very excited to try something new - the overall Epson ratings from the public have been very encouraging. I'm no techno-geek but I'm no beginner either. Whereas I can set up a stand-alone or a network printer with my eyes closed this was a nightmare. They include drawings with the "get started" instructions but they are small (I have perfect vision). If I have trouble understanding what the drawing is supposed to represent I can't imagine what a person wearing glasses will see. Here's a hint though - if you're good at figuring out "Where's Waldo" you probably won't have a problem. The directions are good, until you hit a road block. The instructions then tell you "follow the steps on the screen" but at that point there's no place to turn! They suggest you look on-line under "Help" but they don't tell you where to go? I had to call support FIVE times to finally get it working. And that's another thorn in my side - their support is only available Mon-Sat and it's not 24x7. And it's not toll-free. Unlimited toll calling is included in my phone package but it's just the principle that gets me. The phone number to dial is California but you're transported to the Philippines. Everyone is pleasant - the first representative spoke VERY good English - hardly an accent. All the other representatives I could barely understand and had to ask them to repeat themselves multiple times. If you ask them a question not scripted in front of them they have to put you on hold and ask someone. That tells me that not only are the customers not given good instruction - their support representatives aren't either. Also - during the entire conversations it sounds like the wind is whistling in the background. I just pictured them on a beach while the vein on my forehead was about ready to pop. Okay - so now I've used it for a week. I'm still not thrilled with this thing. Scanning takes FOR-EV-ER - my grandmother's wheelchair is faster. It takes close to 2 minutes per page! However - the scanning, once completed is very crisp and clear - very nice. Printing - this thing takes 4 cartridges - 1 black and 3 color. Despite the 3 color cartridges I don't feel certain colors are "true" - especially grey - it seems more purply. One nice feature about this machine - which is why I purchased it - it will scan legal-sized documents. So that's a plus if you're looking for that. Of course that makes the footprint of the machine much bigger but it has to be for that very reason. I do wish they would offer this model sans fax - who doesn't use an electronic fax? Without the fax the front plate wouldn't be so cluttered with buttons. All-in-all I doubt I will grow to like this any better - the scanning (which I do a lot of) is just too freakin' slow. I hope I don't ever have to call their "helpless" desk again but I somehow foresee that in the future. The ONLY reason I don't send it back is because I have too much time invested in getting the damn thing hooked up. The thought of having the package the brut up again and then shop for another machine is more than I can handle at this point. I sent Epson a review with similiar comments above and they rejected it; I guess the truth hurts. If I had to do over again I would pass on this machine - definitely.;;1.0;;February 12, 2012;;10;;20;;0.5

It has tubes that run from them to the printhead.  This means that it is verry easy to setup a CIS (external ink tanks) to the printer.  On my old printer I had to keep the lid open so that the ink tubes could run from the tank to the printhead. But I am not surprised. I also cannot recommend HP as a brand any longer because of my professional experience where I am finding that these type of quality defects are common in 2 of every 10 devices I've leased in the past 2 years. When you turn this printer on, it takes- and I'm not exaggerating- 5 minutes of rollers spinning and motors making noises before it's ready to print, even if there is a print task pending. During this time, there's nothing you can do except wait patiently. Kicking the printer does not accelerate this process. Reason 2) yeah this printer is wireless- BUT.. very frequently, the computer will lock up during printing, because there's a message holding everything up on the printer screen. To bypass said message, you have to physically walk over to your printer, and press the chintzy plasticy OK button on the printer. Then, and only then may printing commence. This totally defeats the purpose of wireless printing. You get these manual-bypass messages everytime the printer gets unplugged unexpectedly, or every time you print and the cartridges are getting low. Reason 3) and this one just infuriates me.. when the ink cartridge "Gets low" (aka, when the printer THINKS it's low), you can't print ANYTHING ANYMORE. Right now, my CYAN cartridge is dead. You can't just take out the cyan cartridge and pop it back in either, because each ink tank has a microchip that stores how many pages it's printed. A software limitation deliberately programmed by the greedy dou--e nozzles at Canon stops the hardware altogether. Canon, I'm gonna go buy new cartridges, in the meantime, I NEED THIS TO PRINT RIGHT NOW.. SERIOUSLY. I am smashing this printer in my basement. Don't waste your money.. I've owned various lower priced Canon printers before and was always pleased with them. And I've owned a comparatively expensive Epson photo printer that only worked for a *very* short while before it was no longer feasible to keep it repaired, no more Epsons for me. This Canon is a breath of fresh air just like I hoped it would be. The prints are gorgeous, leaving me with little to no excuse to send out printing to pro labs anymore. So far I've only used Canon photo paper including the amazing Pro Platinum paper. That's some good stuff.<br /><br />Setup was very easy, took only a few minutes from the time of hoisting that behemoth out of the box. Noise level is low enough that I don't pay any attention to it. And the speed is fine since I'm not doing bulk printing. Ink consumption is pretty much along with what I expected, which is good news. I've ordered in but not replaced yet the two photo inks, cyan and magenta. I do NOT plan to run any aftermarket ink through this printer, I want to keep it working just like it is for as long as I can. A cheap Walmart style printer is okay to take chances with ink carts.<br /><br />While I've not had any bad prints from this printer yet, they don't truly match what is on my monitor, so I've bought an X-Rite i1 monitor calibrator and expect to have that all worked out before the end of the week. It's not the printer's fault, just be aware that the picture you see on the screen may not match what comes out of the printer if you don't do calibrations on the monitor.<br /><br />Last thoughts - I've seen discussions on the perfect stand for this printer. After all, it IS big and heavy just like a pro level printer should be. What I did was pull a 3'x5' dining room table with sturdy legs out of storage and made it my printer stand. Yes, it's oversized to some degree but that gives me room to lay out prints for critical side-by-side viewing and so forth.<br /><br />If you're thinking about buying this printer to turn beautiful digital photos into beautiful prints, I'd say go for it.;;5.0;;October 4, 2011;;4;;6;;0.666667

After initial set up with the disk in mac and hooked up via usb the first test page came out and it looked fine to me.  text looked really sharp (even though some reviews said to pick the fine detail setting for best text)  I could not find that setting either on the printer or on the software.  It looked pretty good to me anyway.  Some have commented about the paper exit tray being a little flimsy....and it is, and i will probably just have it come out enough to gently guide the paper out and down, partially resting on the desk.  I think full extending the multiple sleeved thin plastic tray will eventually just fall apart.  It probably could have been made thicker and more robust.  All the other points felt firm and solid.  The scanner lid felt solid as did the cover for the ink area.  The ADF cover that folds down is also a little thin like the paper tray but unlike the output tray the ADF tray is supported better on both ends and is of one piece construction.  The touch screen is bring easy to adjust and reset, with bright clear graphics and easy to press buttons.  The display is not to busy with useless information and the touch screen is not too hard or soft in the response to touch.  Ink usage will be of little concern due to the purchase of a CIS. When it arrived I will set it up and give it a review as well.  Upon initial assessment of build quality and setup, the printer seems to be a winner.  I have to tested it to see how well it prints to the included printable cd or how well photos look but from the reviews i have read it most likely will not be an issue.  now its time to wipe a little of the dust that showed up on the shiny black parts.;;5.0;;July 10, 2011;;3;;5;;0.6

(Canon printers do this automatically)<br />- Photo printing software not as nice as the Canon software is.<br />- This printer is VERY large, much larger than I expected.<br /><br />Comments:  I am very happy with this printer so far. Well that is 100% false, as the two papers I have listed above work great on it, and I would bet most higher quality paper does... In another review, someone said they used "Office Depot Platinum series Gloss Professional Photo Paper".  I would not use Kodak paper with this though, as it never works with any other brands of printer from my experience.  Remember to also lay the paper face down in the paper tray so it prints on the correct side.<br /><br />I did have a few times where it draws more than one page through the printer.  From what I can tell so far, it seems to happen when I use a rougher type paper, then the friction causes it to drag the paper underneath it through also.  When I use smoother paper it doesn't seem to happen.  I have also been able to print fine on heavy 110lb Card Stock that I use for greeting cards I print, with no jams.<br /><br />This printer is larger than I expected.  I had a hard time finding a place to put it.  I plan on using 3rd party ink and cartridges, although they won't have the fade resistance the real Epson ink does. R39QRJF39ZSJ9;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A3CDF86VUZ1PZG;;Printer;;B003XDU8OE;;Epson Artisan 835 Wireless All-in-One Color Inkjet Printer, Copier, Scanner, Fax (C11CA73201);;Huge Printer;;I have bought several Epson printers through the years. The first was an Epson Stylus 1400, I think. After that one, I swore I would NEVER buy another Epson printer because the ink was so expensive and the print heads become so clogged that there is no fixing them. After literally stomping on the first one, I swore them off. Then, they came out with printers that print directly to CD/DVD, so after several years of not owning an Epson, I purchased the Rx595 Stylus Printer. It printed as expected, beautiful prints (after cleaning the print heads to prevent lines appearing) and my CD's came out beautifully. However, after some weeks of non-use, I went to use the printer, and sure enough... the print heads were clogged. I attempted to clean them time and again, going through the very expensive ink rather quickly, and they would not unclog (the Cyan). Banding was horrible, and of course, I couldn't get the printer to print the color blue. After going through about $100.00 worth of ink, I went in search of a new printer, but could not find one that printed to CD's and ended up purchasing this one, the Artisan 835. Set up was pretty easy, the WiFi is a handy addition. And it prints beautifully. I was able to get it at Best Buy for $199.00. It comes with all the inks and an extra black in (98) -- all the other inks are the 99 standard size. The Artisan can print to CD and the colors are true and quite stunning. It is HUGE. The footprint of this thing is far larger than it needs to be, so make sure you have the space for it. It has a protrusion from the back, which I assume assists in double sided printing, but if you don't have much space around your computer, this thing will need a table all its own.<br /><br />Regardless, I give the Epson two stars. The reason for this is because Epson's are NOTORIOUSLY WASTEFUL and break down far quicker than any other printer I've ever owned. The rather expensive inks are wasted when the printer charges the inks, and when you clean the print heads, the ink is wasted in loads... and YOU WILL HAVE TO CLEAN THE PRINTHEADS even if you print daily. In addition, I have never been able to keep an Epson printer longer than approximately two years because of print head clogging. While there is apparently some way to remove the print head and clean them, such a task is no simple matter and it will surely void your warranty. The ONLY reason to purchase this or any other Epson printer is if you want speciality printing, such as on a CD. Otherwise, if you just want fantastic prints on paper, envelops, etc., then go to HP, Cannon or some other manufacturer. For example, I have a Cannon Pixma that is about four years old and it still prints like a dream and I have NEVER had a SINGLE problem with it... other than it does not print to CD's. Epson's charge you through the tooth for ink and then end up wasting it cleaning the print heads (you'd think they would at least come up with a system where you could clean ONLY the print head that was clogged... or better yet... come up with a system where the print heads did not become clogged so easily). I expect this printer to last as long as the other Epson's I have had and to behave in the same manner... after about a month, every time I want to print a nice photo or other color print, I will waste half the ink cleaning clogged print heads and test runs to get the perfect print. This is unacceptable in a printer that boasts it can do artist quality prints. And when you are going to pay close to $80.00 for the color and then the black ink only to have it ALL WASTED... well, you do the math. I wrote tech support a couple of times, but got no resolution.  I use this Canon as my "workhorse" printer, where 99% of what I print is in black and white and in FAST mode.  In spite of those settings, all my color and photo black ink cartridges go down continually, even thought I'm producing almost no color documents.  Tech Support told me that this is caused by two things:  every time you shut your computer down and bring it up, each cartridge jettisons the ink it has in its holding chamber to "clean" the cartridge nozzle.  The only way to avoid this is to leave your printer going 24/7 so that it doesn't go through the cleaning process.  Also, when I asked how I could set the printer to only use the large black ink cartridge, they said there really isn't a way.  If you set it to FAST, GRAYSCALE, you supposedly will use the least color ink, but since Canon produces shades of gray using color cartridges, you can't totally eliminate their usage.<br /><br />I feel this is a real design flaw, both energy wise (leave it on 24/7!) and ink-wise (you can't just use black ink).<br /><br />I'm disappointed in this feature because it means I'm replacing all my ink cartridges much faster than you'd ever expect (and not getting the benefit of their use!). R8I78IGDNLGP8;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A16D8DLTN5JJWS;;Printer;;B002E1RITO;;HP Officejet 7000 Wide Format Printer (C9299A#B1H);;Photo printing is defective for Linux;;Users of the Linux operating system cannot adjust this printer to print photos properly.  Under Linux Fedora Core 11, the printer that I purchased left evenly spaced lines running across the image perpendicular to the direction of the paper feed.  This is well known problem with inkjet printers and HP has a page about troubleshooting it.  However, all the directions on that page describe using a program that runs under Windows.  The HP linux compatibility page for this product says that two important troubleshooting functions, "calibrate linefeed" and "print diagnostic page" are not supported for Linux.  (The "print diagnostic page" is different than a "test page" or an "alignment page", which are supported.)<br /><br />I was able to install the printer and have it recognized with no difficulty in Fedora Core 11.<br /><br />To demonstrate that the defective printing was not a problem with the printer hardware, I installed the printer on machine running Windows Vista Home Edition.  I downloaded the "full" driver from the HP site.  When this file is run, it installs the printer.  ( Run the file; don't extract it first.)  I printed the same photo from Windows Photo Gallery and the spurious lines were gone.<br /><br />The printer advertises 13 x 19 inch "borderless" printing.  I have not found any settings in Linux or in Windows Vista that produce a true 13 x 19 borderless print.  In Linux, I used Gimp (the "GNU Image Manipuluation Program"). In the page setup, I defined a custom paper size of 13 x 19 inches with zero sized borders.  In the printer setup, I tried to set the image size to 13 x 19, but this option was never allowed.  I was able to print a nearly 13 x 19 inch image, but part of the image was truncated and narrow borders did appear on the print.  In Windows Vista, Windows Photo Gallery, I set the paper size to "Super B 13x19in".  This produced a similar result, a nearly 13 x 19 image, but truncated to allow narrow borders.  Of course, there may be some other software or combinations of settings that produce borderless printing, but my straightforward attempts didn't work.<br /><br />I discovered that it is possible to print on canvas taken from a pad of primed artist's canvas.  This isn't a completely reliable process.  Sometimes the printer simply ejects the sheet without printing.  It doesn't work at all in humid weather when the canvas is limp.  Canvas is not a recommended media and the image must be sprayed with fixative to keep it from dissolving when it comes in contact with water or other solvents.<br /><br />This printer's ink cartridges do not have build-in print heads. The printer relies of feeding ink from the cartridges to a permanently installed print head.  It needs 4 cartridges, the HP #920 series: black, cyan, magenta,yellow.<br /><br />The combination of this printer and its driver under Windows is very sensitive to paper width. Don't count on using a paper width that doesn't show up in the print set-up menu.  Even though the image would fit on paper that is a fraction of an inch wider than the standard size, the printer/driver may detect that the paper is the wrong width and cause the job to error.  If you are cutting your own paper, you must get the width to match the width of one of the standard paper sizes listed by the print menu.<br /><br />The printer won't work with paper that is much thicker than standard photo paper.  For example, I found that a moderately thick watercolor paper will feed through the machine quite well, but the printer will only print about the first inch of the picture.  Then it ejects the paper, as if it has detected an error.<br /><br />This is the first wide format printer that I have owned, so I can't compare it to other similar products.  I rate it three stars to indicate that it is an average  deal.;;3.0;;October 13, 2009;;5;;8;;0.625

R9A5MWP7YZJJG;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A3E83CGPBC4VR0;;Printer;;B006M1MSKG;;HP Officejet 6700 Premium e-All-in-One Wireless Color Photo Printer with Scanner, Copier and Fax;;Disappointment;;I have used HP Printers now for years and never had an issue until now.  I'm a world-class photographer with many shows here in Atlanta.  If you haven't noticed, HP neglected in its design of this printer to include a Photo Black cartridge, a fatal flaw!  What this means is that the blacks won't be a deeper black like in an Ansel Adams photograph.<br /><br />For instance, I compared the wings of a Monarch butterfly as printed by my old HP C309 Premium Printer and my new HP Office Jet 6700 Printer side by side and one can see wings as printed on my old HP are much blacker. The new HP gives them a brownish black. According to the Wall Street Journal, HP has over 1,000 ink scientists working at their Palo-Alto headquarters. This is one task they failed. The Black Cartridge is no substitute for the effects of the Photo Black and the regular Black working in unison to produce a superior print. As they say, the proof is in the pudding.  Since both of these printers has the word Premium on its face, one might easily assume that the print is comparable but such is not the case.  It's as if Col. Sanders had changed his secret recipe for his chicken without telling anyone and now one finds himself eating turkey instead of chicken!  I'm glad to see that HP has released a new version of this printer that might correct this deficiency. Tomorrow, I plan to return this printer and place an order with Amazon for a printer that still has the photo black cartridge as one of its main components. It finally gave up the ghost. After some research (and the fact that it went on sale at Office Depot), I decided on the HL-2240. My first impression ... it's a lot noisier than my 1440 was. Part of the reason is because Brother decided to shift the exhaust fan from the left side to the right side of the printer (something I didn't notice in the store), so I now I get to listen to it until it decides to shut off and go back into sleep mode. I can handle noise while the actual printing is taking place (and it does make it's fair share of noise while printing), but I don't really appreciate having to listen to the exhaust fan hum for 3 minutes afterwards. So this being the case, you might want to consider getting the higher end model with networking capability so you can locate the printer farther away from your desk. USB cables don't come in long enough lengths to allow relocation of the printer to someplace where the noise won't be so annoying. Other than the noise issue, the printer seems to do what it's supposed to do. Hard to complain about $79.95 for a printer, even if the toner cartridge is a "starter" version.;;3.0;;October 25, 2010;;10;;14;;0.714286

RVNY6F6WM9Q6P;;http://www.amazon.com/gp/pdp/profile/A7415MVFF0112;;Printer;;B0067PTW3I;;Brother MFC9325CW Wireless Color Printer with Scanner, Copier & Fax;;Offsetting penalties;;If I were a football referee, I would have dropped a flag every time this scanner needed to interact with any PC on my network.  It has an Ethernet card, it has a USB port, it has wireless connectivity and it would be penalized 15 yards every time I attempted to do a software scan or fax.  Since my scanning needs are about 50/50 with my printing needs, there is a 15 yard gain, every time I print, because the prints on this printer are amazing!  I love the prints!  We love the prints. I can print every time!  But blast that non-communicating document management system!  Did they even try and QA the thing?  Did they test it in a bubble?  If you need a network scanner and or fax, forget this one.  If you need an OUTSTANDING PRINTER, then buy the NON MFC version and save yourself some money and aggravation.  If you already bought it, and you don't have any troubles with your network scanning and faxing, then you need to check your network, because if you are wide open to this very chatty printer, then you obviously have a gaping hole in your firewall.  It seems that somewhere in Japan, someone needs an update on this printer, like 50,000 times a day. Seriously, the printer is not botted, brand new off the shelf, and it needs to tell someone in Japan, everything!  You can block this, of course, but then whoever it is that's talking to my beloved Brother MFC, gets ticked and locks you down from getting SW updates, they tell the remote configuration utility to refuse to access setup, and the whole printer complains it can't see when you select the Scan or Fax button on the control panel.  On top of that, we get this unrecoverable sleep mode.  When this printer goes to sleep, it can't wake up unless (and Wireshark is great for showing this, so is OPEN DNS) the printer-lord in Japan tells it to.  You can press that evil scan button all day long, but it isn't going to obey.  So the game is now tied, at zero, no team is able to move the ball, and we are left with a great scanner that wont scan, a fax that wont fax, and a printer who just longs to print great looking pages.  The last thing that bugs me, is this.  If you have photo-shop and you want to scan, the scanner utility is great.  But there's no option to trouble shoot the network aspect.  The scanner utility shows you the printer is discoverable on the network, it shows you a cool picture that leads you down the path towards hoping you can scan, but get ready for a 10 to 15 minute wait until you can actually see a message (which says nothing but placating techno gibberish about how you failed to get a first down and you have to punt), and then it still does not tell you what the problem actually is.  Kind of like the fat guy on Jurassic Park, wagging his finger mockingly, telling you that you can't do what ever it is you want to do, even though you own the system - until you say the magic word.
